Index">79th</a></td></tr><tr><th scope="row">Currency</th><td><a href="/wiki/Brazilian_real" title="Brazilian real">Real</a> (R$) (<a href="/wiki/ISO_4217" title="ISO 4217">BRL</a>)</td></tr><tr numbers in Brazil">Calling code</a></th><td><a href="/wiki/Telephone_numbers_in_Brazil" title="Telephone numbers in Brazil">+55</a></td></tr><tr><th scope="row"><a href="/wiki/ISO_3166" title="ISO 3166">ISO 3166 code</a></th><td><a href="/wiki/ISO_3166-2:BR" title="ISO 3166-2:BR">BR</a></td></tr><tr><th scope="row"><a href="/wiki/Country_code_top-level_domain" title="Country code top-level domain">Internet TLD</a></th><td><a href="/wiki/.br" title=".br">.br</a></td></tr></tbody></table>\n<p><b>Brazil</b> (<a href="/wiki/Portuguese_language" title="Portuguese language">Portuguese</a>: <i lang="pt">Brasil</i> <small>Portuguese pronunciation:&#160;</small><span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/Portuguese" title="Help:IPA/Portuguese">[b&#638;a&#712;ziw]</a></span>),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-9"><a href="#cite_note-9">[nt 1]</a></sup> officially the <b>Federative Republic of Brazil</b> (Portuguese: <i lang="pt">Rep&#250;blica Federativa do Brasil</i>, <span class="unicode haudio"><span class="fn"><span style="white-space:nowrap;margin-right:.25em;"><a href="/wiki/File:Pt-br-Rep%C3%BAblica_Federativa_do_Brasil.ogg" title="About this sound"><img alt="About this sound" data-file-height="20" data-file-width="20" decoding="async" height="11" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/11px-Loudspeaker.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/17px-Loudspeaker.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/22px-Loudspeaker.svg.png 2x" width="11"/></a></span><a class="internal" href="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/b/b7/Pt-br-Rep%C3%BAblica_Federativa_do_Brasil.ogg" title="Pt-br-Rep&#250;blica Federativa do Brasil.ogg">listen</a></span>&#160;<small class="metadata audiolinkinfo" style="cursor:help;">(<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Media_help" title="Wikipedia:Media help"><span style="cursor:help;">help</span></a>&#183;<a href="/wiki/File:Pt-br-Rep%C3%BAblica_Federativa_do_Brasil.ogg" title="File:Pt-br-Rep&#250;blica Federativa do Brasil.ogg"><span style="cursor:help;">info</span></a>)</small></span>),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Bello1966v_10-0"><a href="#cite_note-Bello1966v-10">[9]</a></sup> is the largest country in both <a href="/wiki/South_America" title="South America">South America</a> and <a href="/wiki/Latin_America" title="Latin America">Latin America</a>. At 8.5&#160;million square kilometers (3.2&#160;million square miles)<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-11"><a href="#cite_note-11">[10]</a></sup> and with over 208 million people, Brazil is the world\'s <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_countries_and_outlying_territories_by_total_area" title="List of countries and outlying territories by total area">fifth-largest country by area</a> and the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_population" title="List of countries by population">fifth most populous</a>. The capital is <a href="/wiki/Bras%C3%ADlia" title="Bras&#237;lia">Bras&#237;lia</a>, and <a href="/wiki/List_of_largest_cities_in_Brazil" title="List of largest cities in Brazil">the most populated city</a> is <a href="/wiki/S%C3%A3o_Paulo" title="S&#227;o Paulo">S&#227;o Paulo</a>. The federation is composed of the union of the 26 <a href="/wiki/States_of_Brazil" title="States of Brazil">states</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Federal_District_(Brazil)" title="Federal District (Brazil)">Federal District</a>, and the 5,570 <a href="/wiki/Municipalities_of_Brazil" title="Municipalities of Brazil">municipalities</a>. It is the largest country to have <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_language" title="Portuguese language">Portuguese</a> as an <a href="/wiki/List_of_territorial_entities_where_Portuguese_is_an_official_language" title="List of territorial entities where Portuguese is an official language">official language</a> and the only one in the <a href="/wiki/Americas" title="Americas">Americas</a>;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Philander2012_12-0"><a href="#cite_note-Philander2012-12">[11]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CrocittiVallance2011_13-0"><a href="#cite_note-CrocittiVallance2011-13">[12]</a></sup> it is also one of the most <a href="/wiki/Multiculturalism" title="Multiculturalism">multicultural</a> and ethnically diverse nations, due to over a century of mass <a href="/wiki/Immigration_to_Brazil" title="Immigration to Brazil">immigration from around the world</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-14"><a href="#cite_note-14">[13]</a></sup>\n</p><p>Bounded by the Atlantic Ocean on the east, Brazil has a <a href="/wiki/Coastline_of_Brazil" title="Coastline of Brazil">coastline</a> of 7,491 kilometers (4,655&#160;mi).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CIA_Geo_15-0"><a href="#cite_note-CIA_Geo-15">[14]</a></sup> It borders all other South American countries except Ecuador and Chile and covers 47.3% of the continent\'s land area.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-16"><a href="#cite_note-16">[15]</a></sup> Its <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Amazon_River_basin" title="Amazon River basin">Amazon River basin</a> includes a <a href="/wiki/Amazon_rainforest" title="Amazon rainforest">vast tropical forest</a>, home to diverse <a href="/wiki/Wildlife_of_Brazil" title="Wildlife of Brazil">wildlife</a>, a variety of <a href="/wiki/Environment_of_Brazil" title="Environment of Brazil">ecological systems</a>, and extensive natural resources spanning numerous <a href="/wiki/Protected_areas_of_Brazil" title="Protected areas of Brazil">protected habitats</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CIA_Geo_15-1"><a href="#cite_note-CIA_Geo-15">[14]</a></sup> This unique environmental heritage makes Brazil one of 17 <a href="/wiki/Megadiverse_countries" title="Megadiverse countries">megadiverse countries</a>, and is the subject of significant global interest and debate regarding deforestation and environmental protection.\n</p><p>Brazil was inhabited by <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Indigenous_Brazilian" title="Indigenous Brazilian">numerous tribal nations</a> prior to the landing in 1500 of explorer <a href="/wiki/Pedro_%C3%81lvares_Cabral" title="Pedro &#193;lvares Cabral">Pedro &#193;lvares Cabral</a>, who claimed the area for the <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_Empire" title="Portuguese Empire">Portuguese Empire</a>. Brazil remained a <a href="/wiki/Colonial_Brazil" title="Colonial Brazil">Portuguese colony</a> until 1808, when the capital of the empire was <a href="/wiki/Transfer_of_the_Portuguese_Court_to_Brazil" title="Transfer of the Portuguese Court to Brazil">transferred from Lisbon to Rio de Janeiro</a>. In 1815, the colony was elevated to the rank of kingdom upon the formation of the <a href="/wiki/United_Kingdom_of_Portugal,_Brazil_and_the_Algarves" title="United Kingdom of Portugal, Brazil and the Algarves">United Kingdom of Portugal, Brazil and the Algarves</a>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Brazilian_Independence" title="Brazilian Independence">Independence</a> was achieved in 1822 with the creation of the <a href="/wiki/Empire_of_Brazil" title="Empire of Brazil">Empire of Brazil</a>, a unitary state governed under a constitutional monarchy and a parliamentary system. The ratification of the first constitution in 1824 led to the formation of a bicameral legislature, now called the <a href="/wiki/National_Congress_of_Brazil" title="National Congress of Brazil">National Congress</a>. The country <a href="/wiki/Proclamation_of_the_Republic_(Brazil)" title="Proclamation of the Republic (Brazil)">became a presidential republic</a> in 1889 following a military <a href="/wiki/Coup_d%27%C3%A9tat" title="Coup d\'&#233;tat">coup d\'&#233;tat</a>. An authoritarian <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Brazilian_military_dictatorship" title="Brazilian military dictatorship">military junta</a> came to power <a href="/wiki/1964_Brazilian_coup_d%27%C3%A9tat" title="1964 Brazilian coup d\'&#233;tat">in 1964</a> and ruled until 1985, after which civilian governance resumed. Brazil\'s current <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_Brazil" title="Constitution of Brazil">constitution</a>, formulated in 1988, defines it as a <a href="/wiki/Democracy" title="Democracy">democratic</a> <a href="/wiki/Federal_republic" title="Federal republic">federal republic</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Constitui&#231;&#227;o_17-0"><a href="#cite_note-Constitui&#231;&#227;o-17">[16]</a></sup> Due to its rich culture and history, the country ranks <a href="/wiki/List_of_World_Heritage_Sites_in_Brazil" title="List of World Heritage Sites in Brazil">thirteenth in the world</a> by number of <a href="/wiki/UNESCO" title="UNESCO">UNESCO</a> <a href="/wiki/World_Heritage_Site" title="World Heritage Site">World Heritage Sites</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-18"><a href="#cite_note-18">[17]</a></sup>\n</p><p>Brazil is considered an advanced <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Emerging_economy" title="Emerging economy">emerging economy</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-19"><a href="#cite_note-19">[18]</a></sup> It has the eighth largest GDP in the world by both <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_(nominal)" title="List of countries by GDP (nominal)">nominal</a> and <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_(PPP)" title="List of countries by GDP (PPP)">PPP</a> measures.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-IMF,_October_2015_20-0"><a href="#cite_note-IMF,_October_2015-20">[19]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-21"><a href="#cite_note-21">[20]</a></sup> It is one of the world\'s major <a href="/wiki/Breadbasket" title="Breadbasket">breadbaskets</a>, being the largest <a href="/wiki/Coffee_production_in_Brazil" title="Coffee production in Brazil">producer of coffee</a> for the last 150 years.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Neilson102_22-0"><a href="#cite_note-Neilson102-22">[21]</a></sup> It is classified as an upper-middle income economy by the <a href="/wiki/World_Bank" title="World Bank">World Bank</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-wb-upper-middle_23-0"><a href="#cite_note-wb-upper-middle-23">[22]</a></sup> and a <a href="/wiki/Newly_industrialized_country" title="Newly industrialized country">newly industrialized country</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Globalization_24-0"><a href="#cite_note-Globalization-24">[23]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Limits_25-0"><a href="#cite_note-Limits-25">[24]</a></sup> with <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/National_wealth" title="National wealth">the largest share of global wealth</a> in Latin America. Brazil is a <a href="/wiki/Regional_power" title="Regional power">regional power</a> and sometimes considered a <a href="/wiki/Great_power" title="Great power">great</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-SchaeferPoffenbarger2014_26-0"><a href="#cite_note-SchaeferPoffenbarger2014-26">[25]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Gina_27-0"><a href="#cite_note-Gina-27">[26]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Burges2016_28-0"><a href="#cite_note-Burges2016-28">[27]</a></sup> or a <a href="/wiki/Middle_power" title="Middle power">middle power</a> in <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/International_affairs" title="International affairs">international affairs</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Burges2016_28-1"><a href="#cite_note-Burges2016-28">[27]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-29"><a href="#cite_note-29">[28]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-30"><a href="#cite_note-30">[29]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-31"><a href="#cite_note-31">[30]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-32"><a href="#cite_note-32">[31]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Gina_27-1"><a href="#cite_note-Gina-27">[26]</a></sup> On account of its international recognition and influence, the country is subsequently classified as an <a href="/wiki/Emerging_power" title="Emerging power">emerging power</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FRIDE_33-0"><a href="#cite_note-FRIDE-33">[32]</a></sup> and a <a href="/wiki/Potential_superpowers" title="Potential superpowers">potential superpower</a> by several analysts.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Collecott_34-0"><a href="#cite_note-Collecott-34">[33]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-35"><a href="#cite_note-35">[34]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-DominguezKim2013_36-0"><a href="#cite_note-DominguezKim2013-36">[35]</a></sup> Brazil is a founding member of the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations" title="United Nations">United Nations</a>, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/G-20_major_economies" title="G-20 major economies">G20</a>, <a href="/wiki/BRICS" title="BRICS">BRICS</a>, <a href="/wiki/Union_of_South_American_Nations" title="Union of South American Nations">Union of South American Nations</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mercosur" title="Mercosur">Mercosul</a>, <a href="/wiki/Organization_of_American_States" title="Organization of American States">Organization of American States</a>, <a href="/wiki/Organization_of_Ibero-American_States" title="Organization of Ibero-American States">Organization of Ibero-American States</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Community_of_Portuguese_Language_Countries" title="Community of Portuguese Language Countries">Community of Portuguese Language Countries</a>.\n</p>\n<div class="toc" id="toc"><input class="toctogglecheckbox" id="toctogglecheckbox" role="button" style="display:none" type="checkbox"/><div class="toctitle" dir="ltr" lang="en"><h2>Contents</h2><span class="toctogglespan"><label class="toctogglelabel" for="toctogglecheckbox"></label></span></div>\n<ul>\n<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-1"><a href="#Etymology"><span class="tocnumber">1</span> <span class="toclevel-1 tocsection-12"><a href="#Government_and_politics"><span class="tocnumber">4</span> <span class="toctext">Government and politics</span></a>\n<ul>\n<li class="toclevel-2 <span class="toctext">Military</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-15"><a href="#Foreign_policy"><span class="tocnumber">4.3</span> <span class="toctext">Foreign policy</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-16"><a href="#Law_enforcement_and_crime"><span class="tocnumber">4.4</span> <span class="toctext">Law enforcement and crime</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-17"><a href="#Administrative_divisions"><span class="tocnumber">4.5</span> <span class="toctext">Administrative divisions</span></a></li>\n</ul>\n</li>\n<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-18"><a href="#Economy"><span class="tocnumber">5</span> <span class="toctext">Economy</span></a>\n<ul>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-19"><a href="#Energy"><span class="tocnumber">5.1</span> <span class="toctext">Energy</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-20"><a href="#Tourism"><span class="tocnumber">5.2</span> <span class="toctext">Tourism</span></a></li>\n</ul>\n</li>\n<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-21"><a href="#Infrastructure"><span class="tocnumber">6</span> <span class="toctext">Infrastructure</span></a>\n<ul>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-22"><a href="#Science_and_technology"><span class="tocnumber">6.1</span> <span class="toctext">Science and technology</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-23"><a href="#Transport"><span class="tocnumber">6.2</span> <span class="toctext">Transport</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-24"><a href="#Health"><span class="tocnumber">6.3</span> <span class="toctext">Health</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-25"><a href="#Education"><span class="tocnumber">6.4</span> <span class="toctext">Education</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-26"><a href="#Media_and_communication"><span class="tocnumber">6.5</span> <span class="toctext">Media and communication</span></a></li>\n</ul>\n</li>\n<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-27"><a href="#Demographics"><span class="tocnumber">7</span> <span class="toctext">Demographics</span></a>\n<ul>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-28"><a href="#Race_and_ethnicity"><span class="tocnumber">7.1</span> <span class="toctext">Race and ethnicity</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-29"><a href="#Religion"><span class="tocnumber">7.2</span> <span class="toctext">Religion</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-30"><a href="#Urbanization"><span class="tocnumber">7.3</span> <span class="toctext">Urbanization</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-31"><a href="#Language"><span class="tocnumber">7.4</span> <span class="toctext">Language</span></a></li>\n</ul>\n</li>\n<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-32"><a href="#Culture"><span class="tocnumber">8</span> <span class="toctext">Culture</span></a>\n<ul>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-33"><a href="#Architecture"><span class="tocnumber">8.1</span> <span class="toctext">Architecture</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-34"><a href="#Music"><span class="tocnumber">8.2</span> <span class="toctext">Music</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-35"><a href="#Literature"><span class="tocnumber">8.3</span> <span class="toctext">Literature</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-36"><a href="#Cuisine"><span class="tocnumber">8.4</span> <span class="toctext">Cuisine</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-37"><a href="#Cinema"><span class="tocnumber">8.5</span> <span class="toctext">Cinema</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-38"><a href="#Theatre"><span class="tocnumber">8.6</span> <span class="toctext">Theatre</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-39"><a href="#Visual_arts"><span class="tocnumber">8.7</span> <span class="toctext">Visual arts</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-40"><a href="#Sports"><span class="tocnumber">8.8</span> <span class="toctext">Sports</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-41"><a href="#National_holidays"><span class="tocnumber">8.9</span> <span class="toctext">National holidays</span></a></li>\n</ul>\n</li>\n<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-42"><a href="#See_also"><span class="tocnumber">9</span> <span class="toctext">See also</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-43"><a href="#Notes"><span class="tocnumber">10</span> <span class="toctext">Notes</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-44"><a href="#References"><span class="tocnumber">11</span> <span class="toctext">References</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-45"><a href="#Bibliography"><span class="tocnumber">12</span> <span class="toctext">Bibliography</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-46"><a href="#Further_reading"><span class="tocnumber">13</span> <span class="toctext">Further reading</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-47"><a href="#External_links"><span class="tocnumber">14</span> <span class="toctext">External links</span></a></li>\n</ul>\n</div>\n<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Etymology">Etymology</span></h2>\n<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Name_of_Brazil" title="Name of Brazil">Name of Brazil</a></div>\n<p>It is likely that the word "Brazil" comes from the Portuguese word for <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Caesalpinia_echinata" title="Caesalpinia echinata">brazilwood</a>, a tree that once grew plentifully along the Brazilian coast.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Fausto1999_37-0"><a href="#cite_note-Fausto1999-37">[36]</a></sup> In Portuguese, brazilwood is called <i>pau-brasil</i>, with the word <i>brasil</i> commonly given the etymology "red like an ember", formed from <i>brasa</i> ("ember") and the suffix <i>-il</i> (from <i>-iculum</i> or <i>-ilium</i>).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Vincent2003_38-0"><a href="#cite_note-Vincent2003-38">[37]</a></sup> As brazilwood produces a deep red dye, it was highly valued by the European textile industry and was the earliest commercially exploited product from Brazil.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Tucker2007_39-0"><a href="#cite_note-Tucker2007-39">[38]</a></sup> Throughout the 16th century, massive amounts of brazilwood were harvested by <a href="/wiki/Indigenous_peoples_in_Brazil" title="Indigenous peoples in Brazil">indigenous peoples</a> (mostly <a href="/wiki/Tupi_people" title="Tupi people">Tupi</a>) along the Brazilian coast, who sold the timber to European traders (mostly Portuguese, but also French) in return for assorted European consumer goods.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Lee2011_40-0"><a href="#cite_note-Lee2011-40">[39]</a></sup>\n</p><p>The official Portuguese name of the land, in original Portuguese records, was the "Land of the Holy Cross" (<i>Terra da Santa Cruz</i>),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Corporation1880_41-0"><a href="#cite_note-Corporation1880-41">[40]</a></sup> but European sailors and merchants commonly called it simply the "Land of Brazil" (<i>Terra do Brasil</i>) because of the brazilwood trade.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-L&#233;ry1990_42-0"><a href="#cite_note-L&#233;ry1990-42">[41]</a></sup> The popular appellation eclipsed and eventually supplanted the official Portuguese name. Some early sailors called it the "Land of Parrots".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Sokolow2003_43-0"><a href="#cite_note-Sokolow2003-43">[42]</a></sup>\n</p><p>In the <a href="/wiki/Guarani_language" title="Guarani language">Guarani language</a>, an official language of <a href="/wiki/Paraguay" title="Paraguay">Paraguay</a>, Brazil is called "Pindorama". This was the name the indigenous population gave to the region, meaning "land of the palm trees".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Herrera-Sobek2012_44-0"><a href="#cite_note-Herrera-Sobek2012-44">[43]</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="History">History</span></h2>\n<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/History_of_Brazil" title="History of Brazil">History of Brazil</a> and <a href="/wiki/Timeline_of_Brazilian_history" title="Timeline of Brazilian history">Timeline of Brazilian history</a></div>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Pre-Cabraline_era">Pre-Cabraline era</span></h3>\n<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Serra_da_Capivara_-_Several_Paintings_2b.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1512" data-file-width="2295" decoding="async" height="145" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/70/Serra_da_Capivara_-_Several_Paintings_2b.jpg/220px-Serra_da_Capivara_-_Several_Paintings_2b.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/70/Serra_da_Capivara_-_Several_Paintings_2b.jpg/330px-Serra_da_Capivara_-_Several_Paintings_2b.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/70/Serra_da_Capivara_-_Several_Paintings_2b.jpg/440px-Serra_da_Capivara_-_Several_Paintings_2b.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Serra_da_Capivara_-_Several_Paintings_2b.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Cave_painting" title="Cave painting">Cave painting</a> at <a href="/wiki/Serra_da_Capivara_National_Park" title="Serra da Capivara National Park">Serra da Capivara National Park</a>. This area has the largest concentration of prehistoric sites in the <a href="/wiki/Americas" title="Americas">Americas</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-45"><a href="#cite_note-45">[44]</a></sup></div></div></div>\n<p>Some of the earliest human remains found in the <a href="/wiki/Americas" title="Americas">Americas</a>, <a href="/wiki/Luzia_Woman" title="Luzia Woman">Luzia Woman</a>, were found in the area of <a href="/wiki/Pedro_Leopoldo" title="Pedro Leopoldo">Pedro Leopoldo</a>, <a href="/wiki/Minas_Gerais" title="Minas Gerais">Minas Gerais</a> and provide evidence of human habitation going back at least 11,000 years.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-46"><a href="#cite_note-46">[45]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-LevineCrocitti1999_47-0"><a href="#cite_note-LevineCrocitti1999-47">[46]</a></sup> The earliest <a href="/wiki/Pottery" title="Pottery">pottery</a> ever found in the Western Hemisphere was excavated in the <a href="/wiki/Amazon_basin" title="Amazon basin">Amazon basin</a> of Brazil and <a href="/wiki/Radiocarbon_dating" title="Radiocarbon dating">radiocarbon dated</a> to 8,000 years ago (6000 BC). The pottery was found near <a href="/wiki/Santar%C3%A9m,_Par%C3%A1" title="Santar&#233;m, Par&#225;">Santar&#233;m</a> and provides evidence that the tropical forest region supported a complex prehistoric culture.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Eighth_Millennium_Pottery_from_a_Prehistoric_Shell_Midden_in_the_Brazilian_Amazon_48-0"><a href="#cite_note-Eighth_Millennium_Pottery_from_a_Prehistoric_Shell_Midden_in_the_Brazilian_Amazon-48">[47]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Marajoara_culture" title="Marajoara culture">Marajoara culture</a> flourished on <a href="/wiki/Maraj%C3%B3" title="Maraj&#243;">Maraj&#243;</a> in the Amazon delta from 800 CE to 1400 CE, developing sophisticated pottery, <a href="/wiki/Social_stratification" title="Social stratification">social stratification</a>, large populations, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mound_building" title="Mound building">mound building</a>, and complex social formations such as <a href="/wiki/Chiefdom" title="Chiefdom">chiefdoms</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Mann_49-0"><a href="#cite_note-Mann-49">[48]</a></sup>\n</p><p>Around the time of the Portuguese arrival, the territory of current day Brazil had an estimated indigenous population of 7 million people,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-50"><a href="#cite_note-50">[49]</a></sup> mostly semi-nomadic who subsisted on hunting, fishing, gathering, and migrant agriculture. The indigenous population of Brazil comprised several large indigenous ethnic groups (e.g. the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Tup%C3%AD_people" title="Tup&#237; people">Tupis</a>, <a href="/wiki/Guaran%C3%AD_people" title="Guaran&#237; people">Guaranis</a>, <a href="/wiki/G%C3%AA_peoples" title="G&#234; peoples">G&#234;s</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Arawak_peoples" title="Arawak peoples">Arawaks</a>). The Tup&#237; people were subdivided into the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Tupiniquim_people" title="Tupiniquim people">Tupiniquins</a> and <a href="/wiki/Tupinamb%C3%A1_people" title="Tupinamb&#225; people">Tupinamb&#225;s</a>, and there were also many subdivisions of the other groups.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELevine200331_51-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELevine200331-51">[50]</a></sup>\n</p><p>Before the arrival of the Europeans, the boundaries between these groups and their subgroups were marked by wars that arose from differences in culture, language and moral beliefs.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Fausto_52-0"><a href="#cite_note-Fausto-52">[51]</a></sup> These wars also involved large-scale military actions on land and water, with <a href="/wiki/Cannibalism" title="Cannibalism">cannibalistic</a> rituals on <a href="/wiki/Prisoner_of_war" title="Prisoner of war">prisoners of war</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-53"><a href="#cite_note-53">[52]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFausto200078&#8211;80_54-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFausto200078&#8211;80-54">[53]</a></sup> While heredity had some weight, leadership status was more subdued over time, than allocated in succession ceremonies and conventions.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Fausto_52-1"><a href="#cite_note-Fausto-52">[51]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Slavery" title="Slavery">Slavery</a> among the Indians had a different meaning than it had for Europeans, since it originated from a diverse socioeconomic organization, in which asymmetries were translated into <a href="/wiki/Kinship" title="Kinship">kinship</a> relations.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFausto200050_55-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFausto200050-55">[54]</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Portuguese_colonization">Portuguese colonization</span></h3>\n<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Colonial_Brazil" title="Colonial Brazil">Colonial Brazil</a>, <a href="/wiki/War_of_the_Emboabas" title="War of the Emboabas">War of the Emboabas</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Inconfid%C3%AAncia_Mineira" title="Inconfid&#234;ncia Mineira">Inconfid&#234;ncia Mineira</a></div>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Desembarque_de_Pedro_%C3%81lvares_Cabral_em_Porto_Seguro_em_1500_by_Oscar_Pereira_da_Silva_(1865%E2%80%931939).jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2775" data-file-width="4288" decoding="async" height="142" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a6/Desembarque_de_Pedro_%C3%81lvares_Cabral_em_Porto_Seguro_em_1500_by_Oscar_Pereira_da_Silva_%281865%E2%80%931939%29.jpg/220px-Desembarque_de_Pedro_%C3%81lvares_Cabral_em_Porto_Seguro_em_1500_by_Oscar_Pereira_da_Silva_%281865%E2%80%931939%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a6/Desembarque_de_Pedro_%C3%81lvares_Cabral_em_Porto_Seguro_em_1500_by_Oscar_Pereira_da_Silva_%281865%E2%80%931939%29.jpg/330px-Desembarque_de_Pedro_%C3%81lvares_Cabral_em_Porto_Seguro_em_1500_by_Oscar_Pereira_da_Silva_%281865%E2%80%931939%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a6/Desembarque_de_Pedro_%C3%81lvares_Cabral_em_Porto_Seguro_em_1500_by_Oscar_Pereira_da_Silva_%281865%E2%80%931939%29.jpg/440px-Desembarque_de_Pedro_%C3%81lvares_Cabral_em_Porto_Seguro_em_1500_by_Oscar_Pereira_da_Silva_%281865%E2%80%931939%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Desembarque_de_Pedro_%C3%81lvares_Cabral_em_Porto_Seguro_em_1500_by_Oscar_Pereira_da_Silva_(1865%E2%80%931939).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Representation of the landing of <a href="/wiki/Pedro_%C3%81lvares_Cabral" title="Pedro &#193;lvares Cabral">Pedro &#193;lvares Cabral</a> in <a href="/wiki/Porto_Seguro" title="Porto Seguro">Porto Seguro</a>, 1500. Painting of 1922.</div></div></div>\n<p>The land now called Brazil was claimed for the <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_Empire" title="Portuguese Empire">Portuguese Empire</a> on 22 April 1500, with the arrival of the Portuguese fleet commanded by <a href="/wiki/Pedro_%C3%81lvares_Cabral" title="Pedro &#193;lvares Cabral">Pedro &#193;lvares Cabral</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Boxer,_p._98_56-0"><a href="#cite_note-Boxer,_p._98-56">[55]</a></sup> The Portuguese encountered indigenous peoples divided into several tribes, most of whom spoke languages of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Tupi%E2%80%93Guarani" title="Tupi&#8211;Guarani">Tupi&#8211;Guarani</a> family, and fought among themselves.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Boxer,_p.&#160;100_57-0"><a href="#cite_note-Boxer,_p._100-57">[56]</a></sup> Though the first settlement was founded in 1532, <a href="/wiki/Colonization" title="Colonization">colonization</a> effectively began in 1534, when King <a href="/wiki/John_III_of_Portugal" title="John III of Portugal">John&#160;III of Portugal</a> divided the territory into the fifteen private and autonomous <a href="/wiki/Captaincies_of_Brazil" title="Captaincies of Brazil">Captaincy Colonies of Brazil</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-58"><a href="#cite_note-58">[57]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Skidmore,_p.&#160;27_59-0"><a href="#cite_note-Skidmore,_p._27-59">[58]</a></sup>\n</p><p>However, the decentralized and unorganized tendencies of the captaincy colonies proved problematic, and in 1549 the Portuguese king restructured them into the <a href="/wiki/Governorate_General_of_Brazil" title="Governorate General of Brazil">Governorate General of Brazil</a>, a single and centralized Portuguese colony in South America.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Skidmore,_p.&#160;27_59-1"><a href="#cite_note-Skidmore,_p._27-59">[58]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-60"><a href="#cite_note-60">[59]</a></sup> In the first two centuries of colonization, Indigenous and European groups lived in constant war, establishing <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Opportunistic" title="Opportunistic">opportunistic</a> alliances in order to gain advantages against each other.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-61"><a href="#cite_note-61">[60]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-62"><a href="#cite_note-62">[61]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECrocittiVallance2012_63-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECrocittiVallance2012-63">[62]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-64"><a href="#cite_note-64">[63]</a></sup> By the mid-16th century, <a href="/wiki/Sugar#Sugarcane" title="Sugar">cane sugar</a> had become Brazil\'s most important export,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Boxer,_p.&#160;100_57-1"><a href="#cite_note-Boxer,_p._100-57">[56]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-65"><a href="#cite_note-65">[64]</a></sup> and slaves purchased in <a href="/wiki/Sub-Saharan_Africa" title="Sub-Saharan Africa">Sub-Saharan Africa</a>, in the <a href="/wiki/Slavery_in_Africa#Atlantic_slave_trade" title="Slavery in Africa">slave market of Western Africa</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-66"><a href="#cite_note-66">[65]</a></sup> (not only those from Portuguese allies of their colonies in <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_Angola" title="Portuguese Angola">Angola</a> and <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_Mozambique" title="Portuguese Mozambique">Mozambique</a>), had become its largest import,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-67"><a href="#cite_note-67">[66]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-68"><a href="#cite_note-68">[67]</a></sup> to cope with <a href="/wiki/Plantation_economy" title="Plantation economy">plantations</a> of sugarcane, due to increasing international demand for Brazilian sugar.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Boxer,_p.&#160;102_69-0"><a href="#cite_note-Boxer,_p._102-69">[68]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-70"><a href="#cite_note-70">[69]</a></sup>\n</p>\n<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Ant%C3%B4nio_Parreiras_-_Pris%C3%A3o_de_Tiradentes,_1914.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="314" data-file-width="500" decoding="async" height="138" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/65/Ant%C3%B4nio_Parreiras_-_Pris%C3%A3o_de_Tiradentes%2C_1914.jpg/220px-Ant%C3%B4nio_Parreiras_-_Pris%C3%A3o_de_Tiradentes%2C_1914.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/65/Ant%C3%B4nio_Parreiras_-_Pris%C3%A3o_de_Tiradentes%2C_1914.jpg/330px-Ant%C3%B4nio_Parreiras_-_Pris%C3%A3o_de_Tiradentes%2C_1914.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/65/Ant%C3%B4nio_Parreiras_-_Pris%C3%A3o_de_Tiradentes%2C_1914.jpg/440px-Ant%C3%B4nio_Parreiras_-_Pris%C3%A3o_de_Tiradentes%2C_1914.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Ant%C3%B4nio_Parreiras_-_Pris%C3%A3o_de_Tiradentes,_1914.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Painting showing the arrest of <a href="/wiki/Tiradentes" title="Tiradentes">Tiradentes</a>; he was sentenced to death for his involvement in the best known <a href="/wiki/Inconfid%C3%AAncia_Mineira" title="Inconfid&#234;ncia Mineira">movement for independence</a> in Colonial Brazil. Painting of 1914.</div></div></div>\n<p>By the end of the 17th century, sugarcane exports began to decline,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-71"><a href="#cite_note-71">[70]</a></sup> and the discovery of gold by <a href="/wiki/Bandeirantes" title="Bandeirantes">bandeirantes</a> in the 1690s would become the new backbone of the colony\'s economy, fostering a <a href="/wiki/Brazilian_Gold_Rush" title="Brazilian Gold Rush">Brazilian Gold Rush</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-72"><a href="#cite_note-72">[71]</a></sup> which attracted thousands of new <a href="/wiki/Settler_colonialism" title="Settler colonialism">settlers</a> to Brazil from Portugal and all Portuguese colonies around the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-73"><a href="#cite_note-73">[72]</a></sup> This increased level of immigration in turn caused <a href="/wiki/War_of_the_Emboabas" title="War of the Emboabas">some conflicts</a> between newcomers and old settlers.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-74"><a href="#cite_note-74">[73]</a></sup>\n</p><p>Portuguese expeditions known as <a href="/wiki/Bandeirantes" title="Bandeirantes">Bandeiras</a> gradually advanced the Portugal colonial <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Tordesillas" title="Treaty of Tordesillas">original frontiers</a> in South America to approximately the current Brazilian borders.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-75"><a href="#cite_note-75">[74]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-76"><a href="#cite_note-76">[75]</a></sup> In this era other European powers tried to colonize parts of Brazil, in incursions that the Portuguese had to fight, notably the French <a href="/wiki/France_Antarctique" title="France Antarctique">in Rio during the 1560s</a>, <a href="/wiki/Equinoctial_France" title="Equinoctial France">in Maranh&#227;o during the 1610s</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Dutch_Brazil" title="Dutch Brazil">Dutch in Bahia and Pernambuco</a>, during the <a href="/wiki/Dutch%E2%80%93Portuguese_War" title="Dutch&#8211;Portuguese War">Dutch&#8211;Portuguese War</a>, after the end of <a href="/wiki/Iberian_Union" title="Iberian Union">Iberian Union</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-77"><a href="#cite_note-77">[76]</a></sup>\n</p><p>The Portuguese colonial administration in Brazil had two objectives that would ensure colonial order and the <a href="/wiki/Monopoly" title="Monopoly">monopoly</a> of Portugal\'s wealthiest and largest colony: to keep under control and eradicate all forms of <a href="/wiki/Slave_rebellion" title="Slave rebellion">slave rebellion</a> and resistance, such as the <a href="/wiki/Palmares_(quilombo)" title="Palmares (quilombo)">Quilombo of Palmares</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-78"><a href="#cite_note-78">[77]</a></sup> and to repress all movements for <a href="/wiki/Autonomous_administrative_division" title="Autonomous administrative division">autonomy</a> or <a href="/wiki/Independence" title="Independence">independence</a>, such as the <a href="/wiki/Inconfid%C3%AAncia_Mineira" title="Inconfid&#234;ncia Mineira">Minas Conspiracy</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-79"><a href="#cite_note-79">[78]</a></sup>\n</p>\n<div style="clear:both;"></div>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="United_Kingdom_with_Portugal">United Kingdom with Portugal</span></h3>\n<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/United_Kingdom_of_Portugal,_Brazil_and_the_Algarves" title="United Kingdom of Portugal, Brazil and the Algarves">United Kingdom of Portugal, Brazil and the Algarves</a></div>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:262px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Aclama%C3%A7%C3%A3o_do_rei_Dom_Jo%C3%A3o_VI_no_Rio_de_Janeiro.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="836" data-file-width="1408" decoding="async" height="154" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4b/Aclama%C3%A7%C3%A3o_do_rei_Dom_Jo%C3%A3o_VI_no_Rio_de_Janeiro.jpg/260px-Aclama%C3%A7%C3%A3o_do_rei_Dom_Jo%C3%A3o_VI_no_Rio_de_Janeiro.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4b/Aclama%C3%A7%C3%A3o_do_rei_Dom_Jo%C3%A3o_VI_no_Rio_de_Janeiro.jpg/390px-Aclama%C3%A7%C3%A3o_do_rei_Dom_Jo%C3%A3o_VI_no_Rio_de_Janeiro.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4b/Aclama%C3%A7%C3%A3o_do_rei_Dom_Jo%C3%A3o_VI_no_Rio_de_Janeiro.jpg/520px-Aclama%C3%A7%C3%A3o_do_rei_Dom_Jo%C3%A3o_VI_no_Rio_de_Janeiro.jpg 2x" width="260"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Aclama%C3%A7%C3%A3o_do_rei_Dom_Jo%C3%A3o_VI_no_Rio_de_Janeiro.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The Acclamation of <a href="/wiki/John_VI_of_Portugal" title="John VI of Portugal">King Jo&#227;o VI</a> of the <a href="/wiki/United_Kingdom_of_Portugal,_Brazil_and_the_Algarves" title="United Kingdom of Portugal, Brazil and the Algarves">United Kingdom of Portugal, Brazil and the Algarves</a> in <a href="/wiki/Rio_de_Janeiro" title="Rio de Janeiro">Rio de Janeiro</a>, 6 February 1818</div></div></div>\n<p>In late 1807, Spanish and Napoleonic forces threatened the security of <a href="/wiki/Continental_Portugal" title="Continental Portugal">continental Portugal</a>, causing <a href="/wiki/John_VI_of_Portugal" title="John VI of Portugal">Prince Regent Jo&#227;o</a>, in the name of <a href="/wiki/Maria_I_of_Portugal" title="Maria I of Portugal">Queen Maria I</a>, to move the royal court from <a href="/wiki/Lisbon" title="Lisbon">Lisbon</a> to <a href="/wiki/Transfer_of_the_Portuguese_Court_to_Brazil" title="Transfer of the Portuguese Court to Brazil">Rio de Janeiro</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Boxer,_p.&#160;213_80-0"><a href="#cite_note-Boxer,_p._213-80">[79]</a></sup> There they established some of Brazil\'s first financial institutions, such as its local <a href="/wiki/Stock_exchange" title="Stock exchange">stock exchanges</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-81"><a href="#cite_note-81">[80]</a></sup> and its <a href="/wiki/Banco_do_Brasil" title="Banco do Brasil">National Bank</a>, additionally ending the Portuguese <a href="/wiki/Monopoly" title="Monopoly">monopoly</a> on Brazilian trade and opening Brazil to other nations. In 1809, in retaliation for being forced into exile, the Prince Regent ordered the <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_conquest_of_French_Guiana" title="Portuguese conquest of French Guiana">Portuguese conquest of French Guiana</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-82"><a href="#cite_note-82">[81]</a></sup>\n</p><p>With the end of the <a href="/wiki/Peninsular_War" title="Peninsular War">Peninsular War</a> in 1814, the courts of Europe demanded that Queen Maria I and Prince Regent Jo&#227;o return to Portugal, deeming it unfit for the head of an ancient European monarchy to reside in a <a href="/wiki/Colony" title="Colony">colony</a>. In 1815, to justify continuing to live in Brazil, where the royal court had thrived for the prior six years, the Crown established the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/United_Kingdom_of_Portugal,_Brazil,_and_the_Algarves" title="United Kingdom of Portugal, Brazil, and the Algarves">United Kingdom of Portugal, Brazil, and the Algarves</a>, thus creating a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Pluricontinental" title="Pluricontinental">pluricontinental</a> transatlantic monarchic state.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Mosher2008_83-0"><a href="#cite_note-Mosher2008-83">[82]</a></sup> However, such a ploy didn\'t last long, since the leadership in Portugal, resentful of the new status of its larger colony, continued to require the return of court to Lisbon (as postulated by the <a href="/wiki/Liberal_Revolution_of_1820" title="Liberal Revolution of 1820">Liberal Revolution of 1820</a>), and also groups of Brazilians, impatient for practical and real changes, still demanded independence and a republic, as demonstrated by the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Pernambucan_Revolt" title="Pernambucan Revolt">1817 Pernambucan Revolt</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Mosher2008_83-1"><a href="#cite_note-Mosher2008-83">[82]</a></sup>\nIn 1821, as a demand of revolutionaries who had taken the city of <a href="/wiki/Porto" title="Porto">Porto</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Adelman2006_84-0"><a href="#cite_note-Adelman2006-84">[83]</a></sup> D. Jo&#227;o VI was unable to hold out any longer, and departed for Lisbon. There he swore an oath to the new constitution, leaving his son, <a href="/wiki/Pedro_I_of_Brazil" title="Pedro I of Brazil">Prince Pedro de Alc&#226;ntara</a>, as Regent of the <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Brazil" title="Kingdom of Brazil">Kingdom of Brazil</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-85"><a href="#cite_note-85">[84]</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Independent_empire">Independent empire</span></h3>\n<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Independence_of_Brazil" title="Independence of Brazil">Independence of Brazil</a> and <a href="/wiki/Empire_of_Brazil" title="Empire of Brazil">Empire of Brazil</a></div>\n<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:262px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Independence_of_Brazil_1888.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1268" data-file-width="2271" decoding="async" height="145" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/40/Independence_of_Brazil_1888.jpg/260px-Independence_of_Brazil_1888.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/40/Independence_of_Brazil_1888.jpg/390px-Independence_of_Brazil_1888.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/40/Independence_of_Brazil_1888.jpg/520px-Independence_of_Brazil_1888.jpg 2x" width="260"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Independence_of_Brazil_1888.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Declaration of the <a href="/wiki/War_of_Independence_of_Brazil" title="War of Independence of Brazil">Brazilian independence</a> by Prince Pedro (later Emperor <a href="/wiki/Pedro_I_of_Brazil" title="Pedro I of Brazil">Pedro&#160;I</a>) on 7 September 1822.</div></div></div>\n<p>Tensions between Portuguese and Brazilians increased, and the <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_Cortes" title="Portuguese Cortes">Portuguese Cortes</a>, guided by the new political regime imposed by the 1820 Liberal Revolution, tried to re-establish Brazil as a colony.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-86"><a href="#cite_note-86">[85]</a></sup> The Brazilians refused to yield, and Prince Pedro decided to stand with them, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Brazilian_Declaration_of_Independence" title="Brazilian Declaration of Independence">declaring the country\'s independence from Portugal</a> on 7 September 1822.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-87"><a href="#cite_note-87">[86]</a></sup> A month later, Prince Pedro was declared the first <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Emperor_of_Brazil" title="Emperor of Brazil">Emperor of Brazil</a>, with the royal title of Dom <a href="/wiki/Pedro_I_of_Brazil" title="Pedro I of Brazil">Pedro&#160;I</a>, resulting in the foundation of the <a href="/wiki/Empire_of_Brazil" title="Empire of Brazil">Empire of Brazil</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-88"><a href="#cite_note-88">[87]</a></sup>\n</p><p>The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Brazilian_War_of_Independence" title="Brazilian War of Independence">Brazilian War of Independence</a>, which had already begun along this process, spread through northern, northeastern regions and in <a href="/wiki/Cisplatina" title="Cisplatina">Cisplatina</a> province.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-89"><a href="#cite_note-89">[88]</a></sup> The last Portuguese soldiers surrendered on 8 March 1824;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-90"><a href="#cite_note-90">[89]</a></sup> Portugal officially recognized Brazil on 29 August 1825.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-91"><a href="#cite_note-91">[90]</a></sup>\n</p><p>On 7 April 1831, worn down by years of administrative turmoil and political dissent with both liberal and conservative sides of politics, including an attempt of <a href="/wiki/Confederation_of_the_Equator" title="Confederation of the Equator">republican secession</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFausto199982&#8211;83_92-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFausto199982&#8211;83-92">[91]</a></sup> and unreconciled to the way that absolutists in Portugal had given in the succession of King John VI, Pedro&#160;I went to Portugal to <a href="/wiki/Liberal_Wars" title="Liberal Wars">reclaim his daughter\'s crown</a>, abdicating the Brazilian throne in favor of his five-year-old son and heir (who thus became the Empire\'s second monarch, with the royal title of Dom <a href="/wiki/Pedro_II_of_Brazil" title="Pedro II of Brazil">Pedro&#160;II</a>).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-93"><a href="#cite_note-93">[92]</a></sup>\n</p>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Pedro_Am%C3%A9rico_-_D._Pedro_II_na_abertura_da_Assembl%C3%A9ia_Geral.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1281" data-file-width="876" decoding="async" height="249" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/55/Pedro_Am%C3%A9rico_-_D._Pedro_II_na_abertura_da_Assembl%C3%A9ia_Geral.jpg/170px-Pedro_Am%C3%A9rico_-_D._Pedro_II_na_abertura_da_Assembl%C3%A9ia_Geral.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/55/Pedro_Am%C3%A9rico_-_D._Pedro_II_na_abertura_da_Assembl%C3%A9ia_Geral.jpg/255px-Pedro_Am%C3%A9rico_-_D._Pedro_II_na_abertura_da_Assembl%C3%A9ia_Geral.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/55/Pedro_Am%C3%A9rico_-_D._Pedro_II_na_abertura_da_Assembl%C3%A9ia_Geral.jpg/340px-Pedro_Am%C3%A9rico_-_D._Pedro_II_na_abertura_da_Assembl%C3%A9ia_Geral.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Pedro_Am%C3%A9rico_-_D._Pedro_II_na_abertura_da_Assembl%C3%A9ia_Geral.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Pedro_II_of_Brazil" title="Pedro II of Brazil">Pedro II</a>, <a href="/wiki/List_of_monarchs_of_Brazil" title="List of monarchs of Brazil">Emperor of Brazil</a> between 1831 and 1889.</div></div></div>\n<p>As the new Emperor could not exert his constitutional powers until he became of age, a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Regency_(government)" title="Regency (government)">regency</a> was set up by the National Assembly.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-94"><a href="#cite_note-94">[93]</a></sup> In the absence of a charismatic figure who could represent a moderate face of power, during this period a series of localized rebellions took place, such as the <a href="/wiki/Cabanagem" title="Cabanagem">Cabanagem</a> in <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Gr%C3%A3o-Par%C3%A1_Province" title="Gr&#227;o-Par&#225; Province">Gr&#227;o-Par&#225; Province</a>, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mal%C3%AA_Revolt" title="Mal&#234; Revolt">Mal&#234; Revolt</a> in <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Salvador_da_Bahia" title="Salvador da Bahia">Salvador da Bahia</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Balaiada" title="Balaiada">Balaiada</a> (<a href="/wiki/Maranh%C3%A3o" title="Maranh&#227;o">Maranh&#227;o</a>), the <a href="/wiki/Sabinada" title="Sabinada">Sabinada</a> (<a href="/wiki/Bahia" title="Bahia">Bahia</a>), and the <a href="/wiki/Ragamuffin_War" title="Ragamuffin War">Ragamuffin War</a> beginning in <a href="/wiki/Rio_Grande_do_Sul" title="Rio Grande do Sul">Rio Grande do Sul</a> and supported by <a href="/wiki/Giuseppe_Garibaldi" title="Giuseppe Garibaldi">Giuseppe Garibaldi</a>. These emerged from the dissatisfaction of the provinces with the central power, coupled with old and latent social tensions peculiar to a vast, slaveholding and newly independent <a href="/wiki/Nation_state" title="Nation state">nation state</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFausto1999Chapter_2,_2.1_to_2.3_95-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFausto1999Chapter_2,_2.1_to_2.3-95">[94]</a></sup> This period of internal political and social upheaval, which included the <a href="/wiki/Praieira_revolt" title="Praieira revolt">Praieira revolt</a> in <a href="/wiki/Pernambuco" title="Pernambuco">Pernambuco</a>, was overcome only at the end of the 1840s, years after the end of the regency, which occurred with the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Dom_Pedro_II#Early_coronation" title="Dom Pedro II">premature coronation of Pedro II</a> in 1841.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFausto1999_96-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFausto1999-96">[95]</a></sup>\n</p><p>During the last phase of the monarchy, internal political debate centered on the issue of slavery. The <a href="/wiki/Atlantic_slave_trade" title="Atlantic slave trade">Atlantic slave trade</a> was abandoned in 1850,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-97"><a href="#cite_note-97">[96]</a></sup> as a result of the <a href="/wiki/United_Kingdom_of_Great_Britain_and_Ireland" title="United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland">British</a> <a href="/wiki/Aberdeen_Act" title="Aberdeen Act">Aberdeen Act</a>, but only in <a href="/wiki/Lei_%C3%81urea" title="Lei &#193;urea">May 1888</a> after a long process of internal mobilization and debate for an ethical and legal dismantling of <a href="/wiki/Slavery_in_Brazil" title="Slavery in Brazil">slavery in the country</a>, was the institution formally abolished.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-98"><a href="#cite_note-98">[97]</a></sup>\n</p><p>The foreign affairs in the monarchy were basically related to issues with the countries of the <a href="/wiki/Southern_Cone" title="Southern Cone">Southern Cone</a> with which Brazil had borders. Long after the <a href="/wiki/Cisplatine_War" title="Cisplatine War">Cisplatine War</a> that resulted in independence for <a href="/wiki/Uruguay" title="Uruguay">Uruguay</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-99"><a href="#cite_note-99">[98]</a></sup> Brazil won three international wars during the 58-year reign of Pedro&#160;II. These were the <a href="/wiki/Platine_War" title="Platine War">Platine War</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Uruguayan_War" title="Uruguayan War">Uruguayan War</a> and the devastating <a href="/wiki/Paraguayan_War" title="Paraguayan War">Paraguayan War</a>, the largest <a href="/wiki/War_effort" title="War effort">war effort</a> in Brazilian history.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-100"><a href="#cite_note-100">[99]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id=\'cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFausto1999Chapter_2,_p._83,_and_2.6_"The_Paraguayan_War"_101-0\'><a href=\'#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFausto1999Chapter_2,_p._83,_and_2.6_"The_Paraguayan_War"-101\'>[100]</a></sup>\n</p><p>Although there was no desire among the majority of Brazilians to change the country\'s <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Form_of_government" title="Form of government">form of government</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEErmakoff2006189_102-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEErmakoff2006189-102">[101]</a></sup> on 15 November 1889, in attrition with the majority of <a href="/wiki/Imperial_Brazilian_Army" title="Imperial Brazilian Army">Army</a> officers, as well as with rural and financial elites (for different reasons), the monarchy was overthrown by a military coup.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-103"><a href="#cite_note-103">[102]</a></sup> 15 November is now <a href="/wiki/Republic_Day" title="Republic Day">Republic Day</a>, a national holiday.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-104"><a href="#cite_note-104">[103]</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Early_republic">Early republic</span></h3>\n<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/First_Brazilian_Republic" title="First Brazilian Republic">First Brazilian Republic</a>, <a href="/wiki/Vargas_Era#Estado_Novo" title="Vargas Era">Vargas Era &#167;&#160;Estado Novo</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Second_Brazilian_Republic" title="Second Brazilian Republic">Second Brazilian Republic</a></div>\n<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:242px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Proclama%C3%A7%C3%A3o_da_Rep%C3%BAblica_by_Benedito_Calixto_1893.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3574" data-file-width="5799" decoding="async" height="148" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b7/Proclama%C3%A7%C3%A3o_da_Rep%C3%BAblica_by_Benedito_Calixto_1893.jpg/240px-Proclama%C3%A7%C3%A3o_da_Rep%C3%BAblica_by_Benedito_Calixto_1893.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b7/Proclama%C3%A7%C3%A3o_da_Rep%C3%BAblica_by_Benedito_Calixto_1893.jpg/360px-Proclama%C3%A7%C3%A3o_da_Rep%C3%BAblica_by_Benedito_Calixto_1893.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b7/Proclama%C3%A7%C3%A3o_da_Rep%C3%BAblica_by_Benedito_Calixto_1893.jpg/480px-Proclama%C3%A7%C3%A3o_da_Rep%C3%BAblica_by_Benedito_Calixto_1893.jpg 2x" width="240"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Proclama%C3%A7%C3%A3o_da_Rep%C3%BAblica_by_Benedito_Calixto_1893.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><i><a href="/wiki/Proclamation_of_the_Republic_(Brazil)" title="Proclamation of the Republic (Brazil)">Proclamation of the Republic</a></i>, 1893, oil on canvas by <a href="/wiki/Benedito_Calixto" title="Benedito Calixto">Benedito Calixto</a>.</div></div></div>\n<p>The early republican government was nothing more than a military dictatorship, with army dominating affairs both at Rio de Janeiro and in the states. Freedom of the press disappeared and elections were controlled by those in power.<sup class="reference" id=\'cite_ref-FOOTNOTESmallman2002end_of_Chapter_1,_from_p._18_"Military_rule"_105-0\'><a href=\'#cite_note-FOOTNOTESmallman2002end_of_Chapter_1,_from_p._18_"Military_rule"-105\'>[104]</a></sup> Only in 1894, following the unfoldings of two severe crises, <a href="/wiki/Encilhamento" title="Encilhamento">an economic</a> along with <a href="/wiki/Revolta_da_Armada" title="Revolta da Armada">a military one</a>, the civilians rose to power staying there until October 1930.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESmallman200221&#8211;26_106-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESmallman200221&#8211;26-106">[105]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-107"><a href="#cite_note-107">[106]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-108"><a href="#cite_note-108">[107]</a></sup>\n</p><p>If in relation to its foreign policy, the country in this first republican period maintained a relative balance characterized by a success in resolving border disputes with neighboring countries,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-109"><a href="#cite_note-109">[108]</a></sup> only broken by the <a href="/wiki/Acre_War" title="Acre War">Acre War</a> (1899&#8211;1902) and <a href="/wiki/Brazil_during_World_War_I" title="Brazil during World War I">its involvement</a> in <a href="/wiki/World_War_I" title="World War I">World War I</a> (1914&#8211;1918),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-110"><a href="#cite_note-110">[109]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-111"><a href="#cite_note-111">[110]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-112"><a href="#cite_note-112">[111]</a></sup> followed by a failed attempt to exert a prominent role in the <a href="/wiki/League_of_Nations" title="League of Nations">League of Nations</a>;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-113"><a href="#cite_note-113">[112]</a></sup> <i>Internally</i>, from the <i>crisis of Encilhamento</i><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-114"><a href="#cite_note-114">[113]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-115"><a href="#cite_note-115">[114]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-116"><a href="#cite_note-116">[115]</a></sup> and the Armada Revolts,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-117"><a href="#cite_note-117">[116]</a></sup> a prolonged cycle of financial, political and social instability began until the 1920s, keeping the country besieged by various rebellions, both civilian<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-118"><a href="#cite_note-118">[117]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-119"><a href="#cite_note-119">[118]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-120"><a href="#cite_note-120">[119]</a></sup> and military.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-121"><a href="#cite_note-121">[120]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-122"><a href="#cite_note-122">[121]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-123"><a href="#cite_note-123">[122]</a></sup>\n</p>\n<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r856303569">@media all and (max-width:720px){.mw-parser-output .tmulti>.thumbinner{width:100%!important;max-width:none!important}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .tsingle{float:none!important;max-width:none!important;width:100%!important;text-align:center}}</style><div class="thumb tmulti tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:224px;max-width:224px"><div class="tsingle" style="margin:1px;width:222px;max-width:222px"><div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:50%C2%BA_Anivers%C3%A1rio_da_Rep%C3%BAblica_Brasileira.png"><img alt="" data-file-height="1950" data-file-width="2257" decoding="async" height="190" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/68/50%C2%BA_Anivers%C3%A1rio_da_Rep%C3%BAblica_Brasileira.png/220px-50%C2%BA_Anivers%C3%A1rio_da_Rep%C3%BAblica_Brasileira.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/68/50%C2%BA_Anivers%C3%A1rio_da_Rep%C3%BAblica_Brasileira.png/330px-50%C2%BA_Anivers%C3%A1rio_da_Rep%C3%BAblica_Brasileira.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/68/50%C2%BA_Anivers%C3%A1rio_da_Rep%C3%BAblica_Brasileira.png/440px-50%C2%BA_Anivers%C3%A1rio_da_Rep%C3%BAblica_Brasileira.png 2x" width="220"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left">In half of the first 100 years of republic, the <a href="/wiki/Brazilian_Army" title="Brazilian Army">Army</a> exercised power directly or through figures like <a href="/wiki/Get%C3%BAlio_Vargas" title="Get&#250;lio Vargas">Get&#250;lio Vargas</a> (center).</div></div><div class="tsingle" style="margin:1px;width:222px;max-width:222px"><div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Massarosaw.jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="915" data-file-width="1261" decoding="async" height="160" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/43/Massarosaw.jpg/220px-Massarosaw.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/43/Massarosaw.jpg/330px-Massarosaw.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/43/Massarosaw.jpg/440px-Massarosaw.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left">Soldiers of the <a href="/wiki/Brazilian_Expeditionary_Force" title="Brazilian Expeditionary Force">Brazilian Expeditionary Force</a> greet <a href="/wiki/Italy" title="Italy">Italian</a> civilians in <a href="/wiki/Massarosa" title="Massarosa">Massarosa</a>, during <a href="/wiki/World_War_II" title="World War II">World War II</a>.</div></div></div></div>\n<p>Little by little, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Rebellions_and_revolutions_in_Brazil#1st_Republican_period_(1889-1930)" title="Rebellions and revolutions in Brazil">a cycle of general instability</a> sparked by these crises undermined the regime to such an extent, that in the wake of the murder of his running mate, the defeated opposition presidential candidate <a href="/wiki/Get%C3%BAlio_Vargas" title="Get&#250;lio Vargas">Get&#250;lio Vargas</a> supported by most of the military, successfully led the <a href="/wiki/Brazilian_Revolution_of_1930" title="Brazilian Revolution of 1930">October 1930 Coup</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-124"><a href="#cite_note-124">[123]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-125"><a href="#cite_note-125">[124]</a></sup> Vargas and the military were supposed to assume power temporarily, but instead closed the Congress, extinguished the Constitution, ruled with emergency powers and replaced the states\' governors with their own supporters.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-126"><a href="#cite_note-126">[125]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-127"><a href="#cite_note-127">[126]</a></sup>\n</p><p>In the 1930s, three failed attempts to remove Vargas and his supporters from power occurred. The first was the <a href="/wiki/Constitutionalist_Revolution" title="Constitutionalist Revolution">Constitutionalist Revolution</a> in 1932, led by the <a href="/wiki/S%C3%A3o_Paulo_(state)" title="S&#227;o Paulo (state)">Paulista</a> oligarchy. The second was a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Brazilian_uprising_of_1935" title="Brazilian uprising of 1935">Communist uprising</a> in November 1935, and the last one a <i>putsch</i> attempt by <a href="/wiki/Brazilian_Integralism" title="Brazilian Integralism">local fascists</a> in May 1938.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-128"><a href="#cite_note-128">[127]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-129"><a href="#cite_note-129">[128]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-130"><a href="#cite_note-130">[129]</a></sup> The 1935 uprising created a security crisis in which the Congress transferred more power to the executive. The 1937 <i>coup d\'&#233;tat</i> resulted in the cancellation of the 1938 election, formalized Vargas as dictator, beginning the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Estado_Novo_(Brazil)" title="Estado Novo (Brazil)">Estado Novo</a> era, which was noted for government brutality and censorship of the press.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-131"><a href="#cite_note-131">[130]</a></sup>\n</p><p>Foreign policy during Vargas years was marked by the antecedents and <a href="/wiki/World_War_II" title="World War II">World War II</a>. Brazil remained neutral until August 1942, when the country entered on the <a href="/wiki/Allies_of_World_War_II" title="Allies of World War II">allied side</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-132"><a href="#cite_note-132">[131]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-133"><a href="#cite_note-133">[132]</a></sup> after suffering <a href="/wiki/Submarine_warfare#Atlantic_ocean" title="Submarine warfare">retaliation</a> by <a href="/wiki/Nazi_Germany" title="Nazi Germany">Nazi Germany</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Italy_(1861%E2%80%931946)#Fascism_(1922&#8211;1943)" title="Kingdom of Italy (1861&#8211;1946)">Fascist Italy</a>, in a strategic dispute over the South Atlantic.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-134"><a href="#cite_note-134">[133]</a></sup> In addition to <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_the_Atlantic#South_Atlantic_(May_1942_-_September_1943)" title="Battle of the Atlantic">its participation in the battle of the Atlantic</a>, Brazil also sent an <a href="/wiki/Brazilian_Expeditionary_Force" title="Brazilian Expeditionary Force">expeditionary force</a> to fight in the <a href="/wiki/Italian_Campaign_(World_War_II)" title="Italian Campaign (World War II)">Italian campaign</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-135"><a href="#cite_note-135">[134]</a></sup>\n</p><p>With the Allied victory in 1945 and the end of the Nazi-fascist regimes in Europe, Vargas\'s position became unsustainable and he was swiftly overthrown in another military coup, with democracy "reinstated" by the same army that had ended it 15 years earlier.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-136"><a href="#cite_note-136">[135]</a></sup> Vargas committed suicide in August 1954 amid a political crisis, after having returned to power by election in 1950.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-137"><a href="#cite_note-137">[136]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-138"><a href="#cite_note-138">[137]</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Contemporary_era">Contemporary era</span></h3>\n<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Military_dictatorship_in_Brazil" title="Military dictatorship in Brazil">Military dictatorship in Brazil</a> and <a href="/wiki/History_of_Brazil_since_1985" title="History of Brazil since 1985">History of Brazil since 1985</a></div>\n<p>Several brief interim governments followed Vargas\'s suicide.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-139"><a href="#cite_note-139">[138]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Juscelino_Kubitschek" title="Juscelino Kubitschek">Juscelino Kubitschek</a> became president in 1956 and assumed a conciliatory posture towards the <a href="/wiki/Opposition_(politics)" title="Opposition (politics)">political opposition</a> that allowed him to govern without major crises.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-140"><a href="#cite_note-140">[139]</a></sup> The economy and industrial sector grew remarkably,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-141"><a href="#cite_note-141">[140]</a></sup> but his greatest achievement was the construction of the new capital city of <a href="/wiki/Bras%C3%ADlia" title="Bras&#237;lia">Bras&#237;lia</a>, inaugurated in 1960.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-142"><a href="#cite_note-142">[141]</a></sup>\n</p>\n<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r856303569" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="thumb tmulti tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:224px;max-width:224px"><div class="tsingle" style="margin:1px;width:222px;max-width:222px"><div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:0741_NOV_B_05_Esplanada_dos_Ministerios_Brasilia_DF_03_09_1959.jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="855" data-file-width="1276" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/30/0741_NOV_B_05_Esplanada_dos_Ministerios_Brasilia_DF_03_09_1959.jpg/220px-0741_NOV_B_05_Esplanada_dos_Ministerios_Brasilia_DF_03_09_1959.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/30/0741_NOV_B_05_Esplanada_dos_Ministerios_Brasilia_DF_03_09_1959.jpg/330px-0741_NOV_B_05_Esplanada_dos_Ministerios_Brasilia_DF_03_09_1959.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/30/0741_NOV_B_05_Esplanada_dos_Ministerios_Brasilia_DF_03_09_1959.jpg/440px-0741_NOV_B_05_Esplanada_dos_Ministerios_Brasilia_DF_03_09_1959.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left">Construction of <a href="/wiki/Bras%C3%ADlia" title="Bras&#237;lia">Bras&#237;lia</a>, the new capital, in 1959.</div></div><div class="tsingle" style="margin:1px;width:222px;max-width:222px"><div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Tanques_ocupam_a_Avenida_Presidente_Vargas,_1968-04-04.jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="499" data-file-width="646" decoding="async" height="170" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b2/Tanques_ocupam_a_Avenida_Presidente_Vargas%2C_1968-04-04.jpg/220px-Tanques_ocupam_a_Avenida_Presidente_Vargas%2C_1968-04-04.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b2/Tanques_ocupam_a_Avenida_Presidente_Vargas%2C_1968-04-04.jpg/330px-Tanques_ocupam_a_Avenida_Presidente_Vargas%2C_1968-04-04.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b2/Tanques_ocupam_a_Avenida_Presidente_Vargas%2C_1968-04-04.jpg/440px-Tanques_ocupam_a_Avenida_Presidente_Vargas%2C_1968-04-04.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left"><a href="/wiki/M41_Walker_Bulldog" title="M41 Walker Bulldog">M41s</a> along the <a href="/wiki/Avenida_Presidente_Vargas" title="Avenida Presidente Vargas">Avenida Presidente Vargas</a> during the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Brazilian_military_government" title="Brazilian military government">military government</a>.</div></div></div></div>\n<p>Kubitschek\'s successor, <a href="/wiki/J%C3%A2nio_Quadros" title="J&#226;nio Quadros">J&#226;nio Quadros</a>, resigned in 1961 less than a year after taking office.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-143"><a href="#cite_note-143">[142]</a></sup> His vice-president, <a href="/wiki/Jo%C3%A3o_Goulart" title="Jo&#227;o Goulart">Jo&#227;o Goulart</a>, assumed the presidency, but aroused strong political opposition<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-144"><a href="#cite_note-144">[143]</a></sup> and was <a href="/wiki/1964_Brazilian_coup_d%27%C3%A9tat" title="1964 Brazilian coup d\'&#233;tat">deposed in April 1964</a> by a coup that resulted in a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Brazilian_military_government" title="Brazilian military government">military regime</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-145"><a href="#cite_note-145">[144]</a></sup>\n</p><p>The new regime was intended to be transitory<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-146"><a href="#cite_note-146">[145]</a></sup> but gradually closed in on itself and became a full dictatorship with the promulgation of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/AI-5" title="AI-5">Fifth Institutional Act</a> in 1968.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Gaspari_p.35_147-0"><a href="#cite_note-Gaspari_p.35-147">[146]</a></sup> Oppression was not limited to those who resorted to guerrilla tactics to fight the regime, but also reached institutional opponents, artists, journalists and other members of civil society,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECrocittiVallance2012[httpsbooksgooglecombooksidVhkvhllLooUCpgPA395_395],_last_paragraph_148-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECrocittiVallance2012[httpsbooksgooglecombooksidVhkvhllLooUCpgPA395_395],_last_paragraph-148">[147]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-149"><a href="#cite_note-149">[148]</a></sup> inside and outside the country through the infamous "<a href="/wiki/Operation_Condor" title="Operation Condor">Operation Condor</a>".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-150"><a href="#cite_note-150">[149]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECrocittiVallance2012[httpsbooksgooglecombooksidVhkvhllLooUCpgPA396_396]_151-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECrocittiVallance2012[httpsbooksgooglecombooksidVhkvhllLooUCpgPA396_396]-151">[150]</a></sup> Despite its brutality, like other <a href="/wiki/Authoritarianism" title="Authoritarianism">authoritarian regimes</a>, due to an economic boom, known as an "economic miracle", the regime reached a peak in popularity in the early 1970s.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECrocittiVallance2012[httpsbooksgooglecombooksidVhkvhllLooUCpgPA395_395&#8211;97]_152-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECrocittiVallance2012[httpsbooksgooglecombooksidVhkvhllLooUCpgPA395_395&#8211;97]-152">[151]</a></sup>\n</p><p>Slowly however, the wear and tear of years of dictatorial power that had not slowed the repression, even after the defeat of the leftist guerrillas,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-153"><a href="#cite_note-153">[152]</a></sup> plus the inability to deal with the economic crises of the period and popular pressure, made an opening policy inevitable, which from the regime side was led by Generals <a href="/wiki/Ernesto_Geisel" title="Ernesto Geisel">Ernesto Geisel</a> and <a href="/wiki/Golbery_do_Couto_e_Silva" title="Golbery do Couto e Silva">Golbery do Couto e Silva</a>.<sup class="reference" id=\'cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFausto1999Chapter_6_"The_military_government_and_the_transition_to_democracy_(1964&#8211;1984)"_154-0\'><a href=\'#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFausto1999Chapter_6_"The_military_government_and_the_transition_to_democracy_(1964&#8211;1984)"-154\'>[153]</a></sup> With the enactment of the <a href="/wiki/Amnesty_law#Brazil" title="Amnesty law">Amnesty Law</a> in 1979, Brazil began a slow return to democracy, which was completed during the 1980s.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFausto1999_96-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFausto1999-96">[95]</a></sup>\n</p><p>Civilians returned to power in 1985 when <a href="/wiki/Jos%C3%A9_Sarney" title="Jos&#233; Sarney">Jos&#233; Sarney</a> assumed the presidency. He became unpopular during his tenure through failure to control the economic crisis and <a href="/wiki/Hyperinflation" title="Hyperinflation">hyperinflation</a> he inherited from the military regime.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-155"><a href="#cite_note-155">[154]</a></sup> Sarney\'s unsuccessful government led to the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Brazilian_presidential_election,_1989" title="Brazilian presidential election, 1989">election in 1989</a> of the almost-unknown <a href="/wiki/Fernando_Collor_de_Mello" title="Fernando Collor de Mello">Fernando Collor</a>, subsequently impeached by the National Congress in 1992.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-156"><a href="#cite_note-156">[155]</a></sup>\n</p><p>Collor was succeeded by his vice-president, <a href="/wiki/Itamar_Franco" title="Itamar Franco">Itamar Franco</a>, who appointed <a href="/wiki/Fernando_Henrique_Cardoso" title="Fernando Henrique Cardoso">Fernando Henrique Cardoso</a> Minister of Finance. In 1994, Cardoso produced a highly successful <a href="/wiki/Plano_Real" title="Plano Real">Plano Real</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-157"><a href="#cite_note-157">[156]</a></sup> that, after decades of failed economic plans made by previous governments attempting to curb hyperinflation, finally stabilized the Brazilian economy.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFausto1999Epilogue_158-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFausto1999Epilogue-158">[157]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-159"><a href="#cite_note-159">[158]</a></sup> Cardoso won the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Brazilian_presidential_election,_1994" title="Brazilian presidential election, 1994">1994 election</a>, and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Brazilian_presidential_election,_1998" title="Brazilian presidential election, 1998">again in 1998</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-160"><a href="#cite_note-160">[159]</a></sup>\n</p>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Ulyssesguimaraesconstituicao.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1772" data-file-width="2595" decoding="async" height="150" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/64/Ulyssesguimaraesconstituicao.jpg/220px-Ulyssesguimaraesconstituicao.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/64/Ulyssesguimaraesconstituicao.jpg/330px-Ulyssesguimaraesconstituicao.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/64/Ulyssesguimaraesconstituicao.jpg/440px-Ulyssesguimaraesconstituicao.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Ulyssesguimaraesconstituicao.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Ulysses_Guimar%C3%A3es" title="Ulysses Guimar&#227;es">Ulysses Guimar&#227;es</a> holding the <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_Brazil" title="Constitution of Brazil">Constitution of 1988</a> in his hands.</div></div></div>\n<p>The peaceful transition of power from Cardoso to his main opposition leader, <a href="/wiki/Luiz_In%C3%A1cio_Lula_da_Silva" title="Luiz In&#225;cio Lula da Silva">Luiz In&#225;cio Lula da Silva</a> (<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Brazilian_presidential_election,_2002" title="Brazilian presidential election, 2002">elected in 2002</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Brazilian_presidential_election,_2006" title="Brazilian presidential election, 2006">re-elected in 2006</a>), was seen as proof that Brazil had achieved a long-sought political stability.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-161"><a href="#cite_note-161">[160]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-162"><a href="#cite_note-162">[161]</a></sup> However, sparked by indignation and frustrations accumulated over decades from corruption, <a href="/wiki/Police_brutality" title="Police brutality">police brutality</a>, inefficiencies of the political <a href="/wiki/The_Establishment" title="The Establishment">establishment</a> and <a href="/wiki/Public_service" title="Public service">public service</a>, <a href="/wiki/2013_protests_in_Brazil" title="2013 protests in Brazil">numerous peaceful protests</a> erupted in Brazil from the middle of first term of <a href="/wiki/Dilma_Rousseff" title="Dilma Rousseff">Dilma Rousseff</a>, who had succeeded Lula after winning election <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Brazilian_presidential_election,_2010" title="Brazilian presidential election, 2010">in 2010</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-163"><a
