href="#cite_note-163">[162]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-164"><a href="#cite_note-164">[163]</a></sup>\n</p><p>Enhanced by political and economic crises with evidence of involvement by politicians from all the primary political parties in several <a href="/wiki/Bribery" title="Bribery">bribery</a> and <a href="/wiki/Tax_evasion" title="Tax evasion">tax evasion</a> schemes,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-165"><a href="#cite_note-165">[164]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-166"><a href="#cite_note-166">[165]</a></sup> with <a href="/wiki/2015%E2%80%9316_protests_in_Brazil" title="2015&#8211;16 protests in Brazil">large street protests for and against her</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-167"><a href="#cite_note-167">[166]</a></sup> Rousseff <a href="/wiki/Impeachment_of_Dilma_Rousseff" title="Impeachment of Dilma Rousseff">was impeached</a> by the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Brazilian_Congress" title="Brazilian Congress">Brazilian Congress</a> in 2016.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-auto1_168-0"><a href="#cite_note-auto1-168">[167]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-169"><a href="#cite_note-169">[168]</a></sup> In 2017, the Supreme Court asked for the investigation of 71 Brazilian lawmakers and nine ministers in President <a href="/wiki/Michel_Temer" title="Michel Temer">Michel Temer</a>\'s cabinet allegedly linked to the <a href="/wiki/Operation_Car_Wash" title="Operation Car Wash">Petrobras corruption scandal</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-170"><a href="#cite_note-170">[169]</a></sup> President Temer is himself accused of <a href="/wiki/Corruption_in_Brazil" title="Corruption in Brazil">corruption</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-171"><a href="#cite_note-171">[170]</a></sup> In 2018, 62% of the population on a poll claimed that corruption was Brazil\'s biggest problem.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-172"><a href="#cite_note-172">[171]</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Geography">Geography</span></h2>\n<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Geography_of_Brazil" title="Geography of Brazil">Geography of Brazil</a></div>\n<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:292px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Brazil_topo.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1419" data-file-width="1400" decoding="async" height="294" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/18/Brazil_topo.jpg/290px-Brazil_topo.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/18/Brazil_topo.jpg/435px-Brazil_topo.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/18/Brazil_topo.jpg/580px-Brazil_topo.jpg 2x" width="290"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Brazil_topo.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Topographic map of Brazil</div></div></div>\n<p>Brazil occupies a large area along the eastern coast of South America and includes much of the continent\'s interior,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Encarta_6_173-0"><a href="#cite_note-Encarta_6-173">[172]</a></sup> sharing land borders with <a href="/wiki/Uruguay" title="Uruguay">Uruguay</a> to the south; <a href="/wiki/Argentina" title="Argentina">Argentina</a> and <a href="/wiki/Paraguay" title="Paraguay">Paraguay</a> to the southwest; <a href="/wiki/Bolivia" title="Bolivia">Bolivia</a> and <a href="/wiki/Peru" title="Peru">Peru</a> to the west; <a href="/wiki/Colombia" title="Colombia">Colombia</a> to the northwest; and <a href="/wiki/Venezuela" title="Venezuela">Venezuela</a>, <a href="/wiki/Guyana" title="Guyana">Guyana</a>, <a href="/wiki/Suriname" title="Suriname">Suriname</a> and <a href="/wiki/France" title="France">France</a> (French overseas region of <a href="/wiki/French_Guiana" title="French Guiana">French Guiana</a>) to the north. It shares a border with every South American country except <a href="/wiki/Ecuador" title="Ecuador">Ecuador</a> and <a href="/wiki/Chile" title="Chile">Chile</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CIA_Geo_15-2"><a href="#cite_note-CIA_Geo-15">[14]</a></sup>\n</p><p>It also encompasses a number of oceanic <a href="/wiki/Archipelago" title="Archipelago">archipelagos</a>, such as <a href="/wiki/Fernando_de_Noronha" title="Fernando de Noronha">Fernando de Noronha</a>, <a href="/wiki/Rocas_Atoll" title="Rocas Atoll">Rocas Atoll</a>, <a href="/wiki/Saint_Peter_and_Saint_Paul_Archipelago" title="Saint Peter and Saint Paul Archipelago">Saint Peter and Paul Rocks</a>, and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Trindade_and_Martim_Vaz" title="Trindade and Martim Vaz">Trindade and Martim Vaz</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CIA_Geo_15-3"><a href="#cite_note-CIA_Geo-15">[14]</a></sup> Its size, relief, climate, and natural resources make Brazil geographically diverse.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Encarta_6_173-1"><a href="#cite_note-Encarta_6-173">[172]</a></sup> Including its <a href="/wiki/Atlantic_Ocean" title="Atlantic Ocean">Atlantic</a> islands, Brazil lies between latitudes <a href="/wiki/6th_parallel_north" title="6th parallel north">6&#176;N</a> and <a href="/wiki/34th_parallel_south" title="34th parallel south">34&#176;S</a>, and longitudes <a href="/wiki/28th_meridian_west" title="28th meridian west">28&#176;</a> and <a href="/wiki/74th_meridian_west" title="74th meridian west">74&#176;W</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CIA_Geo_15-4"><a href="#cite_note-CIA_Geo-15">[14]</a></sup>\n</p><p>Brazil is the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_countries_and_outlying_territories_by_total_area" title="List of countries and outlying territories by total area">fifth largest</a> country in the world, and third largest in the Americas, with a total area of 8,515,767.049&#160;km<sup>2</sup> (3,287,956&#160;sq&#160;mi),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Official_Area_174-0"><a href="#cite_note-Official_Area-174">[173]</a></sup> including 55,455&#160;km<sup>2</sup> (21,411&#160;sq&#160;mi) of water.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CIA_Geo_15-5"><a href="#cite_note-CIA_Geo-15">[14]</a></sup> It spans four <a href="/wiki/Time_zone" title="Time zone">time zones</a>; from <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/UTC-05" title="UTC-05">UTC&#8722;5</a> comprising the state of <a href="/wiki/Acre_(state)" title="Acre (state)">Acre</a> and the westernmost portion of <a href="/wiki/Amazonas_(Brazilian_state)" title="Amazonas (Brazilian state)">Amazonas</a>, to <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/UTC%E2%88%9204" title="UTC&#8722;04">UTC&#8722;4</a> in the western states, to <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/UTC%E2%88%9203" title="UTC&#8722;03">UTC&#8722;3</a> in the eastern states (the <a href="/wiki/Time_in_Brazil" title="Time in Brazil">national time</a>) and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/UTC%E2%88%9202" title="UTC&#8722;02">UTC&#8722;2</a> in the <a href="/wiki/List_of_islands_of_Brazil" title="List of islands of Brazil">Atlantic islands</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-timezones_175-0"><a href="#cite_note-timezones-175">[174]</a></sup>\n</p><p>Brazil is the only country in the world that has the <a href="/wiki/Equator" title="Equator">equator</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Tropic_of_Capricorn" title="Tropic of Capricorn">Tropic of Capricorn</a> running through it. Brazilian topography is also diverse and includes hills, mountains, plains, highlands, and scrublands. Much of the terrain lies between 200 metres (660&#160;ft) and 800 metres (2,600&#160;ft) in elevation.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Encarta_7_176-0"><a href="#cite_note-Encarta_7-176">[175]</a></sup> The main upland area occupies most of the southern half of the country.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Encarta_7_176-1"><a href="#cite_note-Encarta_7-176">[175]</a></sup> The northwestern parts of the plateau consist of broad, rolling terrain broken by low, rounded hills.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Encarta_7_176-2"><a href="#cite_note-Encarta_7-176">[175]</a></sup>\n</p>\n<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r856303569" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="thumb tmulti tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:425px;max-width:425px"><div class="tsingle" style="float:left;margin:1px;width:222px;max-width:222px"><div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Pico_da_Neblina_(FAB).jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="400" data-file-width="600" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/35/Pico_da_Neblina_%28FAB%29.jpg/220px-Pico_da_Neblina_%28FAB%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/35/Pico_da_Neblina_%28FAB%29.jpg/330px-Pico_da_Neblina_%28FAB%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/35/Pico_da_Neblina_%28FAB%29.jpg/440px-Pico_da_Neblina_%28FAB%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left"><a href="/wiki/Pico_da_Neblina" title="Pico da Neblina">Pico da Neblina</a>, <a href="/wiki/Amazonas_(Brazilian_state)" title="Amazonas (Brazilian state)">Amazonas</a>, part of the <a href="/wiki/Guiana_Shield" title="Guiana Shield">Guiana Shield</a> and the highest peak in Brazil, 2,995.3 metres (9,827&#160;ft) above sea level.</div></div><div class="tsingle" style="float:left;margin:1px;width:199px;max-width:199px"><div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Canind%C3%A9_de_S%C3%A3o_Francisco-002.jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="1500" data-file-width="2000" decoding="async" height="148" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6f/Canind%C3%A9_de_S%C3%A3o_Francisco-002.jpg/197px-Canind%C3%A9_de_S%C3%A3o_Francisco-002.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6f/Canind%C3%A9_de_S%C3%A3o_Francisco-002.jpg/296px-Canind%C3%A9_de_S%C3%A3o_Francisco-002.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6f/Canind%C3%A9_de_S%C3%A3o_Francisco-002.jpg/394px-Canind%C3%A9_de_S%C3%A3o_Francisco-002.jpg 2x" width="197"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left">Canion of <a href="/wiki/Canind%C3%A9_de_S%C3%A3o_Francisco" title="Canind&#233; de S&#227;o Francisco">Canind&#233; de S&#227;o Francisco</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sergipe" title="Sergipe">Sergipe</a>, a geological accident carved by the <a href="/wiki/S%C3%A3o_Francisco_River" title="S&#227;o Francisco River">S&#227;o Francisco River</a>.</div></div><div style="clear:left"></div></div></div>\n<p>The southeastern section is more rugged, with a complex mass of ridges and mountain ranges reaching elevations of up to 1,200 metres (3,900&#160;ft).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Encarta_7_176-3"><a href="#cite_note-Encarta_7-176">[175]</a></sup> These ranges include the <a href="/wiki/Mantiqueira_Mountains" title="Mantiqueira Mountains">Mantiqueira</a> and <a href="/wiki/Espinha%C3%A7o_Mountains" title="Espinha&#231;o Mountains">Espinha&#231;o mountains</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Serra_do_Mar" title="Serra do Mar">Serra do Mar</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Encarta_7_176-4"><a href="#cite_note-Encarta_7-176">[175]</a></sup>\n</p><p>In the north, the <a href="/wiki/Guiana_Shield" title="Guiana Shield">Guiana Highlands</a> form a major drainage divide, separating rivers that flow south into the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Amazon_Basin" title="Amazon Basin">Amazon Basin</a> from rivers that empty into the <a href="/wiki/Orinoco" title="Orinoco">Orinoco River</a> system, in Venezuela, to the north. The highest point in Brazil is the <a href="/wiki/Pico_da_Neblina" title="Pico da Neblina">Pico da Neblina</a> at 2,994 metres (9,823&#160;ft), and the lowest is the Atlantic Ocean.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CIA_Geo_15-6"><a href="#cite_note-CIA_Geo-15">[14]</a></sup>\n</p><p>Brazil has a dense and complex system of rivers, one of the world\'s most extensive, with eight major drainage basins, all of which drain into the Atlantic.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Encarta_8_177-0"><a href="#cite_note-Encarta_8-177">[176]</a></sup> Major rivers include the <a href="/wiki/Amazon_River" title="Amazon River">Amazon</a> (the world\'s second-longest river and the largest in terms of volume of water), the <a href="/wiki/Paran%C3%A1_River" title="Paran&#225; River">Paran&#225;</a> and its major tributary the <a href="/wiki/Iguazu_River" title="Iguazu River">Igua&#231;u</a> (which includes the <a href="/wiki/Iguazu_Falls" title="Iguazu Falls">Iguazu Falls</a>), the <a href="/wiki/Rio_Negro_(Amazon)" title="Rio Negro (Amazon)">Negro</a>, <a href="/wiki/S%C3%A3o_Francisco_River" title="S&#227;o Francisco River">S&#227;o Francisco</a>, <a href="/wiki/Xingu_River" title="Xingu River">Xingu</a>, <a href="/wiki/Madeira_River" title="Madeira River">Madeira</a> and <a href="/wiki/Tapaj%C3%B3s" title="Tapaj&#243;s">Tapaj&#243;s</a> rivers.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Encarta_8_177-1"><a href="#cite_note-Encarta_8-177">[176]</a></sup>\n</p>\n<div style="clear:both;"></div>\n<div class="thumb tnone" style="margin-left: auto; margin-right:auto; width:auto; max-width:808px;">\n<div class="thumbinner"><div class="noresize overflowbugx" style="overflow:auto;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Chapada_Diamantina_Panorama_(cropped).jpg" title="Chapada Diamantina, in the Chapada Diamantina National Park, Bahia."><img alt="" data-file-height="905" data-file-width="3648" decoding="async" height="198" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/38/Chapada_Diamantina_Panorama_%28cropped%29.jpg/800px-Chapada_Diamantina_Panorama_%28cropped%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/38/Chapada_Diamantina_Panorama_%28cropped%29.jpg/1200px-Chapada_Diamantina_Panorama_%28cropped%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/38/Chapada_Diamantina_Panorama_%28cropped%29.jpg/1600px-Chapada_Diamantina_Panorama_%28cropped%29.jpg 2x" width="800"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Chapada_Diamantina_Panorama_(cropped).jpg" title="File:Chapada Diamantina Panorama (cropped).jpg"> </a></div><center><a href="/wiki/Chapada_Diamantina" title="Chapada Diamantina">Chapada Diamantina</a>, in the <a href="/wiki/Chapada_Diamantina_National_Park" title="Chapada Diamantina National Park">Chapada Diamantina National Park</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bahia" title="Bahia">Bahia</a>.</center></div>\n</div></div>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Climate">Climate</span></h3>\n<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Climate_of_Brazil" title="Climate of Brazil">Climate of Brazil</a></div>\n<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:262px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:K%C3%B6ppen_climate_types_of_Brazil.svg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1296" data-file-width="960" decoding="async" height="351" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f9/K%C3%B6ppen_climate_types_of_Brazil.svg/260px-K%C3%B6ppen_climate_types_of_Brazil.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f9/K%C3%B6ppen_climate_types_of_Brazil.svg/390px-K%C3%B6ppen_climate_types_of_Brazil.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f9/K%C3%B6ppen_climate_types_of_Brazil.svg/520px-K%C3%B6ppen_climate_types_of_Brazil.svg.png 2x" width="260"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:K%C3%B6ppen_climate_types_of_Brazil.svg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Brazil map of <a href="/wiki/K%C3%B6ppen_climate_classification" title="K&#246;ppen climate classification">K&#246;ppen climate classification</a></div></div></div>\n<p>The climate of Brazil comprises a wide range of weather conditions across a large area and varied topography, but most of the country is tropical.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CIA_Geo_15-7"><a href="#cite_note-CIA_Geo-15">[14]</a></sup> According to the <a href="/wiki/K%C3%B6ppen_climate_classification" title="K&#246;ppen climate classification">K&#246;ppen system</a>, Brazil hosts six major climatic subtypes: <a href="/wiki/Desert_climate" title="Desert climate">desert</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tropical_rainforest_climate" title="Tropical rainforest climate">equatorial</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tropical_climate" title="Tropical climate">tropical</a>, <a href="/wiki/Semi-arid_climate" title="Semi-arid climate">semiarid</a>, <a href="/wiki/Oceanic_climate" title="Oceanic climate">oceanic</a> and <a href="/wiki/Humid_subtropical_climate" title="Humid subtropical climate">subtropical</a>. The different climatic conditions produce environments ranging from <a href="/wiki/Tropical_and_subtropical_moist_broadleaf_forests" title="Tropical and subtropical moist broadleaf forests">equatorial rainforests</a> in the north and semiarid deserts in the northeast, to <a href="/wiki/Temperate_coniferous_forest" title="Temperate coniferous forest">temperate coniferous forests</a> in the south and <a href="/wiki/Tropical_and_subtropical_grasslands,_savannas,_and_shrublands" title="Tropical and subtropical grasslands, savannas, and shrublands">tropical savannas</a> in central Brazil.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BBC_Weather_178-0"><a href="#cite_note-BBC_Weather-178">[177]</a></sup> Many regions have starkly different <a href="/wiki/Microclimate" title="Microclimate">microclimates</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Encarta_9_179-0"><a href="#cite_note-Encarta_9-179">[178]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BT_180-0"><a href="#cite_note-BT-180">[179]</a></sup>\n</p><p>An equatorial climate characterizes much of northern Brazil. There is no real <a href="/wiki/Dry_season" title="Dry season">dry season</a>, but there are some variations in the period of the year when most rain falls.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BBC_Weather_178-1"><a href="#cite_note-BBC_Weather-178">[177]</a></sup> Temperatures average 25&#160;&#176;C (77&#160;&#176;F),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BT_180-1"><a href="#cite_note-BT-180">[179]</a></sup> with more significant temperature variation between night and day than between seasons.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Encarta_9_179-1"><a href="#cite_note-Encarta_9-179">[178]</a></sup>\n</p><p>Over central Brazil rainfall is more seasonal, characteristic of a savanna climate.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Encarta_9_179-2"><a href="#cite_note-Encarta_9-179">[178]</a></sup> This region is as extensive as the Amazon basin but has a very different climate as it lies farther south at a higher altitude.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BBC_Weather_178-2"><a href="#cite_note-BBC_Weather-178">[177]</a></sup> In the interior northeast, seasonal rainfall is even more extreme.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Rain_181-0"><a href="#cite_note-Rain-181">[180]</a></sup>\n</p><p>The semiarid climatic region generally receives less than 800 millimetres (31.5&#160;in) of rain,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Rain_181-1"><a href="#cite_note-Rain-181">[180]</a></sup> most of which generally falls in a period of three to five months of the year<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-182"><a href="#cite_note-182">[181]</a></sup> and occasionally less than this, creating long periods of drought.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Encarta_9_179-3"><a href="#cite_note-Encarta_9-179">[178]</a></sup> Brazil\'s 1877&#8211;78 <i><a href="/wiki/Grande_Seca" title="Grande Seca">Grande Seca</a></i> (Great Drought), the worst in Brazil\'s history,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-183"><a href="#cite_note-183">[182]</a></sup> caused approximately half a million deaths.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-184"><a href="#cite_note-184">[183]</a></sup> A similarly devastating drought occurred in 1915.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-185"><a href="#cite_note-185">[184]</a></sup>\n</p><p>South of Bahia, near the coasts, and more southerly most of the state of S&#227;o Paulo, the distribution of rainfall changes, with rain falling throughout the year.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BBC_Weather_178-3"><a href="#cite_note-BBC_Weather-178">[177]</a></sup> The south enjoys subtropical conditions, with cool winters and average annual temperatures not exceeding 18&#160;&#176;C (64.4&#160;&#176;F);<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BT_180-2"><a href="#cite_note-BT-180">[179]</a></sup> winter frosts and <a href="/wiki/Snow_in_Brazil" title="Snow in Brazil">snowfall</a> are not rare in the highest areas.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BBC_Weather_178-4"><a href="#cite_note-BBC_Weather-178">[177]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Encarta_9_179-4"><a href="#cite_note-Encarta_9-179">[178]</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Biodiversity_and_environment">Biodiversity and environment</span></h3>\n<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Wildlife_of_Brazil" title="Wildlife of Brazil">Wildlife of Brazil</a>, <a href="/wiki/Deforestation_in_Brazil" title="Deforestation in Brazil">Deforestation in Brazil</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Conservation_in_Brazil" title="Conservation in Brazil">Conservation in Brazil</a></div>\n<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r856303569" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="thumb tmulti tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:408px;max-width:408px"><div class="tsingle" style="float:left;margin:1px;width:202px;max-width:202px"><div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Lear%27s_Macaw_Anodorhynchus_leari_(cropped).jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="421" data-file-width="637" decoding="async" height="132" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ac/Lear%27s_Macaw_Anodorhynchus_leari_%28cropped%29.jpg/200px-Lear%27s_Macaw_Anodorhynchus_leari_%28cropped%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ac/Lear%27s_Macaw_Anodorhynchus_leari_%28cropped%29.jpg/300px-Lear%27s_Macaw_Anodorhynchus_leari_%28cropped%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ac/Lear%27s_Macaw_Anodorhynchus_leari_%28cropped%29.jpg/400px-Lear%27s_Macaw_Anodorhynchus_leari_%28cropped%29.jpg 2x" width="200"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left"><a href="/wiki/Lear%27s_macaw" title="Lear\'s macaw">Lear\'s macaw</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Endemic" title="Endemic">endemic</a> to <a href="/wiki/Raso_da_Catarina" title="Raso da Catarina">Raso da Catarina</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bahia" title="Bahia">Bahia</a>.</div></div><div class="tsingle" style="float:left;margin:1px;width:202px;max-width:202px"><div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Amazon_CIAT_(5).jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="2848" data-file-width="4288" decoding="async" height="133" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/18/Amazon_CIAT_%285%29.jpg/200px-Amazon_CIAT_%285%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/18/Amazon_CIAT_%285%29.jpg/300px-Amazon_CIAT_%285%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/18/Amazon_CIAT_%285%29.jpg/400px-Amazon_CIAT_%285%29.jpg 2x" width="200"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left">The <a href="/wiki/Amazon_rainforest" title="Amazon rainforest">Amazon rainforest</a>, the most biodiverse <a href="/wiki/Rainforest" title="Rainforest">rainforest</a> in the world.</div></div><div style="clear:left"></div></div></div>\n<p>Brazil\'s large territory comprises different ecosystems, such as the <a href="/wiki/Amazon_rainforest" title="Amazon rainforest">Amazon rainforest</a>, recognized as having the greatest <a href="/wiki/Biodiversity" title="Biodiversity">biological diversity</a> in the world,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-WWF_186-0"><a href="#cite_note-WWF-186">[185]</a></sup> with the <a href="/wiki/Atlantic_Forest" title="Atlantic Forest">Atlantic Forest</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Cerrado" title="Cerrado">Cerrado</a>, sustaining the greatest biodiversity.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Encarta_10_187-0"><a href="#cite_note-Encarta_10-187">[186]</a></sup> In the south, the <a href="/wiki/Araucaria" title="Araucaria">Araucaria</a> pine forest grows under temperate conditions.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Encarta_10_187-1"><a href="#cite_note-Encarta_10-187">[186]</a></sup> The rich wildlife of Brazil reflects the variety of natural habitats. Scientists estimate that the total number of <a href="/wiki/Wildlife_of_Brazil" title="Wildlife of Brazil">plant</a> and <a href="/wiki/Wildlife_of_Brazil" title="Wildlife of Brazil">animal species</a> in Brazil could approach four million, mostly invertebrates.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Encarta_10_187-2"><a href="#cite_note-Encarta_10-187">[186]</a></sup>\n</p><p>Larger mammals include carnivores <a href="/wiki/Cougar" title="Cougar">pumas</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jaguar" title="Jaguar">jaguars</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ocelot" title="Ocelot">ocelots</a>, rare <a href="/wiki/Bush_dog" title="Bush dog">bush dogs</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Fox" title="Fox">foxes</a>, and herbivores <a href="/wiki/Peccary" title="Peccary">peccaries</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tapir" title="Tapir">tapirs</a>, <a href="/wiki/Anteater" title="Anteater">anteaters</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sloth" title="Sloth">sloths</a>, <a href="/wiki/Opossum" title="Opossum">opossums</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Armadillo" title="Armadillo">armadillos</a>. <a href="/wiki/Deer" title="Deer">Deer</a> are plentiful in the south, and many species of <a href="/wiki/New_World_monkey" title="New World monkey">New World monkeys</a> are found in the northern <a href="/wiki/Rainforest" title="Rainforest">rain forests</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Encarta_10_187-3"><a href="#cite_note-Encarta_10-187">[186]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-188"><a href="#cite_note-188">[187]</a></sup> Concern for the environment has grown in response to global interest in environmental issues.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Encarta_11_189-0"><a href="#cite_note-Encarta_11-189">[188]</a></sup> Brazil\'s Amazon Basin is home to an extremely diverse array of fish species, including the <a href="/wiki/Red-bellied_piranha" title="Red-bellied piranha">red-bellied piranha</a>. Despite its reputation as a ferocious freshwater fish, the red-bellied piranha is actually a generally timid scavenger.\n</p>\n<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r856303569" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="thumb tmulti tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:408px;max-width:408px"><div class="tsingle" style="float:left;margin:1px;width:202px;max-width:202px"><div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Jaguar_(Panthera_onca_palustris)_female_Piquiri_River_2.JPG"><img alt="" data-file-height="3179" data-file-width="4769" decoding="async" height="133" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e9/Jaguar_%28Panthera_onca_palustris%29_female_Piquiri_River_2.JPG/200px-Jaguar_%28Panthera_onca_palustris%29_female_Piquiri_River_2.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e9/Jaguar_%28Panthera_onca_palustris%29_female_Piquiri_River_2.JPG/300px-Jaguar_%28Panthera_onca_palustris%29_female_Piquiri_River_2.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e9/Jaguar_%28Panthera_onca_palustris%29_female_Piquiri_River_2.JPG/400px-Jaguar_%28Panthera_onca_palustris%29_female_Piquiri_River_2.JPG 2x" width="200"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left">Female <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Pantanal_jaguar" title="Pantanal jaguar">pantanal jaguar</a> in <a href="/wiki/Piquir%C3%AD_River_(S%C3%A3o_Louren%C3%A7o)" title="Piquir&#237; River (S&#227;o Louren&#231;o)">Piquir&#237; River</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pantanal" title="Pantanal">Pantanal</a>.</div></div><div class="tsingle" style="float:left;margin:1px;width:202px;max-width:202px"><div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Golden_Lion_Tamarin_Poco_das_Antas.jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="1181" data-file-width="1772" decoding="async" height="133" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/40/Golden_Lion_Tamarin_Poco_das_Antas.jpg/200px-Golden_Lion_Tamarin_Poco_das_Antas.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/40/Golden_Lion_Tamarin_Poco_das_Antas.jpg/300px-Golden_Lion_Tamarin_Poco_das_Antas.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/40/Golden_Lion_Tamarin_Poco_das_Antas.jpg/400px-Golden_Lion_Tamarin_Poco_das_Antas.jpg 2x" width="200"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left"><a href="/wiki/Golden_lion_tamarin" title="Golden lion tamarin">Golden lion tamarin</a>, an <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Endemic" title="Endemic">endemic</a> animal of Brazil, in the <a href="/wiki/Po%C3%A7o_das_Antas_Biological_Reserve" title="Po&#231;o das Antas Biological Reserve">Po&#231;o das Antas Biological Reserve</a>.</div></div><div style="clear:left"></div></div></div>\n<p>Biodiversity can contribute to <a href="/wiki/Agriculture" title="Agriculture">agriculture</a>, livestock, forestry and fisheries extraction. However, almost all economically exploited species of plants, such as soybeans and coffee, or animals, such as chickens, are imported from other countries, and the economic use of native species still crawls. In the Brazilian GDP, the forest sector represents just over 1% and fishing 0.4%.\n</p><p>The natural heritage of Brazil is severely threatened by cattle ranching and agriculture, logging, mining, resettlement, oil and gas extraction, over-fishing, wildlife trade, dams and infrastructure, water pollution, climate change, fire, and invasive species.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-WWF_186-1"><a href="#cite_note-WWF-186">[185]</a></sup> In many areas of the country, the natural environment is threatened by development.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-190"><a href="#cite_note-190">[189]</a></sup>\n</p><p>The construction of highways has opened up previously remote areas for agriculture and settlement; dams have flooded valleys and inundated wildlife habitats; and mines have scarred and polluted the landscape.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Encarta_11_189-1"><a href="#cite_note-Encarta_11-189">[188]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-191"><a href="#cite_note-191">[190]</a></sup> At least 70 dams are said to be planned for the Amazon region, including the controversial <a href="/wiki/Belo_Monte_Dam" title="Belo Monte Dam">Belo Monte</a> hydroelectric dam.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-192"><a href="#cite_note-192">[191]</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Government_and_politics">Government and politics</span></h2>\n<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Politics_of_Brazil" title="Politics of Brazil">Politics of Brazil</a>, <a href="/wiki/Federal_government_of_Brazil" title="Federal government of Brazil">Federal government of Brazil</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Elections_in_Brazil" title="Elections in Brazil">Elections in Brazil</a></div>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Pal%C3%A1cio_do_Planalto_GGFD8938.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2048" data-file-width="3072" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/78/Pal%C3%A1cio_do_Planalto_GGFD8938.jpg/220px-Pal%C3%A1cio_do_Planalto_GGFD8938.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/78/Pal%C3%A1cio_do_Planalto_GGFD8938.jpg/330px-Pal%C3%A1cio_do_Planalto_GGFD8938.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/78/Pal%C3%A1cio_do_Planalto_GGFD8938.jpg/440px-Pal%C3%A1cio_do_Planalto_GGFD8938.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Pal%C3%A1cio_do_Planalto_GGFD8938.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Pal%C3%A1cio_do_Planalto" title="Pal&#225;cio do Planalto">Pal&#225;cio do Planalto</a> ("Plateau Palace"), the official workplace of the <a href="/wiki/President_of_Brazil" title="President of Brazil">President of Brazil</a>.</div></div></div>\n<p>The form of government is a <a href="/wiki/Democracy" title="Democracy">democratic</a> <a href="/wiki/Federation" title="Federation">federative</a> <a href="/wiki/Republic" title="Republic">republic</a>, with a <a href="/wiki/Presidential_system" title="Presidential system">presidential system</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Constitui&#231;&#227;o_17-1"><a href="#cite_note-Constitui&#231;&#227;o-17">[16]</a></sup> The president is both head of state and head of government of the Union and is elected for a four-year term,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Constitui&#231;&#227;o_17-2"><a href="#cite_note-Constitui&#231;&#227;o-17">[16]</a></sup> with the possibility of re-election for a second successive term. The current president is <a href="/wiki/Jair_Bolsonaro" title="Jair Bolsonaro">Jair Bolsonaro</a>. The previous president, <a href="/wiki/Michel_Temer" title="Michel Temer">Michel Temer</a>, replaced <a href="/wiki/Dilma_Rousseff" title="Dilma Rousseff">Dilma Rousseff</a> after her <a href="/wiki/Impeachment_of_Dilma_Rousseff" title="Impeachment of Dilma Rousseff">impeachment</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-auto_193-0"><a href="#cite_note-auto-193">[192]</a></sup> The President appoints the <a href="/wiki/Minister_of_State" title="Minister of State">Ministers of State</a>, who assist in government.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Constitui&#231;&#227;o_17-3"><a href="#cite_note-Constitui&#231;&#227;o-17">[16]</a></sup> Legislative houses in each political entity are the main source of law in Brazil. The <a href="/wiki/National_Congress_of_Brazil" title="National Congress of Brazil">National Congress</a> is the Federation\'s bicameral legislature, consisting of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Chamber_of_Deputies_of_Brazil" title="Chamber of Deputies of Brazil">Chamber of Deputies</a> and the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Senate_of_Brazil" title="Senate of Brazil">Federal Senate</a>. Judiciary authorities exercise jurisdictional duties almost exclusively. Brazil is a <a href="/wiki/Democracy" title="Democracy">democracy</a>, according to the <a href="/wiki/Democracy_Index" title="Democracy Index">Democracy Index</a> 2010.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-194"><a href="#cite_note-194">[193]</a></sup>\n</p><p>The political-administrative organization of the Federative Republic of Brazil comprises the Union, the states, the Federal District, and the municipalities.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Constitui&#231;&#227;o_17-4"><a href="#cite_note-Constitui&#231;&#227;o-17">[16]</a></sup> The Union, the states, the Federal District, and the municipalities, are the "spheres of government". The <a href="/wiki/Federation" title="Federation">federation</a> is set on five fundamental principles:<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Constitui&#231;&#227;o_17-5"><a href="#cite_note-Constitui&#231;&#227;o-17">[16]</a></sup> sovereignty, citizenship, dignity of human beings, the social values of labour and freedom of enterprise, and political pluralism. The classic tripartite branches of government (executive, legislative and judicial under a checks and balances system) are formally established by the Constitution.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Constitui&#231;&#227;o_17-6"><a href="#cite_note-Constitui&#231;&#227;o-17">[16]</a></sup> The executive and legislative are organized <a href="/wiki/Separation_of_powers" title="Separation of powers">independently in all three spheres of government</a>, while the judiciary is organized only at the federal and state and Federal District spheres.\n</p>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Brasilia_Congresso_Nacional_05_2007_221.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1162" data-file-width="2048" decoding="async" height="125" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/74/Brasilia_Congresso_Nacional_05_2007_221.jpg/220px-Brasilia_Congresso_Nacional_05_2007_221.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/74/Brasilia_Congresso_Nacional_05_2007_221.jpg/330px-Brasilia_Congresso_Nacional_05_2007_221.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/74/Brasilia_Congresso_Nacional_05_2007_221.jpg/440px-Brasilia_Congresso_Nacional_05_2007_221.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Brasilia_Congresso_Nacional_05_2007_221.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/National_Congress_of_Brazil" title="National Congress of Brazil">National Congress</a>, seat of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Legislative_branch" title="Legislative branch">legislative branch</a>.</div></div></div>\n<p>All members of the executive and legislative branches are directly elected.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-embassy_195-0"><a href="#cite_note-embassy-195">[194]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-196"><a href="#cite_note-196">[195]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-197"><a href="#cite_note-197">[196]</a></sup> Judges and other judicial officials are appointed after passing entry exams.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-embassy_195-1"><a href="#cite_note-embassy-195">[194]</a></sup> For most of its democratic history, Brazil has had a multi-party system, proportional representation. Voting is compulsory for the literate between 18 and 70 years old and optional for illiterates and those between 16 and 18 or beyond 70.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Constitui&#231;&#227;o_17-7"><a href="#cite_note-Constitui&#231;&#227;o-17">[16]</a></sup>\n</p><p>Together with several smaller parties, four political parties stand out: <a href="/wiki/Workers%27_Party_(Brazil)" title="Workers\' Party (Brazil)">Workers\' Party</a> (PT), <a href="/wiki/Brazilian_Social_Democracy_Party" title="Brazilian Social Democracy Party">Brazilian Social Democracy Party</a> (PSDB), <a href="/wiki/Brazilian_Democratic_Movement" title="Brazilian Democratic Movement">Brazilian Democratic Movement</a> (MDB) and <a href="/wiki/Democrats_(Brazil)" title="Democrats (Brazil)">Democrats</a> (DEM). Fifteen political parties are represented in Congress. It is common for politicians to switch parties, and thus the proportion of congressional seats held by particular parties changes regularly.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-198"><a href="#cite_note-198">[197]</a></sup> Almost all governmental and administrative functions are exercised by authorities and agencies affiliated to the Executive.\n</p>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Law">Law</span></h3>\n<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Law_of_Brazil" title="Law of Brazil">Law of Brazil</a>, <a href="/wiki/Law_enforcement_in_Brazil" title="Law enforcement in Brazil">Law enforcement in Brazil</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Crime_in_Brazil" title="Crime in Brazil">Crime in Brazil</a></div>\n<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Supremo_Brasil.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1944" data-file-width="2896" decoding="async" height="148" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/17/Supremo_Brasil.jpg/220px-Supremo_Brasil.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/17/Supremo_Brasil.jpg/330px-Supremo_Brasil.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/17/Supremo_Brasil.jpg/440px-Supremo_Brasil.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Supremo_Brasil.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Supreme_Federal_Court_of_Brazil" title="Supreme Federal Court of Brazil">Supreme Federal Court of Brazil</a> serves primarily as the Constitutional Court of the country</div></div></div>\n<p>Brazilian law is based on the <a href="/wiki/Civil_law_(legal_system)" title="Civil law (legal system)">civil law</a> legal system<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-199"><a href="#cite_note-199">[198]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Civil_law_(legal_system)" title="Civil law (legal system)">civil law</a> concepts prevail over common law practice. Most of Brazilian law is codified, although non-codified statutes also represent a substantial part, playing a complementary role. Court decisions set out interpretive guidelines; however, they are seldom binding on other specific cases. Doctrinal works and the works of academic jurists have strong influence in law creation and in law cases.\n</p><p>The legal system is based on the <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_Brazil" title="Constitution of Brazil">Federal Constitution</a>, promulgated on 5 October 1988, and is the fundamental law of Brazil. All other legislation and court decisions must conform to its rules.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-200"><a href="#cite_note-200">[199]</a></sup> As of  April&#160;2007<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Brazil&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, there have been 53 amendments. States have their own constitutions, which must not contradict the Federal Constitution.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-201"><a href="#cite_note-201">[200]</a></sup> Municipalities and the Federal District have "organic laws" (<i lang="pt" title="Portuguese language text">leis org&#226;nicas</i>), which act in a similar way to constitutions.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-DeffentiBarral2011_202-0"><a href="#cite_note-DeffentiBarral2011-202">[201]</a></sup> Legislative entities are the main source of statutes, although in certain matters judiciary and executive bodies may enact legal norms.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Constitui&#231;&#227;o_17-8"><a href="#cite_note-Constitui&#231;&#227;o-17">[16]</a></sup> Jurisdiction is administered by the judiciary entities, although in rare situations the <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_Brazil" title="Constitution of Brazil">Federal Constitution</a> allows the Federal Senate to pass on legal judgments.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Constitui&#231;&#227;o_17-9"><a href="#cite_note-Constitui&#231;&#227;o-17">[16]</a></sup> There are also specialized military, labor, and electoral courts.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Constitui&#231;&#227;o_17-10"><a href="#cite_note-Constitui&#231;&#227;o-17">[16]</a></sup> The highest court is the <a href="/wiki/Supreme_Federal_Court" title="Supreme Federal Court">Supreme Federal Court</a>.\n</p><p>This system has been criticized over the last few decades for the slow pace of decision-making. Lawsuits on appeal may take several years to resolve, and in some cases more than a decade elapses before definitive rulings.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-203"><a href="#cite_note-203">[202]</a></sup> Nevertheless, the Supreme Federal Tribunal was the first court in the world to transmit its sessions on television, and also via <a href="/wiki/YouTube" title="YouTube">YouTube</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-204"><a href="#cite_note-204">[203]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-205"><a href="#cite_note-205">[204]</a></sup> More recently, in December 2009, the Supreme Court adopted <a href="/wiki/Twitter" title="Twitter">Twitter</a> to display items on the day planner of the ministers, to inform the daily actions of the Court and the most important decisions made by them.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-206"><a href="#cite_note-206">[205]</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Military">Military</span></h3>\n<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Brazilian_Armed_Forces" title="Brazilian Armed Forces">Brazilian Armed Forces</a></div>\n<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r856303569" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="thumb tmulti tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:224px;max-width:224px"><div class="tsingle" style="margin:1px;width:222px;max-width:222px"><div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Saab_Gripen_NG.png"><img alt="" data-file-height="1080" data-file-width="1861" decoding="async" height="128" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/50/Saab_Gripen_NG.png/220px-Saab_Gripen_NG.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/50/Saab_Gripen_NG.png/330px-Saab_Gripen_NG.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/50/Saab_Gripen_NG.png/440px-Saab_Gripen_NG.png 2x" width="220"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left"><a href="/wiki/Brazilian_Air_Force" title="Brazilian Air Force">Brazilian Air Force</a> <a href="/wiki/Saab_JAS_39_Gripen#Brazil" title="Saab JAS 39 Gripen">Saab Gripen NG</a></div></div><div class="tsingle" style="margin:1px;width:222px;max-width:222px"><div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Astros_2020_(14338252946).jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="2089" data-file-width="2931" decoding="async" height="157" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a6/Astros_2020_%2814338252946%29.jpg/220px-Astros_2020_%2814338252946%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a6/Astros_2020_%2814338252946%29.jpg/330px-Astros_2020_%2814338252946%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a6/Astros_2020_%2814338252946%29.jpg/440px-Astros_2020_%2814338252946%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left"><a href="/wiki/Brazilian_Army" title="Brazilian Army">Brazilian Army</a> <a href="/wiki/Astros_II_MLRS" title="Astros II MLRS">Astros 2020</a></div></div><div class="tsingle" style="margin:1px;width:222px;max-width:222px"><div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:GLAM_MB_Chegada_do_PHM_%22Atl%C3%A2ntico%22_(29323273127).jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="3712" data-file-width="5568" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f9/GLAM_MB_Chegada_do_PHM_%22Atl%C3%A2ntico%22_%2829323273127%29.jpg/220px-GLAM_MB_Chegada_do_PHM_%22Atl%C3%A2ntico%22_%2829323273127%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f9/GLAM_MB_Chegada_do_PHM_%22Atl%C3%A2ntico%22_%2829323273127%29.jpg/330px-GLAM_MB_Chegada_do_PHM_%22Atl%C3%A2ntico%22_%2829323273127%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f9/GLAM_MB_Chegada_do_PHM_%22Atl%C3%A2ntico%22_%2829323273127%29.jpg/440px-GLAM_MB_Chegada_do_PHM_%22Atl%C3%A2ntico%22_%2829323273127%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left"><a href="/wiki/Brazilian_Navy" title="Brazilian Navy">Brazilian Navy</a>\'s <a href="/wiki/Flagship" title="Flagship">flagship</a> <a href="/wiki/HMS_Ocean_(L12)#Sale_to_Brazil" title="HMS Ocean (L12)">PHM <i>Atl&#226;ntico</i></a></div></div></div></div>\n<p>The armed forces of Brazil are the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_number_of_military_and_paramilitary_personnel" title="List of countries by number of military and paramilitary personnel">largest</a> in Latin America by active personnel and the largest in terms of military equipment.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-207"><a href="#cite_note-207">[206]</a></sup> It consists of the <a href="/wiki/Brazilian_Army" title="Brazilian Army">Brazilian Army</a> (including the <a href="/wiki/Brazilian_Army_Aviation_Command" title="Brazilian Army Aviation Command">Army Aviation Command</a>), the <a href="/wiki/Brazilian_Navy" title="Brazilian Navy">Brazilian Navy</a> (including the <a href="/wiki/Brazilian_Marine_Corps" title="Brazilian Marine Corps">Marine Corps</a> and <a href="/wiki/Brazilian_Naval_Aviation" title="Brazilian Naval Aviation">Naval Aviation</a>), and the <a href="/wiki/Brazilian_Air_Force" title="Brazilian Air Force">Brazilian Air Force</a>. Brazil\'s <a href="/wiki/Conscription" title="Conscription">conscription</a> policy gives it one of the world\'s largest military forces, estimated at more than 1.6&#160;million <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Military_Reserve" title="Military Reserve">reservists</a> annually.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-208"><a href="#cite_note-208">[207]</a></sup>\n</p><p>Numbering close to 236,000 active personnel,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-209"><a href="#cite_note-209">[208]</a></sup> the Brazilian Army has the largest number of armored vehicles in <a href="/wiki/South_America" title="South America">South America</a>, including armored transports and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Battle_tank" title="Battle tank">tanks</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-militarypower1_210-0"><a href="#cite_note-militarypower1-210">[209]</a></sup> It is also unique in Latin America for its large, elite forces specializing in unconventional missions, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Brazilian_Special_Operations_Command" title="Brazilian Special Operations Command">Brazilian Special Operations Command</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-211"><a href="#cite_note-211">[210]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-212"><a href="#cite_note-212">[211]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-213"><a href="#cite_note-213">[212]</a></sup> and the versatile Strategic Rapid Action Force, made up of highly mobilized and prepared Special Operations Brigade, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Parachute_Infantry_Brigade_(Brazil)" title="Parachute Infantry Brigade (Brazil)">Infantry Brigade Parachutist</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-214"><a href="#cite_note-214">[213]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-215"><a href="#cite_note-215">[214]</a></sup> 1st Jungle Infantry Battalion (Airmobile)<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-216"><a href="#cite_note-216">[215]</a></sup> and 12th Brigade Light Infantry (Airmobile)<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-217"><a href="#cite_note-217">[216]</a></sup> able to act anywhere in the country, on short notice, to counter external aggression.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-218"><a href="#cite_note-218">[217]</a></sup> The states\' <a href="/wiki/Military_Police_(Brazil)" title="Military Police (Brazil)">Military Police</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Military_Firefighters_Corps" title="Military Firefighters Corps">Military Firefighters Corps</a> are described as an ancillary forces of the Army by the constitution, but are under the control of each state\'s governor.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Constitui&#231;&#227;o_17-11"><a href="#cite_note-Constitui&#231;&#227;o-17">[16]</a></sup>\n</p><p>Brazil\'s navy, the second-largest in the Americas, once operated some of the most powerful warships in the world with the two <a href="/wiki/Minas_Geraes-class_battleship" title="Minas Geraes-class battleship"><i>Minas Geraes</i>-class</a> <a href="/wiki/Dreadnought" title="Dreadnought">dreadnoughts</a>, which sparked a <a href="/wiki/South_American_dreadnought_race" title="South American dreadnought race">South American dreadnought race</a> between Argentina, Brazil, and Chile.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-219"><a href="#cite_note-219">[218]</a></sup> Today, it is a <a href="/wiki/Green-water_navy" title="Green-water navy">green water</a> force and has a group of specialized elite in retaking ships and naval facilities, <a href="/wiki/GRUMEC" title="GRUMEC">GRUMEC</a>, unit specially trained to protect Brazilian oil platforms along its coast.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-220"><a href="#cite_note-220">[219]</a></sup> It\'s the only navy in Latin America that operates an <a href="/wiki/Aircraft_carrier" title="Aircraft carrier">aircraft carrier</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Brazilian_aircraft_carrier_S%C3%A3o_Paulo_(A12)" title="Brazilian aircraft carrier S&#227;o Paulo (A12)">NAe S&#227;o Paulo</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-221"><a href="#cite_note-221">[220]</a></sup> and one of the ten navies of the world to operate one.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-militarypower1_210-1"><a href="#cite_note-militarypower1-210">[209]</a></sup>\n</p><p>The Air Force is the largest in Latin America and has about 700 manned aircraft in service and effective about 67,000 personnel.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-222"><a href="#cite_note-222">[221]</a></sup>\n</p><p>Brazil has not been invaded since 1865 during the <a href="/wiki/Paraguayan_War" title="Paraguayan War">Paraguayan War</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-223"><a href="#cite_note-223">[222]</a></sup> Additionally, Brazil has no contested territorial disputes with any of its neighbours<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-224"><a href="#cite_note-224">[223]</a></sup> and neither does it have rivalries, like Chile and Bolivia have with each other.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-225"><a href="#cite_note-225">[224]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-226"><a href="#cite_note-226">[225]</a></sup> The Brazilian military has also three times intervened militarily to overthrow the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Government_of_Brazil" title="Government of Brazil">Brazilian government</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-revistaepoca.globo.com_227-0"><a href="#cite_note-revistaepoca.globo.com-227">[226]</a></sup> It has built a tradition of participating in UN <a href="/wiki/Peacekeeping" title="Peacekeeping">peacekeeping</a> missions such as in <a href="/wiki/Haiti" title="Haiti">Haiti</a>, <a href="/wiki/East_Timor" title="East Timor">East Timor</a> and <a href="/wiki/Central_African_Republic" title="Central African Republic">Central African Republic</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-228"><a href="#cite_note-228">[227]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-229"><a href="#cite_note-229">[228]</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Foreign_policy">Foreign policy</span></h3>\n<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Foreign_relations_of_Brazil" title="Foreign relations of Brazil">Foreign relations of Brazil</a></div>\n<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Brasilia-2.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2724" data-file-width="4101" decoding="async" height="146" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ac/Brasilia-2.jpg/220px-Brasilia-2.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ac/Brasilia-2.jpg/330px-Brasilia-2.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ac/Brasilia-2.jpg/440px-Brasilia-2.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Brasilia-2.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Itamaraty_Palace" title="Itamaraty Palace">Itamaraty Palace</a>, the seat of the <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Foreign_Affairs_(Brazil)" title="Ministry of Foreign Affairs (Brazil)">Ministry of Foreign Affairs</a></div></div></div>\n<p>Brazil\'s international relations are based on Article 4 of the <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_Brazil" title="Constitution of Brazil">Federal Constitution</a>, which establishes <a href="/wiki/Non-interventionism" title="Non-interventionism">non-intervention</a>, <a href="/wiki/Self-determination" title="Self-determination">self-determination</a>, <a href="/wiki/Internationalism_(politics)" title="Internationalism (politics)">international cooperation</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Peacebuilding" title="Peacebuilding">peaceful settlement of conflicts</a> as the guiding principles of Brazil\'s relationship with other countries and multilateral organizations.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-230"><a href="#cite_note-230">[229]</a></sup>\n</p><p>According to the Constitution, the <a href="/wiki/President_of_Brazil" title="President of Brazil">President</a> has ultimate authority over foreign policy, while the <a href="/wiki/National_Congress_of_Brazil" title="National Congress of Brazil">Congress</a> is tasked with reviewing and considering all diplomatic nominations and <a href="/wiki/Treaty" title="Treaty">international treaties</a>, as well as legislation relating to Brazilian foreign policy.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-231"><a href="#cite_note-231">[230]</a></sup>\n</p><p>Brazil\'s foreign policy is a by-product of the country\'s unique position as a <a href="/wiki/Regional_power" title="Regional power">regional power</a> in <a href="/wiki/Latin_America" title="Latin America">Latin America</a>, a leader among <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Developing_countries" title="Developing countries">developing countries</a>, and an emerging <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/World_power" title="World power">world power</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-232"><a href="#cite_note-232">[231]</a></sup> Brazilian foreign policy has generally been based on the principles of <a href="/wiki/Multilateralism" title="Multilateralism">multilateralism</a>, peaceful dispute settlement, and non-intervention in the affairs of other countries.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-233"><a href="#cite_note-233">[232]</a></sup>\n</p><p>An increasingly well-developed tool of Brazil\'s foreign policy is providing aid as a donor to other developing countries.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ODI1_234-0"><a href="#cite_note-ODI1-234">[233]</a></sup> Brazil does not just use its growing economic strength to provide financial aid, but it also provides high levels of expertise and most importantly of all, a quiet non-confrontational diplomacy to improve governance levels.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ODI1_234-1"><a href="#cite_note-ODI1-234">[233]</a></sup> Total aid is estimated to be around $1&#160;billion per year that includes:<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ODI1_234-2"><a href="#cite_note-ODI1-234">[233]</a></sup>\n</p>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:332px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Diplomatic_missions_in_Brazil.PNG"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="625" data-file-width="1425" decoding="async" height="145" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ac/Diplomatic_missions_in_Brazil.PNG/330px-Diplomatic_missions_in_Brazil.PNG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ac/Diplomatic_missions_in_Brazil.PNG/495px-Diplomatic_missions_in_Brazil.PNG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ac/Diplomatic_missions_in_Brazil.PNG/660px-Diplomatic_missions_in_Brazil.PNG 2x" width="330"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Diplomatic_missions_in_Brazil.PNG" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/List_of_diplomatic_missions_in_Brazil" title="List of diplomatic missions in Brazil">Diplomatic missions of Brazil</a></div></div></div>\n<ul><li>technical cooperation of around $480&#160;million ($30&#160;million in 2010 provided directly by the Brazilian Cooperation Agency (ABC))</li>\n<li>an estimated $450&#160;million for in-kind expertise provided by Brazilian institutions specialising in technical cooperation</li></ul>\n<p>In addition, Brazil manages a peacekeeping mission in <a href="/wiki/2010_Haiti_earthquake" title="2010 Haiti earthquake">Haiti</a> ($350&#160;million) and makes in-kind contributions to the <a href="/wiki/World_Food_Programme" title="World Food Programme">World Food Programme</a> ($300&#160;million).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ODI1_234-3"><a href="#cite_note-ODI1-234">[233]</a></sup> This is in addition to humanitarian assistance and contributions to multilateral development agencies. The scale of this aid places it on par with China and India.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ODI1_234-4"><a href="#cite_note-ODI1-234">[233]</a></sup> The Brazilian South-South aid has been described as a "global model in waiting."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-235"><a href="#cite_note-235">[234]</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Law_enforcement_and_crime">Law enforcement and crime</span></h3>\n<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Law_enforcement_in_Brazil" title="Law enforcement in Brazil">Law enforcement in Brazil</a> and <a href="/wiki/Crime_in_Brazil" title="Crime in Brazil">Crime in Brazil</a></div>\n<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:FNSP_(7952500358).jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2391" data-file-width="3467" decoding="async" height="152" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/15/FNSP_%287952500358%29.jpg/220px-FNSP_%287952500358%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/15/FNSP_%287952500358%29.jpg/330px-FNSP_%287952500358%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/15/FNSP_%287952500358%29.jpg/440px-FNSP_%287952500358%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:FNSP_(7952500358).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Car of the <a href="/wiki/National_Public_Security_Force" title="National Public Security Force">National Public Security Force</a></div></div></div>\n<p>In Brazil, the <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_Brazil" title="Constitution of Brazil">Constitution</a> establishes five different police agencies for law enforcement: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Federal_Police_Department" title="Federal Police Department">Federal Police Department</a>, <a href="/wiki/Federal_Highway_Police_(Brazil)" title="Federal Highway Police (Brazil)">Federal Highway Police</a>, <a href="/wiki/Federal_Railroad_Police" title="Federal Railroad Police">Federal Railroad Police</a>, <a href="/wiki/Military_Police_(Brazil)" title="Military Police (Brazil)">Military Police</a> and <a href="/wiki/Civil_Police_(Brazil)" title="Civil Police (Brazil)">Civil Police</a>. Of these, the first three are affiliated with federal authorities and the last two are subordinate to state governments. All police forces are the responsibility of the executive branch of any of the federal or state powers.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Constitui&#231;&#227;o_17-12"><a href="#cite_note-Constitui&#231;&#227;o-17">[16]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/National_Public_Security_Force" title="National Public Security Force">National Public Security Force</a> also can act in public disorder situations arising anywhere in the country.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-236"><a href="#cite_note-236">[235]</a></sup>\n</p><p>The country still has above-average levels of violent crime and particularly high levels of gun violence and homicide. In 2012, the <a href="/wiki/World_Health_Organization" title="World Health Organization">World Health Organization</a> (WHO) estimated the number of 32 deaths per 100,000 inhabitants, one of the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_intentional_homicide_rate" title="List of countries by intentional homicide rate">highest rates of homicide of the world</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-237"><a href="#cite_note-237">[236]</a></sup> The number considered tolerable by the WHO is about 10 homicides per 100,000 inhabitants.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-238"><a href="#cite_note-238">[237]</a></sup> However, there are differences between the crime rates in the <a href="/wiki/States_of_Brazil" title="States of Brazil">Brazilian states</a>. While in <a href="/wiki/S%C3%A3o_Paulo_(state)" title="S&#227;o Paulo (state)">S&#227;o Paulo</a> the homicide rate registered in 2013 was 10.8 deaths per 100,000 inhabitants, in <a href="/wiki/Alagoas" title="Alagoas">Alagoas</a> it was 64.7 homicides per 100,000 inhabitants.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-239"><a href="#cite_note-239">[238]</a></sup>\n</p><p>Brazil also has high levels of incarceration and the third largest prison population in the world (behind only <a href="/wiki/China" title="China">China</a> and the <a href="/wiki/United_States" title="United States">United States</a>), with an estimated total of approximately 700,000 prisoners around the country (June 2014), an increase of about 300% compared to the index registered in 1992.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-240"><a href="#cite_note-240">[239]</a></sup> The high number of prisoners eventually overloaded the Brazilian prison system, leading to a shortfall of about two hundred thousand accommodations.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-241"><a href="#cite_note-241">[240]</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Administrative_divisions">Administrative divisions</span></h3>\n<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/States_of_Brazil" title="States of Brazil">States of Brazil</a> and <a href="/wiki/Municipalities_of_Brazil" title="Municipalities of Brazil">Municipalities of Brazil</a></div>\n<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Regions_of_Brazil" title="Regions of Brazil">Regions of Brazil</a></div>\n<table class="infobox">\n<tbody><tr>\n<td><div class="noresize" role="img" style="width: 400px; font-size: 85%; line-height: 1; text-align: center; background-color: #ffffff; position: relative;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Brazil_Labelled_Map.svg"><img alt="" data-file-height="687" data-file-width="780" decoding="async" height="352" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f6/Brazil_Labelled_Map.svg/400px-Brazil_Labelled_Map.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f6/Brazil_Labelled_Map.svg/600px-Brazil_Labelled_Map.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f6/Brazil_Labelled_Map.svg/800px-Brazil_Labelled_Map.svg.png 2x" width="400"/></a>\n<div style="position:absolute; left:330px; top:28px"><a href="/wiki/Atlantic_Ocean" title="Atlantic Ocean"><i style="color: #333366;">Atlantic<br/>Ocean</i></a></div>\n<div style="position:absolute; left:10px; top:272px"><a href="/wiki/Pacific_Ocean" title="Pacific Ocean"><i style="color: #333366;">Pacific<br/>Ocean</i></a></div>\n<div style="position:absolute; left:102px; top:24px"><a href="/wiki/Roraima" title="Roraima">Roraima</a></div>\n<div style="position:absolute; left:186px; top:30px"><a href="/wiki/Amap%C3%A1" title="Amap&#225;">Amap&#225;</a></div>\n<div style="position:absolute; left:90px; top:148px"><a href="/wiki/Rond%C3%B4nia" title="Rond&#244;nia">Rond&#244;nia</a></div>\n<div style="position:absolute; left:212px; top:136px"><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Tocantins_(state)" title="Tocantins (state)">Tocantins</a></div>\n<div style="position:absolute; left:238px; top:92px"><a href="/wiki/Maranh%C3%A3o" title="Maranh&#227;o">Maranh&#227;o</a></div>\n<div style="position:absolute; left:274px; top:152px"><a href="/wiki/Bahia" title="Bahia">Bahia</a></div>\n<div style="position:absolute; left:274px; top:112px"><a href="/wiki/Piau%C3%AD" title="Piau&#237;">Piau&#237;</a></div>\n<div style="position:absolute; left:294px; top:84px"><a href="/wiki/Cear%C3%A1" title="Cear&#225;">Cear&#225;</a></div>\n<div style="position:absolute; left:330px; top:84px"><a href="/wiki/Rio_Grande_do_Norte" title="Rio Grande do Norte">Rio Grande<br/>do Norte</a></div>\n<div style="position:absolute; left:334px; top:108px"><a href="/wiki/Para%C3%ADba" title="Para&#237;ba">Para&#237;ba</a></div>\n<div style="position:absolute; left:302px; top:120px"><a href="/wiki/Pernambuco" title="Pernambuco">Pernambuco</a></div>\n<div style="position:absolute; left:334px; top:132px"><a href="/wiki/Alagoas" title="Alagoas">Alagoas</a></div>\n<div style="position:absolute; left:322px; top:144px"><a href="/wiki/Sergipe" title="Sergipe">Sergipe</a></div>\n<div style="position:absolute; left:146px; top:164px"><a href="/wiki/Mato_Grosso" title="Mato Grosso">Mato Grosso</a></div>\n<div style="position:absolute; left:150px; top:224px"><a href="/wiki/Mato_Grosso_do_Sul" title="Mato Grosso do Sul">Mato Grosso<br/>do Sul</a></div>\n<div style="position:absolute; left:220px; top:172px"><a href="/wiki/Federal_District_(Brazil)" title="Federal District (Brazil)">Federal<br/>District</a></div>\n<div style="position:absolute; left:202px; top:196px"><a href="/wiki/Goi%C3%A1s" title="Goi&#225;s">Goi&#225;s</a></div>\n<div style="position:absolute; left:234px; top:216px"><a href="/wiki/Minas_Gerais" title="Minas Gerais">Minas Gerais</a></div>\n<div style="position:absolute; left:202px; top:240px"><a href="/wiki/S%C3%A3o_Paulo_(state)" title="S&#227;o Paulo (state)">S&#227;o Paulo</a></div>\n<div style="position:absolute; left:274px; top:244px"><a href="/wiki/Rio_de_Janeiro_(state)" title="Rio de Janeiro (state)">Rio de Janeiro</a></div>\n<div style="position:absolute; left:294px; top:224px"><a href="/wiki/Esp%C3%ADrito_Santo" title="Esp&#237;rito Santo">Esp&#237;rito Santo</a></div>\n<div style="position:absolute; left:186px; top:264px"><a href="/wiki/Paran%C3%A1_(state)" title="Paran&#225; (state)">Paran&#225;</a></div>\n<div style="position:absolute; left:198px; top:284px"><a href="/wiki/Santa_Catarina_(state)" title="Santa Catarina (state)">Santa Catarina</a></div>\n<div style="position:absolute; left:166px; top:304px"><a href="/wiki/Rio_Grande_do_Sul" title="Rio Grande do Sul">Rio Grande<br/>do Sul</a></div>\n<div style="position:absolute; left:82px; top:312px"><i><a href="/wiki/Argentina" title="Argentina"><span style="color: #C0C0C0;">Argentina</span></a></i></div>\n<div style="position:absolute; left:82px; top:196px"><i><a href="/wiki/Bolivia" title="Bolivia"><span style="color: #C0C0C0;">Bolivia</span></a></i></div>\n<div style="position:absolute; left:50px; top:252px"><i><a href="/wiki/Chile" title="Chile"><span style="color: #C0C0C0;">Chile</span></a></i></div>\n<div style="position:absolute; left:14px; top:20px"><i><a href="/wiki/Colombia" title="Colombia"><span style="color: #C0C0C0;">Colombia</span></a></i></div>\n<div style="position:absolute; left:186px; top:4px"><i><a href="/wiki/French_Guiana" title="French Guiana"><span style="color: #C0C0C0;">French Guiana</span></a></i></div>\n<div style="position:absolute; left:134px; top:20px"><i><a href="/wiki/Guyana" title="Guyana"><span style="color: #C0C0C0;">Guyana</span></a></i></div>\n<div style="position:absolute; left:126px; top:248px"><i><a href="/wiki/Paraguay" title="Paraguay"><span style="color: #C0C0C0;">Paraguay</span></a></i></div>\n<div style="position:absolute; left:14px; top:164px"><i><a href="/wiki/Peru" title="Peru"><span style="color: #C0C0C0;">Peru</span></a></i></div>\n<div style="position:absolute; left:154px; top:12px"><i><a href="/wiki/Suriname" title="Suriname"><span style="color: #C0C0C0;">Suriname</span></a></i></div>\n<div style="position:absolute; left:152px; top:336px"><i><a href="/wiki/Uruguay" title="Uruguay"><span style="color: #C0C0C0;">Uruguay</span></a></i></div>\n<div style="position:absolute; left:74px; top:4px"><i><a href="/wiki/Venezuela" title="Venezuela"><span style="color: #C0C0C0;">Venezuela</span></a></i></div>\n</div><center><a href="/wiki/States_of_Brazil" title="States of Brazil">States of Brazil</a> and <a href="/wiki/Regions_of_Brazil" title="Regions of Brazil">Regions of Brazil</a></center>\n</td></tr></tbody></table>\n<p>Brazil is a federation composed of 26 <a href="/wiki/Federated_state" title="Federated state">states</a>, one <a href="/wiki/Federal_district" title="Federal district">federal district</a>, and the 5570 <a href="/wiki/Municipality" title="Municipality">municipalities</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Constitui&#231;&#227;o_17-13"><a href="#cite_note-Constitui&#231;&#227;o-17">[16]</a></sup> States have autonomous administrations, collect their own taxes and receive a share of taxes collected by the Federal government. They have a governor and a unicameral legislative body elected directly by their voters. They also have independent Courts of Law for common justice. Despite this, states have much less autonomy to create their own laws than in the United States. For example, criminal and civil laws can be voted by only the federal bicameral Congress and are uniform throughout the country.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Constitui&#231;&#227;o_17-14"><a href="#cite_note-Constitui&#231;&#227;o-17">[16]</a></sup>\n</p><p>The states and the federal district may be grouped into regions: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Northern_Region,_Brazil" title="Northern Region, Brazil">Northern</a>, <a href="/wiki/Northeast_Region,_Brazil" title="Northeast Region, Brazil">Northeast</a>, <a href="/wiki/Central-West_Region,_Brazil" title="Central-West Region, Brazil">Central-West</a>, <a href="/wiki/Southeast_Region,_Brazil" title="Southeast Region, Brazil">Southeast</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Southern_Region,_Brazil" title="Southern Region, Brazil">Southern</a>. The Brazilian regions are merely geographical, not political or administrative divisions, and they do not have any specific form of government. Although defined by law, Brazilian regions are useful mainly for statistical purposes, and also to define the distribution of federal funds in development projects.\n</p><p>Municipalities, as the states, have autonomous administrations, collect their own taxes and receive a share of taxes collected by the Union and state government.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Constitui&#231;&#227;o_17-15"><a href="#cite_note-Constitui&#231;&#227;o-17">[16]</a></sup> Each has a mayor and an elected legislative body, but no separate Court of Law. Indeed, a Court of Law organized by the state can encompass many municipalities in a single justice administrative division called <i><a href="/wiki/Comarca" title="Comarca">comarca</a></i> (county).\n</p>\n<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Economy">Economy</span></h2>\n<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Economy_of_Brazil" title="Economy of Brazil">Economy of Brazil</a></div>\n<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Brazilian_real" title="Brazilian real">Brazilian real</a>, <a href="/wiki/Agriculture_in_Brazil" title="Agriculture in Brazil">Agriculture in Brazil</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mining_in_Brazil" title="Mining in Brazil">Mining in Brazil</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Industry_in_Brazil" title="Industry in Brazil">Industry in Brazil</a></div>\n<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r856303569" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="thumb tmulti tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:503px;max-width:503px"><div class="tsingle" style="float:left;margin:1px;width:277px;max-width:277px"><div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Sao_Paulo_Stock_Exchange.jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="1918" data-file-width="3612" decoding="async" height="146" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b8/Sao_Paulo_Stock_Exchange.jpg/275px-Sao_Paulo_Stock_Exchange.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b8/Sao_Paulo_Stock_Exchange.jpg/413px-Sao_Paulo_Stock_Exchange.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b8/Sao_Paulo_Stock_Exchange.jpg/550px-Sao_Paulo_Stock_Exchange.jpg 2x" width="275"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left">Quotes panel of <a href="/wiki/B3_(stock_exchange)" title="B3 (stock exchange)">B3</a>, in <a href="/wiki/S%C3%A3o_Paulo" title="S&#227;o Paulo">S&#227;o Paulo</a>, one of the <a href="/wiki/List_of_stock_exchanges" title="List of stock exchanges">top 20 stock exchanges by market capitalization</a>.</div></div><div class="tsingle" style="float:left;margin:1px;width:222px;max-width:222px"><div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Avenida_Paulista_no_p%C3%B4r_do_sol.jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="3990" data-file-width="5984" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f6/Avenida_Paulista_no_p%C3%B4r_do_sol.jpg/220px-Avenida_Paulista_no_p%C3%B4r_do_sol.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f6/Avenida_Paulista_no_p%C3%B4r_do_sol.jpg/330px-Avenida_Paulista_no_p%C3%B4r_do_sol.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f6/Avenida_Paulista_no_p%C3%B4r_do_sol.jpg/440px-Avenida_Paulista_no_p%C3%B4r_do_sol.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left"><a href="/wiki/S%C3%A3o_Paulo" title="S&#227;o Paulo">S&#227;o Paulo</a>, the country\'s main <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Financial_center" title="Financial center">financial center</a>, and the largest in Latin America</div></div><div style="clear:left"></div></div></div>\n<p>Brazil is the largest national economy in <a href="/wiki/Latin_America" title="Latin America">Latin America</a>, the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_(nominal)" title="List of countries by GDP (nominal)">world\'s eighth largest economy</a> and the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_(PPP)" title="List of countries by GDP (PPP)">eighth largest</a> in <a href="/wiki/Purchasing_power_parity" title="Purchasing power parity">purchasing power parity</a> (PPP) according to the 2017 estimates. Brazil has a <a href="/wiki/Mixed_economy" title="Mixed economy">mixed economy</a> with abundant natural resources. After rapid growth in preceding decades, the country <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/2014%E2%80%932016_Brazilian_economic_recession" title="2014&#8211;2016 Brazilian economic recession">entered an ongoing recession in 2014</a> amid a political corruption scandal and nationwide protests.\n</p><p>Its GDP (PPP) per capita was $15,919 in 2017<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-imf_242-0"><a href="#cite_note-imf-242">[241]</a></sup> putting Brazil in the 77th position according to IMF data. Active in <a href="/wiki/Agriculture" title="Agriculture">agricultural</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mining" title="Mining">mining</a>, <a href="/wiki/Manufacturing" title="Manufacturing">manufacturing</a> and <a href="/wiki/Tertiary_sector_of_the_economy" title="Tertiary sector of the economy">service sectors</a> Brazil has a labor force of over 107 million (ranking 6th worldwide) and unemployment of 6.2% (ranking 64th worldwide).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CIA_Econ_243-0"><a href="#cite_note-CIA_Econ-243">[242]</a></sup>\n</p><p>The country has been expanding its presence in international financial and <a href="/wiki/Commodity_market" title="Commodity market">commodities markets</a>, and is one of a group of four emerging economies called the <a href="/wiki/BRIC" title="BRIC">BRIC countries</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-244"><a href="#cite_note-244">[243]</a></sup> Brazil has been the world\'s largest <a href="/wiki/Coffee_production_in_Brazil" title="Coffee production in Brazil">producer of coffee</a> for the last 150 years.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Neilson102_22-1"><a href="#cite_note-Neilson102-22">[21]</a></sup>\n</p>\n<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r856303569" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="thumb tmulti tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:224px;max-width:224px"><div class="tsingle" style="margin:1px;width:222px;max-width:222px"><div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Arroz_097.jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="1456" data-file-width="2592" decoding="async" height="124" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4a/Arroz_097.jpg/220px-Arroz_097.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4a/Arroz_097.jpg/330px-Arroz_097.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4a/Arroz_097.jpg/440px-Arroz_097.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left">Rice plantation in <a href="/wiki/Rio_do_Sul" title="Rio do Sul">Rio do Sul</a>, <a href="/wiki/Santa_Catarina_(state)" title="Santa Catarina (state)">Santa Catarina</a>. Brazil is the second largest agricultural exporter in the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-exporta&#231;&#227;oagr&#237;cola_245-0"><a
