href="#cite_note-exporta&#231;&#227;oagr&#237;cola-245">[244]</a></sup></div></div><div class="tsingle" style="margin:1px;width:222px;max-width:222px"><div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:EGLF_-_Embraer_KC-390_-_For%C3%A7a_A%C3%A9rea_Brasileira_-_PT-ZNJ_(43532779431).jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="3285" data-file-width="4891" decoding="async" height="148" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5b/EGLF_-_Embraer_KC-390_-_For%C3%A7a_A%C3%A9rea_Brasileira_-_PT-ZNJ_%2843532779431%29.jpg/220px-EGLF_-_Embraer_KC-390_-_For%C3%A7a_A%C3%A9rea_Brasileira_-_PT-ZNJ_%2843532779431%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5b/EGLF_-_Embraer_KC-390_-_For%C3%A7a_A%C3%A9rea_Brasileira_-_PT-ZNJ_%2843532779431%29.jpg/330px-EGLF_-_Embraer_KC-390_-_For%C3%A7a_A%C3%A9rea_Brasileira_-_PT-ZNJ_%2843532779431%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5b/EGLF_-_Embraer_KC-390_-_For%C3%A7a_A%C3%A9rea_Brasileira_-_PT-ZNJ_%2843532779431%29.jpg/440px-EGLF_-_Embraer_KC-390_-_For%C3%A7a_A%C3%A9rea_Brasileira_-_PT-ZNJ_%2843532779431%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left">The <a href="/wiki/Embraer_KC-390" title="Embraer KC-390">KC-390</a>, developed by <a href="/wiki/Embraer" title="Embraer">Embraer</a>, the third largest producer of civil aircraft in the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-246"><a href="#cite_note-246">[245]</a></sup></div></div><div class="tsingle" style="margin:1px;width:222px;max-width:222px"><div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Oil_platform_P-51_(Brazil).jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="1772" data-file-width="2657" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ab/Oil_platform_P-51_%28Brazil%29.jpg/220px-Oil_platform_P-51_%28Brazil%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ab/Oil_platform_P-51_%28Brazil%29.jpg/330px-Oil_platform_P-51_%28Brazil%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ab/Oil_platform_P-51_%28Brazil%29.jpg/440px-Oil_platform_P-51_%28Brazil%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left">P-51, an <a href="/wiki/Oil_platform" title="Oil platform">oil platform</a> of <a href="/wiki/Petrobras" title="Petrobras">Petrobras</a></div></div><div class="tsingle" style="margin:1px;width:222px;max-width:222px"><div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Vista_Aerea_Itaipu.jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="1770" data-file-width="2592" decoding="async" height="150" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f4/Vista_Aerea_Itaipu.jpg/220px-Vista_Aerea_Itaipu.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f4/Vista_Aerea_Itaipu.jpg/330px-Vista_Aerea_Itaipu.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f4/Vista_Aerea_Itaipu.jpg/440px-Vista_Aerea_Itaipu.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left">The <a href="/wiki/Itaipu_Dam" title="Itaipu Dam">Itaipu Dam</a> on the <a href="/wiki/Paran%C3%A1_River" title="Paran&#225; River">Paran&#225; River</a>, located on the border between Brazil and Paraguay, is the second largest of the world (the first is the <a href="/wiki/Three_Gorges_Dam" title="Three Gorges Dam">Three Gorges Dam</a>, in China). Approximately 75% of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Energy_policy_of_Brazil" title="Energy policy of Brazil">Brazilian energy matrix</a>, one of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Clean_energy" title="Clean energy">cleanest</a> in the world, comes from <a href="/wiki/Hydropower" title="Hydropower">hydropower</a>.</div></div></div></div>\n<p>Brazil\'s diversified economy includes agriculture, industry, and a wide range of services.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BansalPhatak2009_247-0"><a href="#cite_note-BansalPhatak2009-247">[246]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Agriculture_in_Brazil" title="Agriculture in Brazil">Agriculture</a> and allied sectors like <a href="/wiki/Forestry" title="Forestry">forestry</a>, <a href="/wiki/Logging" title="Logging">logging</a> and <a href="/wiki/Fishing" title="Fishing">fishing</a> accounted for 5.1% of the <a href="/wiki/Gross_domestic_product" title="Gross domestic product">gross domestic product</a> in 2007.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CIA_GDP_248-0"><a href="#cite_note-CIA_GDP-248">[247]</a></sup> Brazil is one of the <a href="/wiki/List_of_largest_producing_countries_of_agricultural_commodities" title="List of largest producing countries of agricultural commodities">largest producer</a> of oranges, coffee, sugar cane, cassava and sisal, soybeans and papayas.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Luck1998_249-0"><a href="#cite_note-Luck1998-249">[248]</a></sup>\n</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Industry_in_Brazil" title="Industry in Brazil">industry</a> &#8211; from <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Automobile" title="Automobile">automobiles</a>, <a href="/wiki/Steel" title="Steel">steel</a> and <a href="/wiki/Petrochemical" title="Petrochemical">petrochemicals</a> to <a href="/wiki/Computer" title="Computer">computers</a>, <a href="/wiki/Aircraft" title="Aircraft">aircraft</a> and <a href="/wiki/Durable_good" title="Durable good">consumer durables</a> &#8211; accounted for 30.8% of the gross domestic product.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CIA_GDP_248-1"><a href="#cite_note-CIA_GDP-248">[247]</a></sup> Industry is highly concentrated in metropolitan S&#227;o Paulo, Rio de Janeiro, <a href="/wiki/Campinas" title="Campinas">Campinas</a>, <a href="/wiki/Porto_Alegre" title="Porto Alegre">Porto Alegre</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Belo_Horizonte" title="Belo Horizonte">Belo Horizonte</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-GiordanoLanzafame2005_250-0"><a href="#cite_note-GiordanoLanzafame2005-250">[249]</a></sup> Brazil has become the fourth largest car market in the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-251"><a href="#cite_note-251">[250]</a></sup> Major export products include <a href="/wiki/Fixed-wing_aircraft" title="Fixed-wing aircraft">aircraft</a>, <a href="/wiki/Electrical_equipment" title="Electrical equipment">electrical equipment</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Automobile" title="Automobile">automobiles</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ethanol_fuel" title="Ethanol fuel">ethanol</a>, <a href="/wiki/Textile" title="Textile">textiles</a>, <a href="/wiki/Footwear" title="Footwear">footwear</a>, <a href="/wiki/Iron_ore" title="Iron ore">iron ore</a>, <a href="/wiki/Steel" title="Steel">steel</a>, <a href="/wiki/Coffee" title="Coffee">coffee</a>, <a href="/wiki/Orange_juice" title="Orange juice">orange juice</a>, <a href="/wiki/Soybean" title="Soybean">soybeans</a> and <a href="/wiki/Corned_beef" title="Corned beef">corned beef</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-252"><a href="#cite_note-252">[251]</a></sup> In total, Brazil ranks 23rd worldwide in <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_exports" title="List of countries by exports">value of exports</a>.\n</p><p>Brazil pegged its currency, the <a href="/wiki/Brazilian_real" title="Brazilian real">real</a>, to the U.S. dollar in 1994. However, after the <a href="/wiki/1997_Asian_financial_crisis" title="1997 Asian financial crisis">East Asian financial crisis</a>, the <a href="/wiki/1998_Russian_financial_crisis" title="1998 Russian financial crisis">Russian default</a> in 1998<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-253"><a href="#cite_note-253">[252]</a></sup> and the series of adverse financial events that followed it, the <a href="/wiki/Central_Bank_of_Brazil" title="Central Bank of Brazil">Central Bank of Brazil</a> temporarily changed its <a href="/wiki/Monetary_policy" title="Monetary policy">monetary policy</a> to a managed-float<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-254"><a href="#cite_note-254">[253]</a></sup> scheme while undergoing a <a href="/wiki/Currency_crisis" title="Currency crisis">currency crisis</a>, until definitively changing the exchange regime to <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Free-float" title="Free-float">free-float</a> in January 1999.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-255"><a href="#cite_note-255">[254]</a></sup>\n</p><p>Brazil received an International Monetary Fund rescue package in mid-2002 of $30.4&#160;billion,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-256"><a href="#cite_note-256">[255]</a></sup> then a record sum. Brazil\'s central bank paid back the IMF loan in 2005, although it was not due to be repaid until 2006.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-257"><a href="#cite_note-257">[256]</a></sup> One of the issues the Central Bank of Brazil recently dealt with was an excess of speculative short-term capital inflows to the country, which may have contributed to a fall in the value of the U.S. dollar against the real during that period.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-258"><a href="#cite_note-258">[257]</a></sup> Nonetheless, <a href="/wiki/Foreign_direct_investment" title="Foreign direct investment">foreign direct investment</a> (FDI), related to long-term, less speculative investment in production, is estimated to be $193.8&#160;billion for 2007.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-259"><a href="#cite_note-259">[258]</a></sup> Inflation monitoring and control currently plays a major part in the Central bank\'s role of setting out short-term <a href="/wiki/Interest_rate" title="Interest rate">interest rates</a> as a monetary policy measure.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-260"><a href="#cite_note-260">[259]</a></sup>\n</p><p>Between 1993 and 2010, 7012 <a href="/wiki/Mergers_and_acquisitions" title="Mergers and acquisitions">mergers &amp; acquisitions</a> with a total known value of $707&#160;billion with the involvement of Brazilian firms have been announced.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-261"><a href="#cite_note-261">[260]</a></sup> The year 2010 was a new record in terms of value with US$115&#160;billion of transactions. The largest transaction with involvement of Brazilian companies has been: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Vale_(mining_company)" title="Vale (mining company)">Cia. Vale do Rio Doce</a> acquired <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Vale_Inco" title="Vale Inco">Inco</a> in a tender offer valued at US$18.9&#160;billion.\n</p><p>Corruption costs Brazil almost $41&#160;billion a year alone in 2010, with 69.9% of the country\'s firms identifying the issue as a major constraint in successfully penetrating the global market.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-262"><a href="#cite_note-262">[261]</a></sup> Local government corruption is so prevalent that voters perceive it as a problem only if it surpasses certain levels, and only if a local media e.g. a radio station is present to divulge the findings of corruption charges.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-263"><a href="#cite_note-263">[262]</a></sup> Initiatives, like this exposure, strengthen awareness which is indicated by the Transparency International\'s <a href="/wiki/Corruption_Perceptions_Index" title="Corruption Perceptions Index">Corruption Perceptions Index</a>; ranking Brazil 69th out of 178 countries in 2012.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-264"><a href="#cite_note-264">[263]</a></sup>\nThe <a href="/wiki/Purchasing_power" title="Purchasing power">purchasing power</a> in Brazil is eroded by the so-called <a href="/wiki/Brazil_cost" title="Brazil cost">Brazil cost</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-brcost_265-0"><a href="#cite_note-brcost-265">[264]</a></sup>\n</p><p>Brazil also has a large <a href="/wiki/Cooperative" title="Cooperative">cooperative</a> sector that provides 50% of the food in the country.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-266"><a href="#cite_note-266">[265]</a></sup> The worlds largest healthcare cooperative <a href="/wiki/Unimed_(organization)" title="Unimed (organization)">Unimed</a> is also located in Brazil, and accounts for 32% of the healthcare insurance market in the country.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-267"><a href="#cite_note-267">[266]</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Energy">Energy</span></h3>\n<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Energy_in_Brazil" title="Energy in Brazil">Energy in Brazil</a></div>\n<p>Brazil is the world\'s <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_total_primary_energy_consumption_and_production" title="List of countries by total primary energy consumption and production">tenth largest</a> energy consumer with much of its energy coming from <a href="/wiki/Renewable_energy" title="Renewable energy">renewable sources</a>, particularly <a href="/wiki/Hydroelectricity" title="Hydroelectricity">hydroelectricity</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ethanol" title="Ethanol">ethanol</a>; the <a href="/wiki/Itaipu_Dam" title="Itaipu Dam">Itaipu Dam</a> is the world\'s largest <a href="/wiki/Hydroelectricity" title="Hydroelectricity">hydroelectric plant</a> by energy generation.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-SchmidtOnyango2011_268-0"><a href="#cite_note-SchmidtOnyango2011-268">[267]</a></sup> The first car with an ethanol engine was produced in 1978 and the first airplane engine running on ethanol in 2005.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-OECDDevelopment2001_269-0"><a href="#cite_note-OECDDevelopment2001-269">[268]</a></sup>\n</p><p>Recent oil discoveries in the <a href="/wiki/Pre-salt_layer" title="Pre-salt layer">Pre-salt layer</a> have opened the door for a large increase in oil production.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BrainardMartinez-Diaz2009_270-0"><a href="#cite_note-BrainardMartinez-Diaz2009-270">[269]</a></sup> The governmental agencies responsible for the energy policy are the Ministry of Mines and Energy, the National Council for Energy Policy, the <a href="/wiki/National_Agency_of_Petroleum,_Natural_Gas_and_Biofuels_(Brazil)" title="National Agency of Petroleum, Natural Gas and Biofuels (Brazil)">National Agency of Petroleum, Natural Gas and Biofuels</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Brazilian_Electricity_Regulatory_Agency" title="Brazilian Electricity Regulatory Agency">National Agency of Electricity</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-OECD2005_271-0"><a href="#cite_note-OECD2005-271">[270]</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Tourism">Tourism</span></h3>\n<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Tourism_in_Brazil" title="Tourism in Brazil">Tourism in Brazil</a></div>\n<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r856303569" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="thumb tmulti tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:224px;max-width:224px"><div class="tsingle" style="margin:1px;width:222px;max-width:222px"><div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Fernando_de_Noronha_11.jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="3456" data-file-width="5184" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a6/Fernando_de_Noronha_11.jpg/220px-Fernando_de_Noronha_11.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a6/Fernando_de_Noronha_11.jpg/330px-Fernando_de_Noronha_11.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a6/Fernando_de_Noronha_11.jpg/440px-Fernando_de_Noronha_11.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left">Sancho Bay in <a href="/wiki/Fernando_de_Noronha" title="Fernando de Noronha">Fernando de Noronha Archipelago</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pernambuco" title="Pernambuco">Pernambuco</a>, voted the most beautiful beach in the world by <a href="/wiki/TripAdvisor" title="TripAdvisor">TripAdvisor</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-praias_272-0"><a href="#cite_note-praias-272">[271]</a></sup></div></div><div class="tsingle" style="margin:1px;width:222px;max-width:222px"><div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Abismo_Anhumas,_Bonito,_MS.JPG"><img alt="" data-file-height="2592" data-file-width="3888" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/34/Abismo_Anhumas%2C_Bonito%2C_MS.JPG/220px-Abismo_Anhumas%2C_Bonito%2C_MS.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/34/Abismo_Anhumas%2C_Bonito%2C_MS.JPG/330px-Abismo_Anhumas%2C_Bonito%2C_MS.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/34/Abismo_Anhumas%2C_Bonito%2C_MS.JPG/440px-Abismo_Anhumas%2C_Bonito%2C_MS.JPG 2x" width="220"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left"><a href="/wiki/Bonito,_Mato_Grosso_do_Sul" title="Bonito, Mato Grosso do Sul">Bonito</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mato_Grosso_do_Sul" title="Mato Grosso do Sul">Mato Grosso do Sul</a>. The rivers in the region are known for their <a href="/wiki/Crystal" title="Crystal">crystal</a> clear waters.</div></div></div></div>\n<p>Tourism in Brazil is a growing sector and key to the economy of several regions of the country. The country had 6.36&#160;million visitors in 2015, ranking in terms of the international tourist arrivals as the main destination in <a href="/wiki/South_America" title="South America">South America</a> and second in <a href="/wiki/Latin_America" title="Latin America">Latin America</a> after <a href="/wiki/Mexico" title="Mexico">Mexico</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-273"><a href="#cite_note-273">[272]</a></sup> Revenues from international tourists reached <span style="white-space: nowrap">US$6</span> billion in 2010, showing a recovery from the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Late-2000s_recession" title="Late-2000s recession">2008&#8211;2009 economic crisis</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-UNWTO2011_274-0"><a href="#cite_note-UNWTO2011-274">[273]</a></sup> Historical records of 5.4&#160;million visitors and <span style="white-space: nowrap">US$6.8</span> billion in receipts were reached in 2011.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-MT1_2011_275-0"><a href="#cite_note-MT1_2011-275">[274]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-MT2_2011_276-0"><a href="#cite_note-MT2_2011-276">[275]</a></sup>\n</p><p>Natural areas are its most popular tourism product, a combination of <a href="/wiki/Ecotourism" title="Ecotourism">ecotourism</a> with <a href="/wiki/Leisure" title="Leisure">leisure</a> and <a href="/wiki/Recreation" title="Recreation">recreation</a>, mainly sun and beach, and <a href="/wiki/Adventure_travel" title="Adventure travel">adventure travel</a>, as well as <a href="/wiki/Cultural_tourism" title="Cultural tourism">cultural tourism</a>. Among the most popular destinations are the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Amazon_Rainforest" title="Amazon Rainforest">Amazon Rainforest</a>, <a href="/wiki/Beach" title="Beach">beaches</a> and <a href="/wiki/Dune" title="Dune">dunes</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Northeast_Region,_Brazil" title="Northeast Region, Brazil">Northeast Region</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Pantanal" title="Pantanal">Pantanal</a> in the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Center-West_Region,_Brazil" title="Center-West Region, Brazil">Center-West Region</a>, beaches at <a href="/wiki/Rio_de_Janeiro_(state)" title="Rio de Janeiro (state)">Rio de Janeiro</a> and <a href="/wiki/Santa_Catarina_(state)" title="Santa Catarina (state)">Santa Catarina</a>, cultural tourism in <a href="/wiki/Minas_Gerais" title="Minas Gerais">Minas Gerais</a> and business trips to <a href="/wiki/S%C3%A3o_Paulo" title="S&#227;o Paulo">S&#227;o Paulo</a> city.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Palhares2012_277-0"><a href="#cite_note-Palhares2012-277">[276]</a></sup>\n</p><p>In terms of the 2015 <a href="/wiki/Travel_and_Tourism_Competitiveness_Report" title="Travel and Tourism Competitiveness Report">Travel and Tourism Competitiveness Index</a> (TTCI), which is a measurement of the factors that make it attractive to develop business in the travel and tourism industry of individual countries, Brazil ranked in the 28st place at the world\'s level, third in the <a href="/wiki/Americas" title="Americas">Americas</a>, after <a href="/wiki/Canada" title="Canada">Canada</a> and <a href="/wiki/United_States" title="United States">United States</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-278"><a href="#cite_note-278">[277]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-TTCI2013_279-0"><a href="#cite_note-TTCI2013-279">[278]</a></sup>\n</p><p>Brazil\'s main competitive advantages are its natural resources, which ranked 1st on this criteria out of all countries considered, and ranked 23rd for its cultural resources, due to its many <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/World_Heritage_site" title="World Heritage site">World Heritage sites</a>. The TTCI report notes Brazil\'s main weaknesses: its ground transport infrastructure remains underdeveloped (ranked 116th), with the quality of roads ranking in 105th place; and the country continues to suffer from a lack of price competitiveness (ranked 114th), due in part to high ticket taxes and airport charges, as well as high prices and high taxation. Safety and security have improved significantly: 75th in 2011, up from 128th in 2008.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-TTCI2013_279-1"><a href="#cite_note-TTCI2013-279">[278]</a></sup>\n</p><p>According to the <a href="/wiki/World_Tourism_Organization" title="World Tourism Organization">World Tourism Organization</a> (WTO), international travel to Brazil accelerated in 2000, particularly during 2004 and 2005. However, in 2006 a slow-down took place, and international arrivals had almost no growth in 2007&#8211;08.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-WTO2007_280-0"><a href="#cite_note-WTO2007-280">[279]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-EMBRATUR09_281-0"><a href="#cite_note-EMBRATUR09-281">[280]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-282"><a href="#cite_note-282">[281]</a></sup>\n</p><p>In spite of this trend, revenues from international tourism continued to rise, from <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/USD" title="USD">USD</a> 4&#160;billion in 2005 to 5&#160;billion in 2007, despite 330 000 fewer arrivals. This favorable trend is the result of the strong devaluation of the US dollar against the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Brazilian_Real" title="Brazilian Real">Brazilian Real</a>, which began in 2004, but which makes Brazil a more expensive international destination.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Boletim0207_283-0"><a href="#cite_note-Boletim0207-283">[282]</a></sup>\n</p>\n<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r856303569" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="thumb tmulti tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:224px;max-width:224px"><div class="tsingle" style="margin:1px;width:222px;max-width:222px"><div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Vista_do_Morro_Dona_Marta.jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="3571" data-file-width="5357" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fc/Vista_do_Morro_Dona_Marta.jpg/220px-Vista_do_Morro_Dona_Marta.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fc/Vista_do_Morro_Dona_Marta.jpg/330px-Vista_do_Morro_Dona_Marta.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fc/Vista_do_Morro_Dona_Marta.jpg/440px-Vista_do_Morro_Dona_Marta.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left">The city of <a href="/wiki/Rio_de_Janeiro" title="Rio de Janeiro">Rio de Janeiro</a> is featured in <a href="/wiki/Tourism" title="Tourism">tourism</a> in Brazil.</div></div><div class="tsingle" style="margin:1px;width:222px;max-width:222px"><div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Cataratas.jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="2644" data-file-width="3961" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b6/Cataratas.jpg/220px-Cataratas.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b6/Cataratas.jpg/330px-Cataratas.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b6/Cataratas.jpg/440px-Cataratas.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left"><a href="/wiki/Iguazu_Falls" title="Iguazu Falls">Iguazu Falls</a>, <a href="/wiki/Paran%C3%A1_(state)" title="Paran&#225; (state)">Paran&#225;</a>, in <a href="/wiki/Argentina%E2%80%93Brazil_relations" title="Argentina&#8211;Brazil relations">Brazil-Argentina border</a>. The Garganta do Diabo Walkway allow panoramic view of the falls from the Brazilian side.</div></div></div></div>\n<p>This trend changed in 2009, when both visitors and revenues fell as a result of the <a href="/wiki/Great_Recession" title="Great Recession">Great Recession</a> of 2008&#8211;09.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-WTO2010_284-0"><a href="#cite_note-WTO2010-284">[283]</a></sup> By 2010, the industry had recovered, and arrivals grew above 2006 levels to 5.2&#160;million international visitors, and receipts from these visitors reached US$6&#160;billion.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-UNWTO2011_274-1"><a href="#cite_note-UNWTO2011-274">[273]</a></sup> In 2011 the historical record was reached with 5.4&#160;million visitors and <span style="white-space: nowrap">US$6.8</span> billion in receipts.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-MT1_2011_275-1"><a href="#cite_note-MT1_2011-275">[274]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-MT2_2011_276-1"><a href="#cite_note-MT2_2011-276">[275]</a></sup>\n</p><p>Despite continuing record-breaking international tourism revenues, the number of Brazilian tourists travelling overseas has been growing steadily since 2003, resulting in a net negative <a href="/wiki/Foreign_exchange_market" title="Foreign exchange market">foreign exchange</a> balance, as more money is spent abroad by Brazilians than comes in as receipts from international tourists visiting Brazil.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Boletim0308_285-0"><a href="#cite_note-Boletim0308-285">[284]</a></sup>\n</p><p>Tourism expenditures abroad grew from US$5.8&#160;billion in 2006, to US$8.2&#160;billion in 2007, a 42% increase, representing a net deficit of US$3.3&#160;billion in 2007, as compared to US$1.5&#160;billion in 2006, a 125% increase from the previous year.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Boletim0308_285-1"><a href="#cite_note-Boletim0308-285">[284]</a></sup> This trend is caused by Brazilians taking advantage of the stronger <a href="/wiki/Brazilian_real" title="Brazilian real">Real</a> to travel and making relatively cheaper expenditures abroad.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Boletim0308_285-2"><a href="#cite_note-Boletim0308-285">[284]</a></sup> Brazilians traveling overseas in 2006 represented 4% of the country\'s population.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FIPE006_286-0"><a href="#cite_note-FIPE006-286">[285]</a></sup>\n</p><p>In 2005, tourism contributed with 3.2% of the country\'s revenues from exports of goods and services, and represented 7% of direct and indirect employment in the Brazilian economy.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BID2006_287-0"><a href="#cite_note-BID2006-287">[286]</a></sup> In 2006 direct employment in the sector reached 1.9&#160;million people.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-IPEA08_288-0"><a href="#cite_note-IPEA08-288">[287]</a></sup>\n</p><p>Domestic tourism is a fundamental market segment for the industry, as 51 million people traveled throughout the country in 2005,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FIPE007_289-0"><a href="#cite_note-FIPE007-289">[288]</a></sup> and direct revenues from Brazilian tourists reached US$22&#160;billion,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-290"><a href="#cite_note-290">[289]</a></sup> 5.6 times more receipts than international tourists in 2005.\n</p><p>In 2005, <a href="/wiki/Rio_de_Janeiro" title="Rio de Janeiro">Rio de Janeiro</a>, <a href="/wiki/Foz_do_Igua%C3%A7u" title="Foz do Igua&#231;u">Foz do Igua&#231;u</a>, <a href="/wiki/S%C3%A3o_Paulo" title="S&#227;o Paulo">S&#227;o Paulo</a>, <a href="/wiki/Florian%C3%B3polis" title="Florian&#243;polis">Florian&#243;polis</a> and <a href="/wiki/Salvador,_Bahia" title="Salvador, Bahia">Salvador</a> were the most visited cities by international tourists for leisure trips. The most popular destinations for business trips were <a href="/wiki/S%C3%A3o_Paulo" title="S&#227;o Paulo">S&#227;o Paulo</a>, <a href="/wiki/Rio_de_Janeiro" title="Rio de Janeiro">Rio de Janeiro</a> and <a href="/wiki/Porto_Alegre" title="Porto Alegre">Porto Alegre</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-EMBRATUR06_291-0"><a href="#cite_note-EMBRATUR06-291">[290]</a></sup> In 2006 Rio de Janeiro and <a href="/wiki/Fortaleza" title="Fortaleza">Fortaleza</a> were the most popular destinations for business trips.\n</p>\n<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Infrastructure">Infrastructure</span></h2>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Science_and_technology">Science and technology</span></h3>\n<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Science_and_technology_in_Brazil" title="Science and technology in Brazil">Science and technology in Brazil</a></div>\n<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r856303569" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="thumb tmulti tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:224px;max-width:224px"><div class="tsingle" style="margin:1px;width:222px;max-width:222px"><div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Vls1-mockup-test.jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="413" data-file-width="620" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f2/Vls1-mockup-test.jpg/220px-Vls1-mockup-test.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f2/Vls1-mockup-test.jpg/330px-Vls1-mockup-test.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f2/Vls1-mockup-test.jpg/440px-Vls1-mockup-test.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left"><a href="/wiki/VLS-1" title="VLS-1">VLS-1</a> at the <a href="/wiki/Alc%C3%A2ntara_Launch_Center" title="Alc&#226;ntara Launch Center">Alc&#226;ntara Launch Center</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Brazilian_Space_Agency" title="Brazilian Space Agency">Brazilian Space Agency</a>.</div></div><div class="tsingle" style="margin:1px;width:222px;max-width:222px"><div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Ministro_participa_da_inaugura%C3%A7%C3%A3o_do_acelerador_de_part%C3%ADculas_Sirius._(45909188621).jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="3840" data-file-width="5760" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3d/Ministro_participa_da_inaugura%C3%A7%C3%A3o_do_acelerador_de_part%C3%ADculas_Sirius._%2845909188621%29.jpg/220px-Ministro_participa_da_inaugura%C3%A7%C3%A3o_do_acelerador_de_part%C3%ADculas_Sirius._%2845909188621%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3d/Ministro_participa_da_inaugura%C3%A7%C3%A3o_do_acelerador_de_part%C3%ADculas_Sirius._%2845909188621%29.jpg/330px-Ministro_participa_da_inaugura%C3%A7%C3%A3o_do_acelerador_de_part%C3%ADculas_Sirius._%2845909188621%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3d/Ministro_participa_da_inaugura%C3%A7%C3%A3o_do_acelerador_de_part%C3%ADculas_Sirius._%2845909188621%29.jpg/440px-Ministro_participa_da_inaugura%C3%A7%C3%A3o_do_acelerador_de_part%C3%ADculas_Sirius._%2845909188621%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left"><a href="/wiki/Sirius_(synchrotron_light_source)" title="Sirius (synchrotron light source)">Sirius</a>, a <a href="/wiki/Diffraction-limited_storage_ring" title="Diffraction-limited storage ring">diffraction-limited storage ring</a> <a href="/wiki/Synchrotron_radiation" title="Synchrotron radiation">synchrotron light source</a> at the <a href="/wiki/Laborat%C3%B3rio_Nacional_de_Luz_S%C3%ADncrotron" title="Laborat&#243;rio Nacional de Luz S&#237;ncrotron">Laborat&#243;rio Nacional de Luz S&#237;ncrotron</a>, in the municipality of <a href="/wiki/Campinas" title="Campinas">Campinas</a>, <a href="/wiki/S%C3%A3o_Paulo_(state)" title="S&#227;o Paulo (state)">S&#227;o Paulo</a>.</div></div></div></div>\n<p>Technological research in Brazil is largely carried out in public universities and research institutes, with the majority of funding for basic research coming from various government agencies.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-DevelopmentStaff2006v_292-0"><a href="#cite_note-DevelopmentStaff2006v-292">[291]</a></sup> Brazil\'s most esteemed technological hubs are the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Funda%C3%A7%C3%A3o_Oswaldo_Cruz" title="Funda&#231;&#227;o Oswaldo Cruz">Oswaldo Cruz Institute</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Instituto_Butantan" title="Instituto Butantan">Butantan Institute</a>, the Air Force\'s <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Brazilian_General_Command_for_Aerospace_Technology" title="Brazilian General Command for Aerospace Technology">Aerospace Technical Center</a>, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Empresa_Brasileira_de_Pesquisa_Agropecu%C3%A1ria" title="Empresa Brasileira de Pesquisa Agropecu&#225;ria">Brazilian Agricultural Research Corporation</a> and the <a href="/wiki/National_Institute_for_Space_Research" title="National Institute for Space Research">INPE</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Scientific2010f_293-0"><a href="#cite_note-Scientific2010f-293">[292]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-HarveySmid2010_294-0"><a href="#cite_note-HarveySmid2010-294">[293]</a></sup>\n</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Brazilian_Space_Agency" title="Brazilian Space Agency">Brazilian Space Agency</a> has the most advanced space program in Latin America, with significant resources to launch vehicles, and manufacture of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Artificial_satellite" title="Artificial satellite">satellite</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECrocittiVallance2012[httpsbooksgooglecombooksidvP9jHaoL_s4CpgPA628_628]_295-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECrocittiVallance2012[httpsbooksgooglecombooksidvP9jHaoL_s4CpgPA628_628]-295">[294]</a></sup> Owner of relative technological sophistication, the country develops <a href="/wiki/Submarine" title="Submarine">submarines</a>, aircraft, as well as being involved in space research, having a Vehicle Launch Center Light and being the only country in the <a href="/wiki/Southern_Hemisphere" title="Southern Hemisphere">Southern Hemisphere</a> the integrate team building <a href="/wiki/International_Space_Station" title="International Space Station">International Space Station</a> (ISS).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NASA_296-0"><a href="#cite_note-NASA-296">[295]</a></sup>\n</p><p>The country is also a pioneer in the search for oil in deep water, from where it extracts 73% of its reserves.\n<a href="/wiki/Uranium" title="Uranium">Uranium</a> is enriched at the <a href="/wiki/Resende_Nuclear_Fuel_Factory" title="Resende Nuclear Fuel Factory">Resende Nuclear Fuel Factory</a>, mostly for research purposes (as Brazil obtains 88% from its electricity from <a href="/wiki/Hydroelectricity" title="Hydroelectricity">hydroelectricity</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-297"><a href="#cite_note-297">[296]</a></sup>) and the country\'s first nuclear submarine was delivered in 2015 (by France).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-298"><a href="#cite_note-298">[297]</a></sup>\n</p><p>Brazil is one of the three countries in Latin America<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-299"><a href="#cite_note-299">[298]</a></sup> with an operational <a href="/wiki/Synchrotron" title="Synchrotron">Synchrotron</a> Laboratory, a research facility on physics, chemistry, material science and life sciences, and Brazil is the only Latin American country to have a <a href="/wiki/Semiconductor" title="Semiconductor">semiconductor</a> company with its own <a href="/wiki/Semiconductor_fabrication_plant" title="Semiconductor fabrication plant">fabrication plant</a>, the <a href="/wiki/CEITEC" title="CEITEC">CEITEC</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-300"><a href="#cite_note-300">[299]</a></sup> According to the Global Information Technology Report 2009-2010 of the World Economic Forum, Brazil is the world\'s 61st largest developer of information technology.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-301"><a href="#cite_note-301">[300]</a></sup>\n</p><p>Brazil also has a large number of outstanding scientific personalities. Among the most renowned Brazilian inventors are priests <a href="/wiki/Bartolomeu_de_Gusm%C3%A3o" title="Bartolomeu de Gusm&#227;o">Bartolomeu de Gusm&#227;o</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Landell_de_Moura" title="Landell de Moura">Landell de Moura</a> and Francisco Jo&#227;o de Azevedo, besides <a href="/wiki/Alberto_Santos-Dumont" title="Alberto Santos-Dumont">Alberto Santos-Dumont</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-302"><a href="#cite_note-302">[301]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Evaristo_Conrado_Engelberg" title="Evaristo Conrado Engelberg">Evaristo Conrado Engelberg</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-patentbritish_303-0"><a href="#cite_note-patentbritish-303">[302]</a></sup> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Manuel_Dias_de_Abreu" title="Manuel Dias de Abreu">Manuel Dias de Abreu</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-304"><a href="#cite_note-304">[303]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Andreas_Pavel" title="Andreas Pavel">Andreas Pavel</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-305"><a href="#cite_note-305">[304]</a></sup> and N&#233;lio Jos&#233; Nicolai.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-306"><a href="#cite_note-306">[305]</a></sup>\n</p><p>Brazilian science is represented by the likes of <a href="/wiki/C%C3%A9sar_Lattes" title="C&#233;sar Lattes">C&#233;sar Lattes</a> (Brazilian <a href="/wiki/Physicist" title="Physicist">physicist</a> Pathfinder of <i><a href="/wiki/Pion" title="Pion">Pi Meson</a></i>),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Lattes_307-0"><a href="#cite_note-Lattes-307">[306]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/M%C3%A1rio_Schenberg" title="M&#225;rio Schenberg">M&#225;rio Schenberg</a> (considered the greatest theoretical physicist of Brazil),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-308"><a href="#cite_note-308">[307]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Jos%C3%A9_Leite_Lopes" title="Jos&#233; Leite Lopes">Jos&#233; Leite Lopes</a> (only Brazilian physicist holder of <i>UNESCO Science Prize</i>),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-309"><a href="#cite_note-309">[308]</a></sup> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Artur_%C3%81vila" title="Artur &#193;vila">Artur &#193;vila</a> (the first Latin American winner of <a href="/wiki/Fields_Medal" title="Fields Medal">Fields Medal</a>)<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-310"><a href="#cite_note-310">[309]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Fritz_M%C3%BCller" title="Fritz M&#252;ller">Fritz M&#252;ller</a> (pioneer in factual support of the theory of evolution by Charles Darwin).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-West,_David_A_2003_311-0"><a href="#cite_note-West,_David_A_2003-311">[310]</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Transport">Transport</span></h3>\n<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Transport_in_Brazil" title="Transport in Brazil">Transport in Brazil</a></div>\n<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r856303569" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="thumb tmulti tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:224px;max-width:224px"><div class="tsingle" style="margin:1px;width:222px;max-width:222px"><div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Saopaulo_aerea_aeroportocumbica.jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="2685" data-file-width="4000" decoding="async" height="148" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e7/Saopaulo_aerea_aeroportocumbica.jpg/220px-Saopaulo_aerea_aeroportocumbica.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e7/Saopaulo_aerea_aeroportocumbica.jpg/330px-Saopaulo_aerea_aeroportocumbica.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e7/Saopaulo_aerea_aeroportocumbica.jpg/440px-Saopaulo_aerea_aeroportocumbica.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left">Aerial view of the <a href="/wiki/S%C3%A3o_Paulo%E2%80%93Guarulhos_International_Airport" title="S&#227;o Paulo&#8211;Guarulhos International Airport">S&#227;o Paulo&#8211;Guarulhos International Airport</a>, the second <a href="/wiki/List_of_the_busiest_airports_in_Latin_America" title="List of the busiest airports in Latin America">busiest airport in Latin America</a>.</div></div><div class="tsingle" style="margin:1px;width:222px;max-width:222px"><div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Rodovia_Rio-Teres%C3%B3polis_(BR-116)_-_panoramio_(cropped).jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="1013" data-file-width="1716" decoding="async" height="130" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/41/Rodovia_Rio-Teres%C3%B3polis_%28BR-116%29_-_panoramio_%28cropped%29.jpg/220px-Rodovia_Rio-Teres%C3%B3polis_%28BR-116%29_-_panoramio_%28cropped%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/41/Rodovia_Rio-Teres%C3%B3polis_%28BR-116%29_-_panoramio_%28cropped%29.jpg/330px-Rodovia_Rio-Teres%C3%B3polis_%28BR-116%29_-_panoramio_%28cropped%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/41/Rodovia_Rio-Teres%C3%B3polis_%28BR-116%29_-_panoramio_%28cropped%29.jpg/440px-Rodovia_Rio-Teres%C3%B3polis_%28BR-116%29_-_panoramio_%28cropped%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left"><a href="/wiki/Rodovia_Presidente_Dutra" title="Rodovia Presidente Dutra">Presidente Dutra Highway</a> in <a href="/wiki/Guapimirim" title="Guapimirim">Guapimirim</a>, <a href="/wiki/Rio_de_Janeiro_(state)" title="Rio de Janeiro (state)">Rio de Janeiro</a>, part of the <a href="/wiki/BR-116" title="BR-116">BR-116</a>, the longest <a href="/wiki/Brazilian_Highway_System" title="Brazilian Highway System">highway</a> in the country, with 4,385&#160;km (2,725&#160;mi) of extension.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-312"><a href="#cite_note-312">[311]</a></sup></div></div><div class="tsingle" style="margin:1px;width:222px;max-width:222px"><div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Semin%C3%A1rio_da_TV_Tribuna_em_Santos._(42282761304).jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="2750" data-file-width="4000" decoding="async" height="151" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/ff/Semin%C3%A1rio_da_TV_Tribuna_em_Santos._%2842282761304%29.jpg/220px-Semin%C3%A1rio_da_TV_Tribuna_em_Santos._%2842282761304%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/ff/Semin%C3%A1rio_da_TV_Tribuna_em_Santos._%2842282761304%29.jpg/330px-Semin%C3%A1rio_da_TV_Tribuna_em_Santos._%2842282761304%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/ff/Semin%C3%A1rio_da_TV_Tribuna_em_Santos._%2842282761304%29.jpg/440px-Semin%C3%A1rio_da_TV_Tribuna_em_Santos._%2842282761304%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left"><a href="/wiki/Port_of_Santos" title="Port of Santos">Port of Santos</a>, the busiest port in <a href="/wiki/Latin_America" title="Latin America">Latin America</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-313"><a href="#cite_note-313">[312]</a></sup></div></div></div></div>\n<p>Brazilian roads are the primary carriers of freight and passenger traffic. The road system totaled 1.98&#160;million km (1.23&#160;million mi) in 2002. The total of paved roads increased from 35,496&#160;km (22,056&#160;mi) (22,056&#160;mi) in 1967 to 184,140&#160;km (114,419&#160;mi) (114,425&#160;mi) in 2002.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-314"><a href="#cite_note-314">[313]</a></sup>\n</p><p>The first investments in road infrastructure have given up in the 1920s, the government of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Washington_Luis" title="Washington Luis">Washington Luis</a>, being pursued in the governments of <a href="/wiki/Get%C3%BAlio_Vargas" title="Get&#250;lio Vargas">Get&#250;lio Vargas</a> and <a href="/wiki/Eurico_Gaspar_Dutra" title="Eurico Gaspar Dutra">Eurico Gaspar Dutra</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-315"><a href="#cite_note-315">[314]</a></sup> President <a href="/wiki/Juscelino_Kubitschek" title="Juscelino Kubitschek">Juscelino Kubitschek</a> (1956&#8211;61), who designed and built the capital <a href="/wiki/Bras%C3%ADlia" title="Bras&#237;lia">Bras&#237;lia</a>, was another supporter of highways. Kubitschek was responsible for the installation of major car manufacturers in the country (<a href="/wiki/Volkswagen" title="Volkswagen">Volkswagen</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ford_Motor_Company" title="Ford Motor Company">Ford</a> and <a href="/wiki/General_Motors" title="General Motors">General Motors</a> arrived in Brazil during his rule) and one of the points used to attract them was support for the construction of highways. With the implementation of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Fiat" title="Fiat">Fiat</a> in 1976 ending an automobile market closed loop, from the end of the 1990s the country has received large foreign direct investments installing in its territory other major car manufacturers and utilities, such as <a href="/wiki/Iveco" title="Iveco">Iveco</a>, <a href="/wiki/Renault" title="Renault">Renault</a>, <a href="/wiki/Peugeot" title="Peugeot">Peugeot</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Citroen" title="Citroen">Citroen</a>, <a href="/wiki/Honda" title="Honda">Honda</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mitsubishi" title="Mitsubishi">Mitsubishi</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mercedes-Benz" title="Mercedes-Benz">Mercedes-Benz</a>, <a href="/wiki/BMW" title="BMW">BMW</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hyundai" title="Hyundai">Hyundai</a>, <a href="/wiki/Toyota" title="Toyota">Toyota</a> among others.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-316"><a href="#cite_note-316">[315]</a></sup> Brazil is the seventh most important country in the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Auto_industry" title="Auto industry">auto industry</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-317"><a href="#cite_note-317">[316]</a></sup>\n</p><p>Brazil\'s <a href="/wiki/Rail_transport" title="Rail transport">railway</a> system has been declining since 1945, when emphasis shifted to <a href="/wiki/Highway" title="Highway">highway</a> construction. The total length of railway track was 30,875&#160;km (19,185&#160;mi) in 2002, as compared with 31,848&#160;km (19,789&#160;mi) in 1970. Most of the railway system belonged to the Federal Railroad Corporation RFFSA, which was privatized in 2007.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-318"><a href="#cite_note-318">[317]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/S%C3%A3o_Paulo_Metro" title="S&#227;o Paulo Metro">S&#227;o Paulo Metro</a> was the first underground transit system in Brazil. The other metro systems are in <a href="/wiki/Rio_de_Janeiro" title="Rio de Janeiro">Rio de Janeiro</a>, <a href="/wiki/Porto_Alegre" title="Porto Alegre">Porto Alegre</a>, <a href="/wiki/Recife" title="Recife">Recife</a>, <a href="/wiki/Belo_Horizonte" title="Belo Horizonte">Belo Horizonte</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bras%C3%ADlia" title="Bras&#237;lia">Bras&#237;lia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Teresina" title="Teresina">Teresina</a> and <a href="/wiki/Fortaleza" title="Fortaleza">Fortaleza</a>.\n</p><p>The country has an extensive rail network of 28,538 kilometres (17,733 miles) in length, the tenth largest network in the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-2012ciagini_319-0"><a href="#cite_note-2012ciagini-319">[318]</a></sup> Currently, the Brazilian government, unlike the past, seeks to encourage this mode of transport; an example of this incentive is the project of the <a href="/wiki/Rio%E2%80%93S%C3%A3o_Paulo_high-speed_rail" title="Rio&#8211;S&#227;o Paulo high-speed rail">Rio&#8211;S&#227;o Paulo high-speed rail</a>, that will connect the two main cities of the country to carry passengers.\n</p><p>There are about 2,500 <a href="/wiki/Airport" title="Airport">airports</a> in Brazil, including landing fields: the second largest number in the world, after the United States.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-320"><a href="#cite_note-320">[319]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/S%C3%A3o_Paulo%E2%80%93Guarulhos_International_Airport" title="S&#227;o Paulo&#8211;Guarulhos International Airport">S&#227;o Paulo&#8211;Guarulhos International Airport</a>, near S&#227;o Paulo, is the largest and busiest airport with nearly 20 million passengers annually, while handling the vast majority of commercial traffic for the country.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Palhares2012x_321-0"><a href="#cite_note-Palhares2012x-321">[320]</a></sup>\n</p><p>For freight transport <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Waterways" title="Waterways">waterways</a> are of importance, e.g. the <a href="/wiki/Free_Economic_Zone_of_Manaus" title="Free Economic Zone of Manaus">industrial zones of Manaus</a> can be reached only by means of the Solim&#245;es&#8211;Amazonas waterway (3,250 kilometres (2,020 miles) with 6 metres (20 feet) minimum depth). The country also has 50,000 kilometres (31,000 miles) of waterways.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-2012ciagini_319-1"><a href="#cite_note-2012ciagini-319">[318]</a></sup>\n</p><p>Coastal shipping links widely separated parts of the country. Bolivia and Paraguay have been given free <a href="/wiki/Port" title="Port">ports</a> at <a href="/wiki/Santos,_S%C3%A3o_Paulo" title="Santos, S&#227;o Paulo">Santos</a>. Of the 36 deep-water ports, Santos, Itaja&#237;, Rio Grande, Paranagu&#225;, Rio de Janeiro, Sepetiba, Vit&#243;ria, Suape, Manaus and S&#227;o Francisco do Sul are the most important.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-322"><a href="#cite_note-322">[321]</a></sup> Bulk carriers have to wait up to 18 days before being serviced, container ships 36,3 hours on average.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-323"><a href="#cite_note-323">[322]</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Health">Health</span></h3>\n<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Health_in_Brazil" title="Health in Brazil">Health in Brazil</a></div>\n<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Hospital_das_Cl%C3%ADnicas_(43616006911).jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="4160" data-file-width="6240" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/17/Hospital_das_Cl%C3%ADnicas_%2843616006911%29.jpg/220px-Hospital_das_Cl%C3%ADnicas_%2843616006911%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/17/Hospital_das_Cl%C3%ADnicas_%2843616006911%29.jpg/330px-Hospital_das_Cl%C3%ADnicas_%2843616006911%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/17/Hospital_das_Cl%C3%ADnicas_%2843616006911%29.jpg/440px-Hospital_das_Cl%C3%ADnicas_%2843616006911%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Hospital_das_Cl%C3%ADnicas_(43616006911).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Surgery center of the <a href="/wiki/Hospital_das_Cl%C3%ADnicas_da_Universidade_de_S%C3%A3o_Paulo" title="Hospital das Cl&#237;nicas da Universidade de S&#227;o Paulo">University of S&#227;o Paulo Clinics Hospital</a>, the largest hospital complex in Latin America.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-324"><a href="#cite_note-324">[323]</a></sup></div></div></div>\n<p>The Brazilian <a href="/wiki/Public_health" title="Public health">public health</a> system, the <a href="/wiki/Sistema_%C3%9Anico_de_Sa%C3%BAde" title="Sistema &#218;nico de Sa&#250;de">Unified Health System</a> (SUS), is managed and provided by all levels of government,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ForgiaCouttolenc2008_325-0"><a href="#cite_note-ForgiaCouttolenc2008-325">[324]</a></sup> being the largest system of this type in the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-326"><a href="#cite_note-326">[325]</a></sup> On the other hand, <a href="/wiki/Private_healthcare" title="Private healthcare">private healthcare</a> systems play a complementary role.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Wolper2004_327-0"><a href="#cite_note-Wolper2004-327">[326]</a></sup> Public health services are universal and offered to all citizens of the country for free. However, the construction and maintenance of health centers and hospitals are financed by taxes, and the country spends about 9% of its GDP on expenditures in the area. In 2012, Brazil had 1.85 doctors and 2.3 hospital beds for every 1,000 inhabitants.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-328"><a href="#cite_note-328">[327]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-329"><a href="#cite_note-329">[328]</a></sup>\n</p><p>Despite all the progress made since the creation of the <a href="/wiki/Universal_health_care" title="Universal health care">universal health care</a> system in 1988, there are still several public health problems in Brazil. In 2006, the main points to be solved were the high <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_infant_mortality_rate" title="List of countries by infant mortality rate">infant</a> (2.51%) and maternal mortality rates (73.1 deaths per 1000 births). The number of deaths from noncommunicable diseases, such as <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Cardiovascular_diseases" title="Cardiovascular diseases">cardiovascular diseases</a> (151.7 deaths per 100,000 inhabitants) and <a href="/wiki/Cancer" title="Cancer">cancer</a> (72.7 deaths per 100,000 inhabitants), also has a considerable impact on the health of the Brazilian population. Finally, external but preventable factors such as car accidents, violence and suicide caused 14.9% of all deaths in the country.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-330"><a href="#cite_note-330">[329]</a></sup> The Brazilian health system was ranked 125th among the 191 countries evaluated by the <a href="/wiki/World_Health_Organization" title="World Health Organization">World Health Organization</a> (WHO) in 2000.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-331"><a href="#cite_note-331">[330]</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Education">Education</span></h3>\n<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Education_in_Brazil" title="Education in Brazil">Education in Brazil</a></div>\n<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r856303569" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="thumb tmulti tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:224px;max-width:224px"><div class="tsingle" style="margin:1px;width:222px;max-width:222px"><div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Universidade_Federal_do_Parana_4_Curitiba_Parana.jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="1712" data-file-width="2288" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3d/Universidade_Federal_do_Parana_4_Curitiba_Parana.jpg/220px-Universidade_Federal_do_Parana_4_Curitiba_Parana.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3d/Universidade_Federal_do_Parana_4_Curitiba_Parana.jpg/330px-Universidade_Federal_do_Parana_4_Curitiba_Parana.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3d/Universidade_Federal_do_Parana_4_Curitiba_Parana.jpg/440px-Universidade_Federal_do_Parana_4_Curitiba_Parana.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left">Historical building of the <a href="/wiki/Federal_University_of_Paran%C3%A1" title="Federal University of Paran&#225;">Federal University of Paran&#225;</a>, one of the oldest universities in Brazil, located in <a href="/wiki/Curitiba" title="Curitiba">Curitiba</a></div></div><div class="tsingle" style="margin:1px;width:222px;max-width:222px"><div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Sala_de_aula_CB_Unicamp.jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="1200" data-file-width="1600" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0d/Sala_de_aula_CB_Unicamp.jpg/220px-Sala_de_aula_CB_Unicamp.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0d/Sala_de_aula_CB_Unicamp.jpg/330px-Sala_de_aula_CB_Unicamp.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0d/Sala_de_aula_CB_Unicamp.jpg/440px-Sala_de_aula_CB_Unicamp.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left">Classroom in the main campus of the <a href="/wiki/University_of_Campinas" title="University of Campinas">University of Campinas</a>, <a href="/wiki/S%C3%A3o_Paulo_(state)" title="S&#227;o Paulo (state)">S&#227;o Paulo</a></div></div></div></div>\n<p>The <a href="/wiki/Constitution" title="Constitution">Federal Constitution</a> and the Law of Guidelines and Bases of National Education determine that the <a href="/wiki/Federal_government_of_Brazil" title="Federal government of Brazil">Union</a>, the <a href="/wiki/States_of_Brazil" title="States of Brazil">states</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Federal_District_(Brazil)" title="Federal District (Brazil)">Federal District</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Municipalities_of_Brazil" title="Municipalities of Brazil">municipalities</a> must manage and organize their respective education systems. Each of these public educational systems is responsible for its own maintenance, which manages funds as well as the mechanisms and funding sources. The constitution reserves 25% of the state budget and 18% of federal taxes and municipal taxes for education.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Usa2005_332-0"><a href="#cite_note-Usa2005-332">[331]</a></sup>\n</p><p>According to the <a href="/wiki/Brazilian_Institute_of_Geography_and_Statistics" title="Brazilian Institute of Geography and Statistics">IBGE</a>, in 2011, the literacy rate of the population was 90.4%, meaning that 13 million (9.6% of population) people are still illiterate in the country; functional illiteracy has reached 21.6% of the population.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Agency2010_333-0"><a href="#cite_note-Agency2010-333">[332]</a></sup> Illiteracy is highest in the Northeast, where 19.9% of the population is illiterate.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Bank2001_334-0"><a href="#cite_note-Bank2001-334">[333]</a></sup>\n</p><p>Higher education starts with undergraduate or sequential <a href="/wiki/Course_(education)" title="Course (education)">courses</a>, which may offer different options of specialization in academic or professional careers. Depending on the choice, students can improve their educational background with courses of post-graduate studies or broad sense.\n</p><p>Attending an institution of higher education is required by Law of Guidelines and Bases of Education. <a href="/wiki/Kindergarten" title="Kindergarten">Kindergarten</a>, <a href="/wiki/Elementary_school" title="Elementary school">elementary</a> and medium educations are required of all students, provided the student does not hold any disability, whether physical, <a href="/wiki/Mind" title="Mind">mental</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Visual" title="Visual">visual</a> or <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hearing_(sense)" title="Hearing (sense)">hearing</a>.\n</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/University_of_S%C3%A3o_Paulo" title="University of S&#227;o Paulo">University of S&#227;o Paulo</a> is the second best <a href="/wiki/University" title="University">university</a> in <a href="/wiki/Latin_America" title="Latin America">Latin America</a>, according to recent 2019 <a href="/wiki/QS_World_University_Rankings" title="QS World University Rankings">QS World University Rankings</a>. Of the top 20 Latin Americans universities, eight are Brazilian. Most of them are <a href="/wiki/Public_university" title="Public university">public</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-335"><a href="#cite_note-335">[334]</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Media_and_communication">Media and communication<span id="Media"></span></span></h3>\n<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Telecommunications_in_Brazil" title="Telecommunications in Brazil">Telecommunications in Brazil</a></div>\n<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Concentration_of_media_ownership#Brazil" title="Concentration of media ownership">Concentration of media ownership &#167;&#160;Brazil</a></div>\n<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Jornal_Nacional_3.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="683" data-file-width="1024" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cc/Jornal_Nacional_3.jpg/220px-Jornal_Nacional_3.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cc/Jornal_Nacional_3.jpg/330px-Jornal_Nacional_3.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cc/Jornal_Nacional_3.jpg/440px-Jornal_Nacional_3.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Jornal_Nacional_3.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Former President <a href="/wiki/Dilma_Rousseff" title="Dilma Rousseff">Dilma Rousseff</a> at <i><a href="/wiki/Jornal_Nacional" title="Jornal Nacional">Jornal Nacional</a></i> news program. <a href="/wiki/Rede_Globo" title="Rede Globo">Rede Globo</a> is the second largest commercial television network of the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-336"><a href="#cite_note-336">[335]</a></sup></div></div></div>\n<p>The Brazilian press had its beginnings in 1808 with the arrival of the <a href="/wiki/House_of_Braganza#Realm_in_Brazil" title="House of Braganza">Portuguese royal family</a> to Brazil, hitherto forbidden any activity of the press &#8211; was the publication of newspapers or books. The Brazilian press was officially born in <a href="/wiki/Rio_de_Janeiro" title="Rio de Janeiro">Rio de Janeiro</a> on 13 May 1808, with the creation of the Royal Printing, National Press by the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Prince_Regent" title="Prince Regent">Prince Regent</a> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Jo%C3%A3o_VI_of_Portugal" title="Jo&#227;o VI of Portugal">Dom Jo&#227;o</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Echevarr&#237;aPupo-Walker1996_337-0"><a href="#cite_note-Echevarr&#237;aPupo-Walker1996-337">[336]</a></sup>\n</p><p>The <i>Gazeta do Rio de Janeiro</i>, the first newspaper published in the country, began to circulate on 10 September 1808.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Johnston2003_338-0"><a href="#cite_note-Johnston2003-338">[337]</a></sup> The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_newspapers_in_the_world_by_circulation" title="List of newspapers in the world by circulation">largest newspapers</a> nowadays are <i><a href="/wiki/Folha_de_S.Paulo" title="Folha de S.Paulo">Folha de S.Paulo</a></i> (from the state of S&#227;o Paulo), <i>Super Not&#237;cia</i> (Minas Gerais 296.799), <i><a href="/wiki/O_Globo" title="O Globo">O Globo</a></i> (RJ 277.876) and <i><a href="/wiki/O_Estado_de_S._Paulo" title="O Estado de S. Paulo">O Estado de S. Paulo</a></i> (SP 235.217).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Vincent2003B_339-0"><a href="#cite_note-Vincent2003B-339">[338]</a></sup>\n</p><p>Radio broadcasting began on 7 September 1922, with a speech by then President Pessoa, and was formalized on 20 April 1923 with the creation of "Radio Society of Rio de Janeiro."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-McCann2004_340-0"><a href="#cite_note-McCann2004-340">[339]</a></sup>\n</p><p>Television in Brazil began officially on 18 September 1950, with the founding of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/TV_Tupi" title="TV Tupi">TV Tupi</a> by <a href="/wiki/Assis_Chateaubriand" title="Assis Chateaubriand">Assis Chateaubriand</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ward2007_341-0"><a href="#cite_note-Ward2007-341">[340]</a></sup> Since then television has grown in the country, creating large public networks such as Globo, SBT, Record and Bandeirantes. Today it is the most important factor in popular culture of Brazilian society, indicated by research showing that as much as 67%<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-342"><a href="#cite_note-342">[341]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-343"><a href="#cite_note-343">[342]</a></sup> of the general population follow the same daily <a href="/wiki/Soap_opera" title="Soap opera">soap opera</a> broadcast. Digital Television, using the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/SBTVD" title="SBTVD">SBTVD</a> standard (based on the Japanese standard <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISDB-T" title="ISDB-T">ISDB-T</a>), was adopted 29 June 2006 and launched on 2 November 2007.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Alencar2009_344-0"><a href="#cite_note-Alencar2009-344">[343]</a></sup> In May 2010, Brazil launched <a href="/wiki/TV_Brasil_Internacional" title="TV Brasil Internacional">TV Brasil Internacional</a>, an international <a href="/wiki/Television_station" title="Television station">television station</a>, initially broadcasting to 49 countries.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-345"><a href="#cite_note-345">[344]</a></sup>\n</p>\n<div style="clear:both;"></div>\n<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Demographics">Demographics</span></h2>\n<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Demographics_of_Brazil" title="Demographics of Brazil">Demographics of Brazil</a> and <a href="/wiki/Brazilians" title="Brazilians">Brazilians</a></div>\n<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Immigration_to_Brazil" title="Immigration to Brazil">Immigration to Brazil</a> and <a href="/wiki/List_of_Brazilian_states_by_population_density" title="List of Brazilian states by population density">List of Brazilian states by population density</a></div>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:302px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:ARCHELLA_E_THERY_Img_05.png"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="603" data-file-width="593" decoding="async" height="305" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2e/ARCHELLA_E_THERY_Img_05.png/300px-ARCHELLA_E_THERY_Img_05.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2e/ARCHELLA_E_THERY_Img_05.png/450px-ARCHELLA_E_THERY_Img_05.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/2/2e/ARCHELLA_E_THERY_Img_05.png 2x" width="300"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:ARCHELLA_E_THERY_Img_05.png" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Population density of Brazilian municipalities</div></div></div>\n<table class="wikitable" style="float: right; margin-left: 10px">\n<tbody><tr>\n<th colspan="4" style="text-align:center; background:#cfb;">Population<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-UN_WPP_346-0"><a href="#cite_note-UN_WPP-346">[345]</a></sup>\n</th></tr>\n<tr>\n<th style="background:#cfb;">Year\n</th>\n<th style="background:#cfb;">Million\n</th></tr>\n<tr>\n<td style="text-align:left;">1950</td>\n<td style="text-align:right;">54.0\n</td></tr>\n<tr>\n<td style="text-align:left;">2000</td>\n<td style="text-align:right;">175.3\n</td></tr>\n<tr>\n<td style="text-align:left;">2016</td>\n<td style="text-align:right;">207.7\n</td></tr></tbody></table>\n<p>The population of Brazil, as recorded by the 2008 PNAD, was approximately 190 million<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-347"><a href="#cite_note-347">[346]</a></sup> (22.31 inhabitants per square kilometre or 57.8/sq&#160;mi), with a ratio of men to women of 0.95:1<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-348"><a href="#cite_note-348">[347]</a></sup> and 83.75% of the population defined as urban.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-349"><a href="#cite_note-349">[348]</a></sup> The population is heavily concentrated in the Southeastern (79.8&#160;million inhabitants) and Northeastern (53.5&#160;million inhabitants) regions, while the two most extensive regions, the Center-West and the North, which together make up 64.12% of the Brazilian territory, have a total of only 29.1&#160;million inhabitants.\n</p><p>The first census in Brazil was carried out in 1872 and recorded a population of 9,930,478.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-350"><a href="#cite_note-350">[349]</a></sup> From 1880 to 1930, 4 million Europeans arrived.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-351"><a href="#cite_note-351">[350]</a></sup> Brazil\'s population increased significantly between 1940 and 1970, because of a decline in the <a href="/wiki/Mortality_rate" title="Mortality rate">mortality rate</a>, even though the <a href="/wiki/Birth_rate" title="Birth rate">birth rate</a> underwent a slight decline. In the 1940s the annual <a href="/wiki/Population_growth" title="Population growth">population growth rate</a> was 2.4%, rising to 3.0% in the 1950s and remaining at 2.9% in the 1960s, as life expectancy rose from 44 to 54 years<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-352"><a href="#cite_note-352">[351]</a></sup> and to 72.6 years in 2007.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-353"><a href="#cite_note-353">[352]</a></sup>\nIt has been steadily falling since the 1960s, from 3.04% per year between 1950 and 1960 to 1.05% in 2008 and is expected to fall to a negative value of&#160;&#8211;0.29% by 2050<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-354"><a href="#cite_note-354">[353]</a></sup> thus completing the <a href="/wiki/Demographic_transition" title="Demographic transition">demographic transition</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-355"><a href="#cite_note-355">[354]</a></sup>\n</p><p>In 2008, the illiteracy rate was 11.48%<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-356"><a href="#cite_note-356">[355]</a></sup> and among the <a href="/wiki/Youth_in_Brazil" title="Youth in Brazil">youth</a> (ages 15&#8211;19) 1.74%. It was highest (20.30%) in the Northeast, which had a large proportion of rural poor.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-357"><a href="#cite_note-357">[356]</a></sup> Illiteracy was high (24.18%) among the rural population and lower (9.05%) among the urban population.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-358"><a href="#cite_note-358">[357]</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Race_and_ethnicity">Race and ethnicity</span></h3>\n<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Race_and_ethnicity_in_Brazil" title="Race and ethnicity in Brazil">Race and ethnicity in Brazil</a></div>\n<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Fachada_do_Museu_da_Imigra%C3%A7%C3%A3o_de_S%C3%A3o_Paulo.JPG"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3456" data-file-width="5184" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d4/Fachada_do_Museu_da_Imigra%C3%A7%C3%A3o_de_S%C3%A3o_Paulo.JPG/220px-Fachada_do_Museu_da_Imigra%C3%A7%C3%A3o_de_S%C3%A3o_Paulo.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d4/Fachada_do_Museu_da_Imigra%C3%A7%C3%A3o_de_S%C3%A3o_Paulo.JPG/330px-Fachada_do_Museu_da_Imigra%C3%A7%C3%A3o_de_S%C3%A3o_Paulo.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d4/Fachada_do_Museu_da_Imigra%C3%A7%C3%A3o_de_S%C3%A3o_Paulo.JPG/440px-Fachada_do_Museu_da_Imigra%C3%A7%C3%A3o_de_S%C3%A3o_Paulo.JPG 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Fachada_do_Museu_da_Imigra%C3%A7%C3%A3o_de_S%C3%A3o_Paulo.JPG" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Immigration_Museum_of_the_State_of_S%C3%A3o_Paulo" title="Immigration Museum of the State of S&#227;o Paulo">Immigration Museum of the State of S&#227;o Paulo</a> in the neighborhood of <a href="/wiki/Mooca_(district_of_S%C3%A3o_Paulo)" title="Mooca (district of S&#227;o Paulo)">Mooca</a>, in <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/S%C3%A3o_Paulo_city" title="S&#227;o Paulo city">S&#227;o Paulo city</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Italian_Brazilians" title="Italian Brazilians">Italian Brazilians</a> are 15% of the population and the largest Italian community outside <a href="/wiki/Italy" title="Italy">Italy</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-359"><a href="#cite_note-359">[358]</a></sup></div></div></div>\n<p>According to the <a href="/wiki/Brazilian_Institute_of_Geography_and_Statistics" title="Brazilian Institute of Geography and Statistics">National Research by Household Sample</a> (PNAD) of 2008, 48.43% of the population (about 92 million) described themselves as <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/White_Brazilian" title="White Brazilian">White</a>; 43.80% (about 83 million) as <a href="/wiki/Brown_(racial_classification)#Pardos_in_Brazil" title="Brown (racial classification)">Pardo</a> (<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Brown_people" title="Brown people">brown</a>), 6.84% (about 13 million) as <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Black_Brazilian" title="Black Brazilian">Black</a>; 0.58% (about 1.1&#160;million) as <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Asian_Brazilian" title="Asian Brazilian">Asian</a>; and 0.28% (about 536 thousand) as <a href="/wiki/Indigenous_peoples_in_Brazil" title="Indigenous peoples in Brazil">Amerindian</a> (officially called <i>ind&#237;gena</i>, Indigenous), while 0.07% (about 130 thousand) did not declare their race.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-PNADIBGE_360-0"><a href="#cite_note-PNADIBGE-360">[359]</a></sup>\n</p><p>In 2007, the <a href="/wiki/Funda%C3%A7%C3%A3o_Nacional_do_%C3%8Dndio" title="Funda&#231;&#227;o Nacional do &#205;ndio">National Indian Foundation</a> estimated that Brazil has 67 different uncontacted tribes, up from their estimate of 40 in 2005. Brazil is believed to have the largest number of <a href="/wiki/Uncontacted_peoples" title="Uncontacted peoples">uncontacted peoples</a> in the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-361"><a href="#cite_note-361">[360]</a></sup>\n</p><p>Since the arrival of the Portuguese in 1500, considerable <a href="/wiki/Miscegenation" title="Miscegenation">miscegenation</a> between Amerindians, Europeans, and Africans has taken place in all regions of the country (with European ancestry being dominant nationwide according to the vast majority of all autosomal studies undertaken covering the entire population, accounting for between 65% to 77%).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-alvaro.com.br_362-0"><a href="#cite_note-alvaro.com.br-362">[361]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-www1.folha.uol.com.br_363-0"><a href="#cite_note-www1.folha.uol.com.br-363">[362]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-bdtd.bce.unb.br_364-0"><a href="#cite_note-bdtd.bce.unb.br-364">[363]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-plosone.org_365-0"><a href="#cite_note-plosone.org-365">[364]</a></sup>\n</p>\n<div class="PieChartTemplate thumb tright" style=""><div class="thumbinner" style="width:200px">\n<div style="background-color:white;margin:auto;position:relative;width:200px;height:200px;overflow:hidden;border-radius:100px;border:1px solid black">\n<div style="border:solid transparent;position:absolute;width:100px;line-height:0;left:100px; top:100px; border-width:100px 0 0 15915.284869156px; border-left-color:Red"></div>\n<div style="position:absolute;line-height:0;border-style:solid;left:0;top:0;border-width:0 200px 100px 0;border-color:Red"></div>\n<div style="position:absolute;line-height:0;border-style:solid;left:0;top:0;border-width:0 100px 200px 0;border-color:Red"></div><div style="border:solid transparent;position:absolute;width:100px;line-height:0;left:100px; top:100px; border-width:100px 0 0 3182.0515953785px; border-left-color:#FFE135"></div>\n<div style="position:absolute;line-height:0;border-style:solid;left:0;top:0;border-width:0 200px 100px 0;border-color:#FFE135"></div>\n<div style="position:absolute;line-height:0;border-style:solid;left:0;top:0;border-width:0 100px 200px 0;border-color:#FFE135"></div><div style="border:solid transparent;position:absolute;width:100px;line-height:0;left:100px; top:100px; border-width:100px 0 0 991.36510217707px; border-left-color:MediumAquamarine"></div>\n<div style="position:absolute;line-height:0;border-style:solid;left:0;top:0;border-width:0 200px 100px 0;border-color:MediumAquamarine"></div>\n<div style="position:absolute;line-height:0;border-style:solid;left:0;top:0;border-width:0 100px 200px 0;border-color:MediumAquamarine"></div><div style="border:solid transparent;position:absolute;width:100px;line-height:0;left:100px; top:100px; border-width:100px 0 0 153.28270598844px; border-left-color:#9966CC"></div>\n<div style="position:absolute;line-height:0;border-style:solid;left:0;top:0;border-width:0 200px 100px 0;border-color:#9966CC"></div>\n<div style="position:absolute;line-height:0;border-style:solid;left:0;top:0;border-width:0 100px 200px 0;border-color:#9966CC"></div><div style="border:solid transparent;position:absolute;width:100px;line-height:0;right:100px; top:0; border-width:0 687.15418461366px 100px 0; border-right-color:LightBlue"></div>\n<div style="position:absolute;line-height:0;border-style:solid;right:0;top:0;border-width:0 100px 100px 0;border-color:LightBlue"></div>\n</div>\n<div class="thumbcaption">\n<p><a href="/wiki/Race_and_ethnicity_in_Brazil" title="Race and ethnicity in Brazil">Race and ethnicity in Brazil</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-IBGE_Censo_de_2000_366-0"><a href="#cite_note-IBGE_Censo_de_2000-366">[365]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Etnias_Censo_2010_367-0"><a href="#cite_note-Etnias_Censo_2010-367">[366]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-368"><a href="#cite_note-368">[367]</a></sup>\n</p>\n<div class="legend" style="-webkit-column-break-inside: avoid;page-break-inside: avoid;break-inside: avoid-column"><span class="legend-color" style="display:inline-block; width:1.5em; height:1.5em; margin:1px 0; border:1px solid black; background-color:LightBlue; color:black; font-size:100%; text-align:center;">&#160;</span>&#160;<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/White_Brazilian" title="White Brazilian">White</a> (47.7%)</div><div class="legend" style="-webkit-column-break-inside: avoid;page-break-inside: avoid;break-inside: avoid-column"><span class="legend-color" style="display:inline-block; width:1.5em; height:1.5em; margin:1px 0; border:1px solid black; background-color: #9966CC; color:black; font-size:100%; text-align:center;">&#160;</span>&#160;<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Pardo_Brazilian" title="Pardo Brazilian">Pardo</a> (<a href="/wiki/Multiracial#Brazil" title="Multiracial">Multiracial</a>) (43.1%)</div><div class="legend" style="-webkit-column-break-inside: avoid;page-break-inside: avoid;break-inside: avoid-column"><span class="legend-color" style="display:inline-block; width:1.5em; height:1.5em; margin:1px 0; border:1px solid black; background-color:MediumAquamarine; color:black; font-size:100%; text-align:center;">&#160;</span>&#160;<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Black_Brazilian" title="Black Brazilian">Black</a> (7.6%)</div><div class="legend" style="-webkit-column-break-inside: avoid;page-break-inside: avoid;break-inside: avoid-column"><span class="legend-color" style="display:inline-block; width:1.5em; height:1.5em; margin:1px 0; border:1px solid black; background-color: #FFE135; color:black; font-size:100%; text-align:center;">&#160;</span>&#160;<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Asian_Brazilian" title="Asian Brazilian">Asian</a> (1.1%)</div><div class="legend" style="-webkit-column-break-inside: avoid;page-break-inside: avoid;break-inside: avoid-column"><span class="legend-color" style="display:inline-block; width:1.5em; height:1.5em; margin:1px 0; border:1px solid black; background-color:Red; color:black; font-size:100%; text-align:center;">&#160;</span>&#160;<a href="/wiki/Indigenous_peoples_in_Brazil" title="Indigenous peoples in Brazil">Natives</a> (0.4%)</div>\n</div>\n</div></div>\n<p>Brazilian society is more <a href="/wiki/Social_issues_in_Brazil" title="Social issues in Brazil">markedly divided by social class lines</a>, although a high <a href="/wiki/Income_inequality_in_Brazil" title="Income inequality in Brazil">income disparity</a> is found <a href="/wiki/Social_apartheid_in_Brazil" title="Social apartheid in Brazil">between race groups</a>, so <a href="/wiki/Racism" title="Racism">racism</a> and <a href="/wiki/Class_discrimination" title="Class discrimination">classism</a> can be conflated.
