Socially significant closeness to one racial group <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Race_in_Brazil" title="Race in Brazil">is taken in account</a> more in the basis of appearance (<a href="/wiki/Phenotype" title="Phenotype">phenotypes</a>) rather than ancestry, to the extent that full <a href="/wiki/Sibling" title="Sibling">siblings</a> can pertain to different "racial" groups.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-369"><a href="#cite_note-369">[368]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Socioeconomic_status" title="Socioeconomic status">Socioeconomic</a> factors are also significant, because a minority of <i><a href="/wiki/Pardo" title="Pardo">pardos</a></i> are likely to start declaring themselves White or Black if socially upward.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-370"><a href="#cite_note-370">[369]</a></sup> Skin color and facial features do not line quite well with ancestry (usually, Afro-Brazilians are evenly mixed and European ancestry is dominant in Whites and <i>pardos</i> with a significant non-European contribution, but the individual variation is great).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-plosone.org_365-1"><a href="#cite_note-plosone.org-365">[364]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-afrobras_371-0"><a href="#cite_note-afrobras-371">[370]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-372"><a href="#cite_note-372">[371]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-373"><a href="#cite_note-373">[372]</a></sup>\n</p><p>The brown population (officially called <i><a href="/wiki/Pardo" title="Pardo">pardo</a></i> in Portuguese, also colloquially <i><a class="extiw" href="https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/moreno" title="wikt:moreno">moreno</a></i>)<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Coelho_1996,_p.&#160;268_374-0"><a href="#cite_note-Coelho_1996,_p._268-374">[373]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Vesentini_1988,_p.&#160;117_375-0"><a href="#cite_note-Vesentini_1988,_p._117-375">[374]</a></sup> is a broad category that includes <i><a href="/wiki/Caboclo" title="Caboclo">caboclos</a></i> (assimilated Amerindians in general, and descendants of Whites and Natives), <i><a href="/wiki/Mulatto" title="Mulatto">mulatos</a></i> (descendants of primarily Whites and Afro-Brazilians) and <i><a href="/wiki/Zambo" title="Zambo">cafuzos</a></i> (descendants of Afro-Brazilians and Natives).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Coelho_1996,_p.&#160;268_374-1"><a href="#cite_note-Coelho_1996,_p._268-374">[373]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Vesentini_1988,_p.&#160;117_375-1"><a href="#cite_note-Vesentini_1988,_p._117-375">[374]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-376"><a href="#cite_note-376">[375]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-377"><a href="#cite_note-377">[376]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Moreira_1981,_p.&#160;108_378-0"><a href="#cite_note-Moreira_1981,_p._108-378">[377]</a></sup> People of considerable Amerindian ancestry form the majority of the population in the Northern, Northeastern and Center-Western regions.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-379"><a href="#cite_note-379">[378]</a></sup>\n</p><p>Higher percents of Blacks, mulattoes and tri-racials can be found in the eastern coast of the Northeastern region from Bahia to Para&#237;ba<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Moreira_1981,_p.&#160;108_378-1"><a href="#cite_note-Moreira_1981,_p._108-378">[377]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-380"><a href="#cite_note-380">[379]</a></sup> and also in northern Maranh&#227;o,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-381"><a href="#cite_note-381">[380]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-382"><a href="#cite_note-382">[381]</a></sup> southern Minas Gerais<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Azevedo_1971,_p.&#160;161_383-0"><a href="#cite_note-Azevedo_1971,_p._161-383">[382]</a></sup> and in eastern Rio de Janeiro.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Moreira_1981,_p.&#160;108_378-2"><a href="#cite_note-Moreira_1981,_p._108-378">[377]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Azevedo_1971,_p.&#160;161_383-1"><a href="#cite_note-Azevedo_1971,_p._161-383">[382]</a></sup> From the 19th century, Brazil opened its borders to <a href="/wiki/Immigration_to_Brazil" title="Immigration to Brazil">immigration</a>. About five million people from over 60 countries migrated to Brazil between 1808 and 1972, most of them of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Portuguese_Brazilian" title="Portuguese Brazilian">Portuguese</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Italian_Brazilian" title="Italian Brazilian">Italian</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Brazilians_of_Spanish_descent" title="Brazilians of Spanish descent">Spanish</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/German_Brazilian" title="German Brazilian">German</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ukrainian_Brazilian" title="Ukrainian Brazilian">Ukrainian</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Polish_Brazilian" title="Polish Brazilian">Polish</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Jewish_Brazilian" title="Jewish Brazilian">Jewish</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Russians_in_Brazil" title="Russians in Brazil">Russian</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Chinese_Brazilian" title="Chinese Brazilian">Chinese</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Japanese_Brazilian" title="Japanese Brazilian">Japanese</a>, and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Arab_Brazilian" title="Arab Brazilian">Arab</a> origin.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-384"><a href="#cite_note-384">[383]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-385"><a href="#cite_note-385">[384]</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Religion">Religion</span></h3>\n<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Religion_in_Brazil" title="Religion in Brazil">Religion in Brazil</a></div>\n<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Catholic_Church_in_Brazil" title="Catholic Church in Brazil">Catholic Church in Brazil</a> and <a href="/wiki/Protestantism_in_Brazil" title="Protestantism in Brazil">Protestantism in Brazil</a></div>\n<div class="barbox tleft" style="overflow-x: auto;">\n<div style="border:1px solid silver; font-size:88%; padding:0.4em; width:285px; background: white;">\n<table style="text-align:left; border-collapse:collapse; width:100%;">\n<tbody><tr style="background:#ddd"><th colspan="5" style="text-align:center;"><a href="/wiki/Religion_in_Brazil" title="Religion in Brazil">Religion in Brazil</a> <span style="font-size:85%;">(2010 Census)</span></th></tr>\n<tr style="font-size:88%; height:4px;">\n<td style="padding:0 4px; text-align:left;">Religion</td>\n<td style="padding:0 4px; text-align:right;"></td>\n<td style="width:100px; text-align:left;"></td>\n<td style="padding:0 4px; width:1em; text-align:right;">Percent</td>\n<td style="padding:0 4px; text-align:right;"></td>\n</tr>\n<tr>\n<td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; min-width: 8em;"><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Roman_Catholicism_in_Brazil" title="Roman Catholicism in Brazil">Roman Catholicism</a></td>\n<td style="width: 100px; border-left: solid 1px silver; border-right: solid 1px silver;"><div style="background:lightblue; width:64.6%; overflow: hidden;">&#8201;</div></td>\n<td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; text-align: right;">64.6%</td>\n</tr>\n<tr>\n<td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; min-width: 8em;"><a href="/wiki/Protestantism_in_Brazil" title="Protestantism in Brazil">Protestantism</a></td>\n<td style="width: 100px; border-left: solid 1px silver; border-right: solid 1px silver;"><div style="background:blue; width:22.2%; overflow: hidden;">&#8201;</div></td>\n<td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; text-align: right;">22.2%</td>\n</tr>\n<tr>\n<td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; min-width: 8em;"><a href="/wiki/Irreligion" title="Irreligion">No religion</a></td>\n<td style="width: 100px; border-left: solid 1px silver; border-right: solid 1px silver;"><div style="background:lightgray; width:8.0%; overflow: hidden;">&#8201;</div></td>\n<td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; text-align: right;">8.0%</td>\n</tr>\n<tr>\n<td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; min-width: 8em;"><a href="/wiki/Spiritism" title="Spiritism">Spiritism</a></td>\n<td style="width: 100px; border-left: solid 1px silver; border-right: solid 1px silver;"><div style="background:purple; width:2.0%; overflow: hidden;">&#8201;</div></td>\n<td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; text-align: right;">2.0%</td>\n</tr>\n<tr>\n<td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; min-width: 8em;">Others</td>\n<td style="width: 100px; border-left: solid 1px silver; border-right: solid 1px silver;"><div style="background:yellow; width:3.2%; overflow: hidden;">&#8201;</div></td>\n<td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; text-align: right;">3.2%</td>\n</tr>\n</tbody></table>\n</div>\n</div>\n<p>Religion in Brazil was formed from the meeting of the Catholic Church with the religious traditions of enslaved African peoples and indigenous peoples.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BoyleSheen2013_386-0"><a href="#cite_note-BoyleSheen2013-386">[385]</a></sup> This confluence of faiths during the Portuguese colonization of Brazil led to the development of a diverse array of syncretistic practices within the overarching umbrella of Brazilian Catholic Church, characterized by traditional Portuguese festivities,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-georgetown1_387-0"><a href="#cite_note-georgetown1-387">[386]</a></sup> and in some instances, <a href="/wiki/Allan_Kardec" title="Allan Kardec">Allan Kardec</a>\'s <a href="/wiki/Spiritism" title="Spiritism">Spiritism</a> (a religion which incorporates elements of <a href="/wiki/Spiritualism" title="Spiritualism">spiritualism</a> and Christianity). Religious pluralism increased during the 20th century,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Morris2006a_388-0"><a href="#cite_note-Morris2006a-388">[387]</a></sup> and the Protestant community has grown to include over 22% of the population.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-JeynesRobinson2012_389-0"><a href="#cite_note-JeynesRobinson2012-389">[388]</a></sup> The most common Protestant denominations are <a href="/wiki/Pentecostalism" title="Pentecostalism">Pentecostal</a> and <a href="/wiki/Evangelicalism" title="Evangelicalism">Evangelical</a> ones. Other Protestant branches with a notable presence in the country include the <a href="/wiki/Baptists" title="Baptists">Baptists</a>, <a href="/wiki/Seventh-day_Adventist_Church" title="Seventh-day Adventist Church">Seventh-day Adventists</a>, <a href="/wiki/Lutheranism" title="Lutheranism">Lutherans</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Calvinism" title="Calvinism">Reformed tradition</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-390"><a href="#cite_note-390">[389]</a></sup>\n</p>\n<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r856303569" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="thumb tmulti tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:422px;max-width:422px"><div class="tsingle" style="float:left;margin:1px;width:206px;max-width:206px"><div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:1_cristor_redentor_2014.jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="4300" data-file-width="6432" decoding="async" height="136" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a1/1_cristor_redentor_2014.jpg/204px-1_cristor_redentor_2014.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a1/1_cristor_redentor_2014.jpg/306px-1_cristor_redentor_2014.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a1/1_cristor_redentor_2014.jpg/408px-1_cristor_redentor_2014.jpg 2x" width="204"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left">The <i><a href="/wiki/Christ_the_Redeemer_(statue)" title="Christ the Redeemer (statue)">Christ the Redeemer</a></i> statue in <a href="/wiki/Rio_de_Janeiro" title="Rio de Janeiro">Rio de Janeiro</a> is one of the most famous religious statues worldwide<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-392"><a href="#cite_note-392">[391]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-393"><a href="#cite_note-393">[392]</a></sup></div></div><div class="tsingle" style="float:left;margin:1px;width:212px;max-width:212px"><div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Basilica_of_the_National_Shrine_of_Our_Lady_of_Aparecida,_2007.jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="1611" data-file-width="2480" decoding="async" height="136" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/62/Basilica_of_the_National_Shrine_of_Our_Lady_of_Aparecida%2C_2007.jpg/210px-Basilica_of_the_National_Shrine_of_Our_Lady_of_Aparecida%2C_2007.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/62/Basilica_of_the_National_Shrine_of_Our_Lady_of_Aparecida%2C_2007.jpg/315px-Basilica_of_the_National_Shrine_of_Our_Lady_of_Aparecida%2C_2007.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/62/Basilica_of_the_National_Shrine_of_Our_Lady_of_Aparecida%2C_2007.jpg/420px-Basilica_of_the_National_Shrine_of_Our_Lady_of_Aparecida%2C_2007.jpg 2x" width="210"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left"><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Basilica_of_the_National_Shrine_of_Our_Lady_of_Aparecida" title="Basilica of the National Shrine of Our Lady of Aparecida">Basilica of the National Shrine of Our Lady of Aparecida</a> in <a href="/wiki/Aparecida" title="Aparecida">Aparecida</a>, <a href="/wiki/S%C3%A3o_Paulo_(state)" title="S&#227;o Paulo (state)">S&#227;o Paulo</a>, is the second largest <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Roman_Catholicism_in_Brazil" title="Roman Catholicism in Brazil">Catholic</a> church in the world<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-391"><a href="#cite_note-391">[390]</a></sup></div></div><div style="clear:left"></div></div></div>\n<p><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Roman_Catholicism" title="Roman Catholicism">Roman Catholicism</a> is the country\'s predominant faith. Brazil has the world\'s largest Catholic population.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-USDS_394-0"><a href="#cite_note-USDS-394">[393]</a></sup> According to the 2000 Demographic Census (the PNAD survey does not inquire about religion), 73.57% of the population followed <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Roman_Catholicism_in_Brazil" title="Roman Catholicism in Brazil">Roman Catholicism</a>; 15.41% <a href="/wiki/Protestantism_in_Brazil" title="Protestantism in Brazil">Protestantism</a>; 1.33% Kardecist spiritism; 1.22% other Christian denominations; 0.31% Afro-Brazilian religions; 0.13% <a href="/wiki/Buddhism" title="Buddhism">Buddhism</a>; 0.05% <a href="/wiki/Judaism" title="Judaism">Judaism</a>; 0.02% <a href="/wiki/Islam_in_Brazil" title="Islam in Brazil">Islam</a>; 0.01% Amerindian religions; 0.59% other religions, undeclared or undetermined; while 7.35% have no religion.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Censo2000Religiao_395-0"><a href="#cite_note-Censo2000Religiao-395">[394]</a></sup>\n</p><p>However, in the last ten years Protestantism, particularly in forms of Pentecostalism and Evangelicalism, has spread in Brazil, while the proportion of Catholics has dropped significantly.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-georgetown2_396-0"><a href="#cite_note-georgetown2-396">[395]</a></sup> After Protestantism, individuals professing no religion are also a significant group, exceeding 7% of the population as of the 2000 census. The cities of <a href="/wiki/Boa_Vista,_Roraima" title="Boa Vista, Roraima">Boa Vista</a>, <a href="/wiki/Salvador,_Bahia" title="Salvador, Bahia">Salvador</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Porto_Velho" title="Porto Velho">Porto Velho</a> have the greatest proportion of <a href="/wiki/Irreligion" title="Irreligion">Irreligious</a> residents in Brazil. <a href="/wiki/Teresina" title="Teresina">Teresina</a>, <a href="/wiki/Fortaleza" title="Fortaleza">Fortaleza</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Florian%C3%B3polis" title="Florian&#243;polis">Florian&#243;polis</a> were the most Roman Catholic in the country.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FGV_no_G1_397-0"><a href="#cite_note-FGV_no_G1-397">[396]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Greater_Rio_de_Janeiro" title="Greater Rio de Janeiro">Greater Rio de Janeiro</a>, not including the <a href="/wiki/Rio_de_Janeiro" title="Rio de Janeiro">city proper</a>, is the most irreligious and least Roman Catholic Brazilian periphery, while <a href="/wiki/Greater_Porto_Alegre" title="Greater Porto Alegre">Greater Porto Alegre</a> and Greater <a href="/wiki/Fortaleza" title="Fortaleza">Fortaleza</a> are on the opposite sides of the lists, respectively.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FGV_no_G1_397-1"><a href="#cite_note-FGV_no_G1-397">[396]</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Urbanization">Urbanization</span></h3>\n<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/List_of_largest_cities_in_Brazil" title="List of largest cities in Brazil">List of largest cities in Brazil</a> and <a href="/wiki/Municipalities_of_Brazil" title="Municipalities of Brazil">Municipalities of Brazil</a></div>\n<p>According to IBGE (Brazilian Institute of Geography and Statistics) urban areas already concentrate 84.35% of the population, while the Southeast region remains the most populated one, with over 80 million inhabitants.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-398"><a href="#cite_note-398">[397]</a></sup>\nThe largest urban agglomerations in Brazil are <a href="/wiki/S%C3%A3o_Paulo" title="S&#227;o Paulo">S&#227;o Paulo</a>, <a href="/wiki/Rio_de_Janeiro" title="Rio de Janeiro">Rio de Janeiro</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Belo_Horizonte" title="Belo Horizonte">Belo Horizonte</a> &#8211; all in the Southeastern Region &#8211; with 21.1, 12.3, and 5.1&#160;million inhabitants respectively.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-concentra&#231;&#245;es_urbanas_399-0"><a href="#cite_note-concentra&#231;&#245;es_urbanas-399">[398]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-400"><a href="#cite_note-400">[399]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-401"><a href="#cite_note-401">[400]</a></sup> The majority of state capitals are the largest cities in their states, except for <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Vit%C3%B3ria,_Brazil" title="Vit&#243;ria, Brazil">Vit&#243;ria</a>, the capital of <a href="/wiki/Esp%C3%ADrito_Santo" title="Esp&#237;rito Santo">Esp&#237;rito Santo</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Florian%C3%B3polis" title="Florian&#243;polis">Florian&#243;polis</a>, the capital of Santa Catarina.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-402"><a href="#cite_note-402">[401]</a></sup>\n</p>\n<table class="navbox">\n<tbody><tr>\n<th class="navbox-title" colspan="10"><div style="float:right; width:6em; height:2.6em">&#160;</div><div class="plainlinks hlist navbar mini" style="float: template">v</abbr></a></li><li class="nv-talk"><a href="/wiki/Template_talk:Largest_urban_agglomerations_in_Brazil" title="Template talk:Largest urban agglomerations in Brazil"><abbr title="Discuss this template">t</abbr></a></li><li class="nv-edit"><a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Template:Largest_urban_agglomerations_in_Brazil&amp;action=edit"><abbr title="Edit this template">e</abbr></a></li></ul></div> <div style="height:2.6em;line-height:1.3em;"><span style="font-size:110%;">Largest urban agglomerations in Brazil</span><br/><div
